 <h2>
  <a name="A_About_this_policy">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      1. About this policy
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h2>
 <h3>
  <a name="R_Why_this_policy">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      1.1 Why this policy
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h3>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    The purpose of this policy is to provide an overview of:
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <ul>
  <li>
   Costs which can be included in the loan amount
  </li>
  <li>
   Consumer mortgage application forms and declarations
  </li>
  <li>
   Power of Attorney rules
  </li>
  <li>
   Business lending customer rules
  </li>
  <li>
   Rules relating to:
   <ul>
    <li>
     validating information provided by the customer
    </li>
    <li>
     the currency of completed verification activities
    </li>
    <li>
     the age of verification documents
    </li>
    <li>
     expiry dates associated with the consumer mortgage application
    </li>
   </ul>
  </li>
 </ul>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    If the loan application requires mortgage insurance, refer to
   </span>
   <em>
    <span>
     <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000725">
      Lenders Mortgage Insurance
     </a>
    </span>
   </em>
  </span>
  <span>
   where required.
  </span>
 </span>
 <h2>
  <a name="R_Rules_you_must_apply">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      2. Rules you must apply
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h2>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    Note: Mortgage brokers are unable to submit their own applications i.e., where the finance broker submitting the application is also one of the applicants.  Brokers are still able to submit loans for their family (as long as they are not an applicant) and they are also able to have another finance broker within their group submit a loan on their behalf.
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <h3>
  <a name="R_Loan_Amount-including_costs">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      2.1 Loan Amount-including costs
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h3>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    Costs associated with the purchase of the collateral (e.g. legal fees and stamp duty) can be included in the loan amount, providing the maximum lending value ratio is
    <strong>
     <span>
      not
     </span>
    </strong>
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <span>
  <span>
   exceeded.
   <br/>
  </span>
 </span>
 <h4>
  <a name="R_Interest_only_in_advance_(IOA)_loans">
  </a>
  <span>
   <strong>
    <span>
     <span>
      2.1.1 Interest only in advance (IOA) loans
     </span>
    </span>
   </strong>
  </span>
 </h4>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    The initial amount of prepaid interest can
    <strong>
     <span>
      not
     </span>
    </strong>
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <span>
  <span>
   be added to the loan amount. The borrower is to provide this amount from their own funds.
   <br/>
  </span>
 </span>
 <h3>
  <a name="R_Customer_Interview">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      2.2 Customer Interview
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h3>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    A formal face to face interview should be completed with the loan applicant(s) or guarantor(s) before acceptance of the loan offer agreement.
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <div>
  <span>
   <span>
    <span>
     <strong>
      The interview process is to be carried out without the presence of a third party – must be between the Broker and applicant(s) or guarantor(s).
     </strong>
    </span>
   </span>
  </span>
 </div>
 <h3>
 </h3>
 <h3>
  <a name="R_Customers_Experiencing_Vulnerability">
  </a>
  <strong>
   2.3 Customers Experiencing Vulnerability
  </strong>
 </h3>
 Refer to
 <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000694">
  <em>
   Eligibility
  </em>
 </a>
 &gt;Customers Experiencing Vulnerability policy
 <br/>
 <h3>
  <a id="2.4 In Principle Approval (IPA)" name="2.4 In Principle Approval (IPA)">
   2.4 In Principle Approval (IPA)
  </a>
 </h3>
 In Principle Approval (IPA) is an application type which seeks 'Conditional Approval' only.
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    <span>
     Verification of supporting documentation and security collateral assessment is
     <b>
      not mandatory
     </b>
     .
    </span>
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    <span>
     Consent forms and verification of identity (VOI) must be completed prior to ‘
    </span>
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 Review and Submit’ being undertaken for an IPA. Also see:
 <ul>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <a href="#R_Acknowledgments,_confirmations_and_con">
      <strong>
       <span>
        Acknowledgments, confirmations and consents (for 1
        <sup>
         st
        </sup>
        and 3
        <sup>
         rd
        </sup>
        party channel) or Privacy Statement and other acknowledgements (for digital applications) (Consent Form),
       </span>
      </strong>
     </a>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <a href="#R_Playback_Form">
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <strong>
         <span>
          Playback form
         </span>
        </strong>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </a>
  </li>
  <li>
   <a href="#2.6 Responsible Lending Start Date">
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         <strong>
          <span>
           Responsible Lending Start Date
          </span>
         </strong>
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </a>
  </li>
 </ul>
 When a borrower elects to proceed with the consumer mortgage application, the IPA needs to be converted to a ‘full consumer mortgage application’.
 <br/>
 <b>
  Note:
 </b>
 You can-not convert a full application back to an IPA.
 <div>
  <div>
   <h3>
    <a name="R_Conditional_Approval_Validity_period">
    </a>
    <strong>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        2.4.1 In Principle Approval (IPA) / Conditional Approval Validity period
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </strong>
   </h3>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      The in principle approval (conditional approval) letter or notification has a validity period of 90 days from the most recent application Review and Submit date (both IPA and Full application stage). The expiry period ends either when the customer mortgage application is unconditionally approved, or the consumer mortgage application is edited and re-assessed resulting in a new in principle approval (conditional approval).
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </div>
 </div>
 <h3>
 </h3>
 <h3>

   2.5 Full application
  </a>
 </h3>
 A Full consumer mortgage application is an application type which seeks 'Formal Approval' (Unconditional Approval)
 <br/>
 <span>

     An application may be created as a ‘full application’ or may be converted from an IPA to a ‘full application’.

     Verification of supporting documentation and security assessment

      is mandatory

     for Full Applications.

   </span>
  </span>

 <br/>
 <span>

     Consent forms and verification of identity (VOI) must be completed prior to ‘
    </span>
   </span>
  </span>

 Review and Submit’ being undertaken for a full application.

  <a id="2.7.1 Reviewing customer provided information" name="2.7.1 Reviewing customer provided information">
   <strong>
    <span>
     <span>
      2.7.1
      <span>
       Reviewing customer provided information
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </strong>
  </a>
 </h4>
 <table>
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="3" valign="top">
     <h4 align="center">
      <span>
       <span>
        What to review
       </span>
      </span>
     </h4>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="3" valign="top">
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          The last three months of internal account
          <sup>
           1
          </sup>
          transactions (excluding non Flexi WBC Personal Loans)
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          Supporting documents used to comply with normal loan assessment policy (e.g. income verification)
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          Any document received,
          <b>
           even if it is not mandatory
          </b>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          Comprehensive Credit Bureau report (CCR) – manually review the CCR
          <b>
           for
          </b>
          new loans and loan increases only. Refer to
          <a data-tagid="4. CCR Mismatch" href="#4. CCR Mismatch">
           Comprehensive Credit Report (CCR) Mismatch
          </a>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <h4 align="center">
      <span>
       <span>
        Conflicts to look for
       </span>
      </span>
     </h4>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <h4>
      <span>
       <span>
        Action required
       </span>
      </span>
     </h4>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <b>
         <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000690">
          Commitments
         </a>
         :
        </b>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           Any commitment:
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
       <ul>
        <li>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             that is
             <b>
              u
             </b>
             <b>
              ndisclosed
             </b>
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
       </ul>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           where there is
           <b>
            mismatch
           </b>
           to the Comprehensive Credit Bureau Report (CCR)
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
    <td rowspan="3" valign="top">
     <strong>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         Where a conflict is identified
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </strong>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     With the exception of outgoing child support (maintenance) payments, outgoing alimony (spousal support) and outgoing rent / board, it is not a requirement to obtain further supporting documents to specifically validate expense related outgoings.
     <br/>
     <br/>
     1. Clarify the conflicts with the applicant(s). You may be required to obtain additional supporting documents to verify the commitment.
     <br/>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Refer to
       <i>
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000690" role="link" target="_blank">
         Commitments
        </a>
       </i>
       policy for details of how to verify commitments
      </li>
     </ul>
     2. Amend or update the application to reflect the information found. Re-complete assessments and re-run credit decision if required. If serviceability is still met, continue with application processing.
     <br/>
     <br/>
     3. Where serviceability is not met with the updated information, then clarify any conflicts with the applicant(s) and either further update
     <b>
      or
     </b>
     withdraw the application.
     <br/>
     <br/>
     4. Enter application comments detailing any amendments made to the application and / or the outcome of all related customer discussions. This will provide an audit trail and prevent rework.
     <br/>
     <br/>
     5. Enter a final comment in the application confirming the account review activity has been completed
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <b>
         <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000700">
          Living Expenses
         </a>
         :
        </b>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <b>
            Undisclosed
           </b>
           :
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
       <ul>
        <li>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             outgoing child support (maintenance) payments
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li>
         <span>

 <h4>
 </h4>
 <h3>
  <a name="R_Currency_of_Verification">
  </a>
  <strong>
   2.8 Currency of Verification
  </strong>
 </h3>
 <div>
  Verifications completed in the consumer mortgage application remain current until any one or more of the following occur:
 </div>
 <ul>
  <li>
   Any ‘loan expiry’ type occurs. Refer to
   <em>
    ‘
    <a href="#R_Loan_Expiry_Types_and_Rules">
     Loan Expiry Types and Rules’
    </a>
   </em>
  </li>
  <li>
   Advice is received that information upon which the verification was based has changed (e.g. income details change).
  </li>
 </ul>
 <h3>
  <br/>
 </h3>

   <div id="_com_1" language="JavaScript" onmouseout="msoCommentHide('_com_1')" onmouseover="msoCommentShow('_anchor_1','_com_1')">
    <br/>
    <br/>
    <a name="R_Acknowledgments,_confirmations_and_con">
    </a>
    <strong>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        2.10 Acknowledgments, confirmations and consents (for 1
        <sup>
         <span>
          st
         </span>
        </sup>
        and 3
        <sup>
         <span>
          rd
         </span>
        </sup>
        party channel) or Privacy Statement and other acknowledgements (for digital applications) (Consent Form)
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </strong>
   </div>
  </div>
 </div>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    All consumer mortgage applications require a Consent Form to be signed and dated or accepted digitally by the applicants (and guarantors, if any), prior to credit decisioning.
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    Also refer to
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <em>
  <span>
   <span>
    <span>
     <a href="#R_Power_of_Attorney/Administration_Order">
      Power of Attorney/Administration order
     </a>
    </span>
   </span>
  </span>
 </em>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    where this applies to the application.
    <br/>
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <h3>
  <a name="R_Playback_Form">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      2.11 Playback Form
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h3>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    The Playback Form has been designed to provide the borrower's with an overview of the information captured including the credit assessment within their consumer mortgage application.
    <br/>
    Upon submission of a consumer mortgage application for assessment (In principle approval (IPA) and Full Applications), a copy of the Playback Form is to be provided to the borrower's by the Bank.
    <br/>
    This information is available online in the borrower’s application tracker via Internet Banking (once registered) and can also be provided physically where needed.
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    The playback form is also accepted as being accurate by the borrower as part of the loan offer document pack.
    <br/>
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <h3>
  <a name="R_Power_of_Attorney/Administration_Order">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      2.12 Power of Attorney/Administration Order
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h3>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    Where a Power of Attorney (POA) or Administration Order is in place the Attorney/Administrator must act in the best interests of the donor (person giving the Power of Attorney) and
    <strong>
     <span>
      not
     </span>
    </strong>
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <span>
  <span>
   in the best interests of themselves.
   <br/>
   <br/>
   The Bank’s obligations under
   <em>
    <span>
     The Privacy Act
    </span>
   </em>
  </span>
  advises that
  <strong>
   <span>
    an Attorney cannot  sign or digitally accept
   </span>
  </strong>
 </span>
 the
 <a href="#R_Acknowledgments,_confirmations_and_con">
  <span>
   <em>
    <span>
     <span>
      Consent Forms
     </span>
    </span>
   </em>
  </span>
 </a>
 <span>
  <strong>
   <span>
    on behalf of a borrower / donor where the borrower has capacity
   </span>
  </strong>
 </span>
 <span>
  . Credit (or other Credit Risk authorised staff) approval is required when the
 </span>
 <a href="#R_Acknowledgments,_confirmations_and_con">
  <em>
   <span>
    <span>
     Consent Form
    </span>
   </span>
  </em>
 </a>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    has not been signed or digitally accepted by the donor.
    <br/>
    <br/>
    Brokers must also refer to
   </span>
   <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000694">
    <em>
     <span>
      Eligibility
     </span>
    </em>
   </a>
  </span>
  <span>
   &gt;Customers Experiencing Vulnerability and ensure that relevant criteria is applied.
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    The table below outlines the types of authorities that need to be considered.

  </span>

 <h3>
  <a name="R_Business_Purpose_Declaration">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      2.13 Business Purpose Declaration
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h3>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    If the loan purpose established is wholly or predominantly (i.e. more than or equal to 50%) for business purposes then it is not eligible for a consumer product and must the referred to Business banking. Refer to
   </span>
   <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000694">
    <em>
     <span>
      Eligibility
     </span>
    </em>
   </a>
  </span>
  <span>
   .
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    It is the Broker or Assessor's responsibility to determine whether a loan agreement is to be regulated or not under the National Credit Code. This is determined from loan purpose (not the collateral/s offered to support the loan).
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    As a guide the following questions may be used to assist Brokers or Assessors in determining whether the loan is regulated or not under NCC:
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <ol>
  <li>
   Is this loan in a Company Name? (If
   <strong>
    <span>
     YES
    </span>
   </strong>
   , never regulate.)
  </li>
  <li>
   Will another property be the principal place of residence?
  </li>
  <li>
   Are the loan funds to be used for any business purposes and / or investment purposes other than investment in residential property?
  </li>
  <li>
   Are the loan funds to be used wholly or predominantly for business purpose and /or investment purposes other than investing in residential property?
  </li>
 </ol>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    Where the answer to questions 1, 3-4 inclusive is
    <strong>
     <span>
      YES
     </span>
    </strong>
   </span>
   , the loan may be unregulated.
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <h3>
  <span>
   <a name="R_Loan_Expiry_Types_and_Rules">
   </a>
   <span>
    <strong>
     <span>
      2.14 Loan Expiry Types and Rules
     </span>
    </strong>
   </span>
  </span>
 </h3>
 <span>
  <span>
   The below expiry dates apply to loan applications
   <br/>
  </span>
 </span>
 <table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="1" width="690">
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <strong>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         Loan Expiry Type
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </strong>
    </td>
    <td>
     <strong>
      Start Date
     </strong>
    </td>
    <td>
     <strong>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         Expiry Occurs when
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </strong>
    </td>
    <td>
     <strong>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         If expiry occurs
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </strong>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Responsible Lending
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      • First Apply Online (AOL) submission date (as either an IPA or Full Application), or
     </span>
     <br/>
     <span>
      • If the expiry period has lapsed:
     </span>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        The first AOL resubmission date
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         following the expiry.
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <strong>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         Loan - where the purchase is residential property and the credit will be secured by a mortgage over the same residential collateral:
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </strong>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       <br/>
       The expiry period ends when the borrower has signed and returned their loan offer.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       The expiry period is 120 calendar days from the Start Date.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       In the 120-day period prior to the end date, the following needs to have occurred:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       reasonable inquiries regarding the customer’s requirements and objectives and financial situation
      </li>
      <li>
       reasonable steps to verify the borrower’s financial situation
      </li>
      <li>
       an unsuitability assessment for the credit contract including a credit assessment
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <strong>
         <span>
          Loan – other
         </span>
        </strong>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       The expiry period ends when the customer has signed and returned their loan offer. The expiry period is 90 calendar days from the Start Date.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       In the 90-day period prior to the end date, the following needs to have occurred:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       reasonable inquiries regarding the customer’s requirements and objectives and financial situation
      </li>
      <li>
       reasonable steps to verify the borrower’s financial situation
      </li>
      <li>
       an unsuitability assessment for the credit contract including a credit assessment
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
    <td rowspan="2">
     If the expiry period lapses, the consumer mortgage application will be forced to be edited. The assessor must advise the broker to resubmit the application in AOL .
     <br/>
     <br/>
     Broker must ensure that all the details provided within the application are reconfirmed with borrower prior to re-submission
     <br/>
     <br/>
     Upon re-submitting the application, the RL expiry period will be reset, and documents must be re-verified.
     <br/>
     Refer to Verification
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <br/>
        <u>
         <strong>
          Verification
         </strong>
        </u>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     Verification tasks must be completed and updated / new verification documentation is required where:
     <ul>
      <li>
       the relevant verification document has ‘expired’, i.e. it does not meet the ‘maximum age’ policy against the new Responsible Lending Start Date
      </li>
      <li>
       Information requiring verification has changed (e.g. income has changed)
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <br/>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="1" rowspan="2">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Loan Drawdown
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Loan Offer generated date
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <strong>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         For single draw loans:
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </strong>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Loan not drawn within 180 days of the Start Date.
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <strong>
         <span>
          For Progress Draw loans:
         </span>
        </strong>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       Initial draw down has not occurred within 12 months of the Start Date.
       <br/>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     Loan Offer Expiry
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         The loan offer prints an expiry period of 14 days from the date of generation.
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
      <br/>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         The purpose of this expiry is to ensure it is actioned in a timely manner. If the loan offer is returned after 14 days but within any other expiry periods, it can be accepted without any further action.
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         If the RL expiry date is sooner than the loan offer 14 day expiry period, the loan offer will expire in line with the RL expiry date. The consumer mortgage application must be re-submitted and re-assessed with a new loan offer generated.
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
  </tbody>
 </table>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    <br/>
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <h2>
  <a id="4. CCR Mismatch" name="4. CCR Mismatch" role="link" target="_blank">
   <strong>
    3. Comprehensive Credit Report (CCR) Mismatch
   </strong>
  </a>
 </h2>
 Where a mismatch is identified during manual review of the report, further investigation and action is required. For specific scenarios, refer to the table below:
 <br/>
 <table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="678">
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2">
     <h4>
      <strong>
       Scenario
      </strong>
     </h4>
    </td>
    <td>
     <h4>
      <strong>
       Action
      </strong>
     </h4>
    </td>
    <td>
     <h4>
      <strong>
       Additional requirements
      </strong>
     </h4>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <strong>
      1
     </strong>
    </td>
    <td>
     <strong>
      The applicant advises the facility has been closed but the CCR still shows the account as open.
     </strong>
     <br/>
    </td>
    <td>
     Evidence that the account has been closed must be obtained prior to formal approval. Refer to
     <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000710" role="link" target="_blank">
      <em>
       Serviceability assessment
      </em>
     </a>
     &gt; Rules &gt;Amended current commitment
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <strong>
      Note:
     </strong>
     If unable to obtain evidence of closure, then the commitment is to be included in the serviceability assessment
    </td>
    <td>
     Enter application comments detailing the outcome of all related customer discussions
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <strong>
      2
     </strong>
    </td>
    <td>
     <strong>
      The applicant advises the facility has been paid back, but the CCR shows the account is still open as they have not formally closed the facility
     </strong>
     <br/>
    </td>
    <td>
     Further enquires are to be made with the applicant:
     <br/>
     <br/>
     If the applicant wants to retain the facility, then the commitment is to be included in the serviceability assessment. Verify the details of the commitment as per
     <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000690" role="link" target="_blank">
      <em>
       Commitments
      </em>
     </a>
     &gt; Verifying customer commitments
     <br/>
     <br/>
     If the applicant does not want to retain the facility, they will need to provide evidence the facility has been closed as per Scenario 1
    </td>
    <td>
     Enter application comments detailing the outcome of all related customer discussions
     <br/>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td rowspan="2">
     <strong>
      3
     </strong>
    </td>
    <td rowspan="2">
     <strong>
      The CCR shows an open facility that the borrower forgot and did not declare
     </strong>
     <br/>
    </td>
    <td>
     Where the CCR contains:
     <ul>
      <li>
       <b>
        a maximum of one
       </b>
       undisclosed / undeclared debt (facility) per application
       <b>
        and
       </b>
       the debt is
       <b>
        either
       </b>
       :
       <ul>
        <li>
         a Credit Card
         <b>
          or
         </b>
        </li>
        <li>
         an Overdraft (unsecured / non-mortgage)
        </li>
       </ul>
      </li>
      <li>
       <b>
        and
       </b>
       the current months repayment history status* displays a 0 (zero) refer to and follow the additional requirements.
      </li>
     </ul>
     <br/>
     * Repayment history on CCR appears from right to left. Right = current month at the time the report was generated (most recent month) to oldest month (being month 24). For more information about repayment history status refer to
     <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000690" role="link" target="_blank">
      Commitments
     </a>
     policy &gt; On CCR – Repayment history criteria
    </td>
    <td>
     For the previously undisclosed / undeclared commitment:
     <ul>
      <li>
       Verify the details of the commitment as per
       <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000690" role="link" target="_blank">
        Commitments
       </a>
       &gt; Verifying customer commitments
      </li>
      <li>
       Re-complete serviceability assessments as per
       <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000710" role="link" target="_blank">
        Serviceability Assessment
       </a>
       &gt; Commitments &gt; Serviceability repayment amount
      </li>
      <li>
       Re-run credit decision if required
      </li>
     </ul>
     <br/>
     Where serviceability is met with the additional commitment included, proceed with application processing.
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <b>
      Note
     </b>
     : No referral to the applicant is required.  Inclusion of the additional commitment will result in a more conservative serviceability assessment outcome.
     <br/>
     <br/>
     If serviceability
     <b>
      is not met
     </b>
     with the additional commitment included further enquires are to be made with the applicant:
     <ul>
      <li>
       If the applicant wants to retain the facility, then the commitment is to be included in the serviceability assessment (refer to
       <b>
        Scenario 2
       </b>
       &gt; Additional requirements)
      </li>
     </ul>
     If the applicant does not want to retain the facility, they will need to provide evidence the facility has been closed. Evidence must be obtained
     <b>
      prior
     </b>
     to formal approval (refer to
     <b>
      Scenario 1
     </b>
     Action
     <b>
      and
     </b>
     Additional requirements)
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     Where the CCR contains:
     <ul>
      <li>
       &gt; 1 undisclosed / undeclared Credit card
       <b>
        or
       </b>
       Overdraft (unsecured / non-mortgage);
       <b>
        or
       </b>
      </li>
      <li>
       The Credit Card
       <b>
        or
       </b>
       an Overdraft (unsecured / non-mortgage)  current months repayment history status does not display a 0 (zero);
       <b>
        or
       </b>
      </li>
      <li>
       The undisclosed / undeclared debt (facility) is not a credit card
       <b>
        or
       </b>
       overdraft (unsecured / non-mortgage)
      </li>
     </ul>
     Further enquires are to be made with the applicant:
     <ul>
      <li>
       If the applicant wants to retain the facility, then the commitment is to be included in the serviceability assessment. Verify the details of the commitment as per
       <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000690" role="link" target="_blank">
        <i>
         Commitments
        </i>
       </a>
       &gt; Verifying customer commitments
      </li>
      <li>
       If the applicant does not want to retain the facility, they will need to provide evidence the facility has been closed as per
       <b>
        Scenario 1
       </b>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
    <td>
     Record in application notes the outcome of all related customer discussions
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <strong>
      4
     </strong>
    </td>
    <td>
     <strong>
      The CCR evidences a lower limit than the value entered into the application / used for the monthly repayment calculation.
     </strong>
     <br/>
     <br/>
    </td>
    <td>
     Where the applicant declared limit is &gt; the CCR limit
     <strong>
      and
     </strong>
     serviceability is able to be demonstrated
     <strong>
      based on the higher customer declared limit.
     </strong>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     This is an allowable variance as per the
     <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000690" role="link" target="_blank">
      <em>
       Commitments
      </em>
     </a>
     policy &gt; Allowable Variances. You may rest on the customer declared limit.
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <strong>
      Note
     </strong>
     : Applicant may have recently increased the limit and it is not yet evident on the CCR.
     <br/>
    </td>
    <td>
     <br/>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <strong>
      5
     </strong>
    </td>
    <td>
     <strong>
      The CCR evidences a lower limit than the value entered into the application / used for the monthly repayment calculation.
     </strong>
     <br/>
     <br/>
    </td>
    <td>
     Where the applicant declared limit is &gt; the CCR limit
     <strong>
      and
     </strong>
     serviceability is not able to be demonstrated
     <strong>
      based on the higher customer declared limit.
     </strong>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     Unable to rest on the CCR limit
     <br/>
     <br/>
     Obtain additional supporting documentation to verify the actual limit.
     <br/>
     <br/>
    </td>
    <td>
     Enter application comments detailing the outcome of all related customer discussions.
     <br/>
     <br/>
     Verify the details of the commitment as per:
     <ul>
      <li>
       <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000690" role="link" target="_blank">
        <em>
         Commitments
        </em>
       </a>
      </li>
      <li>
       <em>
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000710" role="link" target="_blank">
         Serviceability assessment
        </a>
       </em>
       &gt; Assessing commitments &gt; payment amount used for serviceability
      </li>
     </ul>
     Amend or update the application to reflect the verified position.
     <br/>
     <br/>
     Re-complete serviceability assessments, and re-run credit decision if required
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <strong>
      6
     </strong>
    </td>
    <td>
     <strong>
      The CCR evidences a higher limit than the value entered into the application / used for the monthly repayment calculation.
     </strong>
     <br/>
     <br/>
    </td>
    <td>
     Where the applicant declared limit is &lt; the CCR limit
     <strong>
      and
     </strong>
     serviceability is able to be demonstrated
     <strong>
      based on the higher CCR limit
     </strong>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     This is an allowable variance as per the
     <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000690" role="link" target="_blank">
      <em>
       Commitments
      </em>
     </a>
     policy &gt; Allowable Variances. You may rest on the CCR limit.
    </td>
    <td>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <strong>
      7
     </strong>
    </td>
    <td>
     <strong>
      The CCR evidences a higher limit than the value entered into the application / used for the monthly repayment calculation.
     </strong>
     <br/>
    </td>
    <td>
     Where the applicant declared limit is &lt; the CCR limit
     <strong>
      and
     </strong>
     serviceability is not able to be demonstrated
     <strong>
      based on the higher CCR limit.
     </strong>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     Unable to rest on applicant declared limit or CCR limit
     <br/>
     <br/>
     Obtain additional supporting documentation to verify the actual limit.
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <strong>
      Note
     </strong>
     : applicant may have recently decreased the limit and it is not yet evident on credit bureau report.
     <br/>
    </td>
    <td>
     Enter application comments detailing the outcome of all related customer discussions.
     <br/>
     <br/>
     Verify the details of the commitment as per:
     <ul>
      <li>
       <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000690" role="link" target="_blank">
        <em>
         Commitments
        </em>
       </a>
      </li>
      <li>
       <em>
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000710" role="link" target="_blank">
         Serviceability assessment
        </a>
       </em>
       &gt; Assessing commitments &gt; payment amount used for serviceability
      </li>
     </ul>
     <br/>
     Amend or update the application to reflect the verified position.
     <br/>
     <br/>
     Re-complete serviceability assessments, and re-run credit decision if required
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <strong>
      8
     </strong>
    </td>
    <td>
     <strong>
      The applicant declares a facility but it does not appear on the CCR as an open facility.
     </strong>
    </td>
    <td>
     <strong>
      Not all financial institutions participate in CCR and some facility types are not supported for positive reporting
     </strong>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     Obtain an alternate supporting documentation to verify the customer declared commitment
    </td>
    <td>
     Verify the details of the commitment as per:
     <ul>
      <li>
       <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000690" role="link" target="_blank">
        <em>
         Commitments
        </em>
       </a>
      </li>
      <li>
       <em>
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000710" role="link" target="_blank">
         Serviceability assessment
        </a>
       </em>
       &gt; Assessing commitments &gt; payment amount used for serviceability
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <strong>
      9
     </strong>
    </td>

     <strong>

     </strong>

     <strong>

    </td>
    <td>
     Verify the details of the commitment as per:
     <ul>

        </a>
       </em>
       &gt; Assessing commitments &gt; payment amount used for serviceability
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <strong>
      10
     </strong>
    </td>
    <td>
     <strong>
      Facility is unheard of – applicant denies any knowledge of facility
     </strong>
    </td>

     Application cannot proceed until issue is resolved
     <br/>
     <br/>
    </td>

       The applicant may choose to make direct contact with the credit provider
      </li>
     </ul>

      11

    </td>

     <ul>
      <li>
       <strong>
        The customer disputes the repayment history on the CCR or
       </strong>
      </li>

       <strong>
        The history on the CCR is inconsistent with repayment history on another supporting document
       </strong>

        and results in the facility not demonstrating satisfactory repayment history requirements
       </strong>
      </li>

    </td>

     Application cannot proceed until issue is resolved
    </td>

     To query the facility and have the bureau content amended:

 <strong>
  1.1 Why this policy
 </strong>
 <table>

        </b>
       </span>

     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Living expenses materially affect the ability of a residential mortgage borrower to meet repayments due on a loan and are a key component of a serviceability assessment.
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        The declared living expenses are used by the Bank as part of the unsuitability assessment as required under our Responsible Lending obligations.
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>

       </span>

     </span>

 <h2>
  <a name="R_Rules_you_must_apply">
  </a>
  <strong>
   2. Rules you must apply
  </strong>
 </h2>
 <h3>
 </h3>
 <h3>
  <a name="R_Capturing_cust_decl_living_expenses_ap">
  </a>
  <strong>
   2.1 Capturing customer declared living expenses
  </strong>
 </h3>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    It is critical that an appropriate level of enquiry is made, to ensure that an accurate view of the declared household living expenses are captured.
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    Refer to
    <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000723">
     Glossary
    </a>
    for definition of a ‘household’
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    Living expenses must be captured and entered according to the set expense category. It is not acceptable to 'bundle' across expense categories.
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    <b>
     Borrowers and income guarantors
    </b>
    are required to declare all ongoing household living expenses that:
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <ul>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      are in place as at time of the application, and
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      will be in place after settlement
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      of their loan
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
 </ul>
 <div>
  <div>
   <div id="_com_1" language="JavaScript" onmouseout="msoCommentHide('_com_1')" onmouseover="msoCommentShow('_anchor_1','_com_1')">
    Brokers
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       are to assist by providing a description of each expense category to ensure the declared responses clearly align to our requirements.
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
    Refer to Expense category tables
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       in
       <a data-tagid="R_Living_expenses_compared_to_HEM" href="#R_Living_expenses_compared_to_HEM">
        Living Expenses compared to HEM
       </a>
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       and
       <a data-tagid="R_Living_expenses_not_compared_to_HEM" href="#R_Living_expenses_not_compared_to_HEM">
        Living Expenses not compared to HEM
       </a>
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </div>
  </div>
 </div>
 <br/>
 Brokers cannot suggest a value on the applicant's behalf, except when rental income used in the serviceability assessment is rental income (in AUD) from a property rented on a short term basis.
 <ul>
  <li>
   Refer to:
   <ul>
    <li>
     <a data-tagid="2.16 Rental expenses from a property rented on a short term basis" href="#2.16 Rental expenses from a property rented on a short term basis">
      Rental expenses from a property rented on a short term basis
     </a>
     , and
    </li>
    <li>
     <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000721">
      Verifying Income
     </a>
     &gt; Supplementary income &gt; Rental income (in AUD) Rent received on a short term basis
    </li>
   </ul>
  </li>
 </ul>
 <h3>
  <br/>
  <a name="R_Reducing_living_expenses">
  </a>
  <strong>
   2.2 Reducing living expenses
  </strong>
 </h3>
 We acknowledge that a customer may change their spending behaviour when they have a new mortgage repayment obligation or following a change in circumstances (e.g. children moving out of parent's house).
 <br/>
 <br/>
 We accept that such a change often involves a reduction in discretionary (non-essential) expenses such as recreation, entertainment, clothing, personal care and groceries. It is less likely that a customer can easily reduce expenses that are more stable by nature such as insurances, property-related costs, utilities, education and telephone. Refer to Expense category tables
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    in
    <a data-tagid="R_Living_expenses_compared_to_HEM" href="#R_Living_expenses_compared_to_HEM">
     Living Expenses compared to HEM
    </a>
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    and
    <a data-tagid="R_Living_expenses_not_compared_to_HEM" href="#R_Living_expenses_not_compared_to_HEM">
     Living Expenses not compared to HEM
    </a>
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 to identify discretionary v’s non-discretionary expense types.
 <br/>
 <br/>
 Where the customer has told us that they are prepared to reasonably change their lifestyle to reduce living expenses, we may adjust customer declared expense amounts in the loan assessment system provided:
 <ul>
  <li>
   Broker has had a robust discussion with customer around their living expenses patterns;
   <strong>
    and
   </strong>
  </li>
  <li>
   The reduction appears reasonable;
   <strong>
    and
   </strong>
  </li>
  <li>
   Overall comments are recorded in ApplyOnline detailing:
   <ul>
    <li>
     the customer discussion
    </li>
    <li>
     what expenses have been adjusted and by how much
    </li>
    <li>
     the reasons why the reductions were deemed acceptable by the Broker.
    </li>
   </ul>
  </li>
 </ul>
 The customer declared amount cannot be accepted for any outgoing child support, alimony, rent / board (post settlement). The amount of the payment must be verified, for further information refer to
 <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000690">
  <em>
   Commitments
  </em>
 </a>
 <em>
  policy
 </em>
 <br/>
 <h3>
  <a name="R_Conflicting_information">
  </a>
  <strong>
   2.3 Conflicting information
  </strong>
 </h3>
 After the declared living expenses have been captured, we may need to make further enquiries if
 <ul>
  <li>
   during the assessment of the application we identify information which conflicts with the declared expenses
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      as per
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000698">
         Loan Application and Approval
        </a>
        &gt;
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      Validation of information provided by the customer policy
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      OBP referral rule '
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
   Customer Declared Expenses being &lt; 70% of HEM’ has been triggered.
  </li>
 </ul>
 <h3>
  <a name="R_Living_expenses_compared_to_HEM">
  </a>
  <strong>
   2.4 Living expenses compared to HEM
  </strong>
 </h3>
 These living living expense:
 <ul>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      categories will be compared to the HEM value;
      <b>
       and
      </b>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
   <ul>
    <li>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        the higher of the declared expenses or HEM will be used in the serviceability calculation
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </li>
   </ul>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      are used to calculate the expense to net [discounted] HEM ratio at application level. This is used to assist in:
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      understanding the  level of expenses;
      <b>
       and
      </b>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      identifying where they are materially different (higher or lower) to the Household Expenditure Measure . Refer
      <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000710">
       <em>
        <span>
         Serviceability assessment
        </span>
       </em>
      </a>
      for HEM values.
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
 </ul>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    Applications where the declared living expenses are assessed as materially low in relation to their income and insufficient to maintain a reasonable standard of living will require further detailed commentary and mitigation before approval can be considered.
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>

 <br/>

       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           is purchasing or obtaining ownership of an investment property as part of the application
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <b>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             Note:
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </b>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            Where the same property is an investment property for one borrower but an owner occupied property for another borrower, ensure that the expense is captured under the relevant category for each borrower and commentary entered.
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Yes
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           Investment Property Costs (Including Insurance) are offset against rental income
           <br/>
           <br/>
           Investment Property Costs (Including Insurance) must be captured as per each applicant's exact expenses across all investment properties in which they have an ownership must be captured.
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <strong>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            Note
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </strong>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           : When the applicant and non-applicant are spouse residing at the same address,
           <em>
            <span>
             Apportioned household expenses and shared commitments - Spousal same household
            </span>
           </em>
           <br/>
           option may apply
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
        <span lang="EN-GB">
         <span>
          <span>
           .
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           Refer to
           <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000710" target="_blank">
            <span>
             Serviceability Assessment
            </span>
           </a>
           policy
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
  </tbody>
 </table>
 <br/>
 <h3>
  <a name="R_Factors_affecting_HEM_living_expenses">
  </a>
  <strong>
   2.6 Factors affecting HEM / living expenses
  </strong>
 </h3>
 Other factors which may impact living expenses are:
 <ul>
  <li>
   post settlement postcode
   <ul>
    <li>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Where an In Principle Approval application is submitted, the post settlement postcode is to be captured as accurately as possible
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </li>
    <li>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        The application must reflect the actual post settlement postcode for formal approval.
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </li>
   </ul>
  </li>
  <li>
   number of dependants - refer to
   <em>
    <a href="#R_Definition_of_a_Dependant">
     Definition of a Dependant
    </a>
   </em>
  </li>
 </ul>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    It is a mandatory to capture these details within the loan assessment system.
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <h3>
  <a name="R_Apportioning_declared_living_expenses_">
  </a>

   2.7 Apportioning declared living expenses in loan application
  </strong>
 </h3>
 The table below details whether household living expenses can be apportioned, according to how the spouse is associated with the loan application
 <br/>
 <table>
  <tbody>
   <tr>

 <h4>
 </h4>
 <h3>
  <a name="R_Definition_of_a_Dependant">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     2.14 Definition of a Dependant
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h3>
 <span>
  <span>
   A dependant is defined as:
  </span>
 </span>
 <ul>
  <li>
   a child under the age of 18 years; or
  </li>
  <li>
   a child aged 18 years or older who lives with the applicant, receives no income from government benefits, employment or other income sources, and is totally financially reliant on the applicant (e.g. A full time unemployed student, or a child with a disability living at home permanently)
  </li>
 </ul>
 <span>
  <span>
   where the applicant has legal responsibility for the care and welfare of the child, on either a full or part time basis.
   <strong>
    Note:
   </strong>
   The child under the age of 18 years may or may not reside with the applicant.
   <br/>
   <br/>
   Unborn children are not considered dependants.
  </span>
 </span>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    Variance to this rule where
    <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000710">
     Serviceability Assessment
    </a>
    &gt; Parental leave – use of ‘return to work’ income’ policy is applied.
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   Any additional expenses for children over the age of 18 living at home need to be captured in the living expenses discussion with the customer.
   <br/>
   <br/>
   If applicants are expecting to add to their family, this should be identified during completion of Responsible Lending requirements by way of question: Do you expect any significant changes to your financial situation over the next 3 years that would adversely impact your ability to meet your repayments?  Refer to
   <em>
    <span>
     <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000710">
      Serviceability Assessment
     </a>
    </span>
   </em>
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   Where the child does not reside with the applicant it is acceptable to use an outgoing child support payment in place of including the child as a dependant for serviceability purposes. If no child support is paid or child support is paid and the child resides with the applicant the child must be included as a dependant for serviceability purposes. Any shared custody arrangements should be clearly explained in the application
   <br/>
   <br/>
   The amount of any outgoing child support payment must be verified for further information refer to
   <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000690">
    <em>
     <span>
      Commitments
     </span>
    </em>
   </a>
  </span>
 </span>
 <span>
  <span>
   policy
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <h3>
  <span>
   <span>
    <a id="2.16 Rental expenses from a property rented on a short term basis" name="2.16 Rental expenses from a property rented on a short term basis">
     <strong>
      2.15 Rental expenses from a property rented on a short term basis
     </strong>
    </a>
   </span>
  </span>
 </h3>
 <span>
  When rental income used in the serviceability assessment is rental income (in AUD) From a property rented on a short term basis and this property was rented for the full 52 weeks of the year. The expenses declared on the rental schedule other that interest, depreciation and once off capital expenses must be used.
  <span lang="EN">
   <span>
    <span>
     Refer to
     <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000721">
      Verifying Income
     </a>
     &gt; Supplementary income &gt; Rental income (in AUD) Rent received on a short term basis
    </span>
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <br/>
 <span>
  Where the short-term rental property has not been rented for the full 52 weeks of the year, expenses incurred when the property is not rented are to be entered into customer expenses either as an owner occupied primary or owner-occupied secondary expenses. The lender should discuss with the customer to determine whether the property is owner occupied primary or owner occupied secondary and document accordingly.
 </span>
 <br/>
 <br/>
 <span>
  If the property is owner-occupied and has a separate area of occupancy (granny flat) being used for short term rent, the owner-occupied portion of expenses is to be separated from the investment portion. Like above, the investment portion can be determined from the rental schedule in the tax return and the owner-occupied portion can be determined through a customer conversation.
 </span>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
  </span>
 </span>
</div>
