 <h2>
  <a name="A_About_this_policy">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      1. About this policy
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h2>
 <h3>
  <a name="A_Why_this_policy">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      1.1 Why this policy
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h3>
 This policy will help you identify an applicant’s residency status and determine if the application for consumer mortgage lending can proceed.
 <span>
  <span>
   <br/>
  </span>
 </span>
 <h2>
  <a name="R_Rules_you_must_apply">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      2. Rules you must apply
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h2>
 <h3>
  <br/>
  <a id="2.1 Establishing citizenship and residency status" name="2.1 Establishing citizenship and residency status">
   <strong>
    2.1 Establishing citizenship and residency status
   </strong>
  </a>
 </h3>
 <div>
  A customer’s citizenship, residency or non-residency status must be established at initial application stage for all consumer mortgage loans.
  <br/>
  For applicants who are:
 </div>
 <ul>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     Australian citizens who reside in Australia, or out of Australia on either a temporary or permanent basis (i.e. Australian expat), refer to
     <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000694">
      Eligibility
     </a>
     policy &gt; Australian Citizen residency status
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        New Zealand citizens, or they hold a permanent or temporary residency visa issued by the Australian government, refer to
        <a data-tagid="R_Migrant_lending" href="#R_Migrant_lending">
         Migrant Lending
        </a>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
 </ul>
 Where the above scenarios do not apply to the applicant, refer
 <a data-tagid="2.12 Non-Resident Lending" href="#2.12 Non-Resident Lending">
  Non-Resident lending
 </a>
 , this will include applicants who:
 <ul>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     are not an Australian or New Zealand citizen, or
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        do not hold either a permanent or temporary residency visa issued by the Australian government, or
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        hold a temporary visa issued b the Australian government, but reside out of Australia
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
 </ul>
 <h3>
  <br/>
  <br/>
  <a name="R_Migrant_lending">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      2.2 Migrant lending
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h3>
 A migrant is defined as an individual that has been granted an Australian government residence visa (temporary or permanent) for entry into Australia, i.e.:
 <ul>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     A permanent residence visa allows a person unrestricted working rights in Australia and they can remain in Australia indefinitely.
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        A temporary residence visa allows a person to live in Australia for a limited time only and they may have restricted working rights.
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
 </ul>
 <span>
  Eligible migrant applicants may be able to access consumer mortgage loan lending for owner occupied or investment purpose, refer to :
 </span>
 <ul>
  <li>
   <a data-tagid="R_Eligibility_criteria" href="#R_Eligibility_criteria">
    <span>
     <span>
      Eligibility criteria
     </span>
    </span>
   </a>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000684">
         Loan to Value Ratio (LVR)
        </a>
        <em>
         <span>
          <span>
           &gt; LVR by borrower type and income source
          </span>
         </span>
        </em>
        for maximum allowable LVR
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <em>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <a data-tagid="R_Applicant_via_Resident_Type_Matrix" href="#R_Applicant_via_Resident_Type_Matrix">
             Applicant via Resident Type matrix
            </a>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </em>
        for any additional conditions.
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
 </ul>
 <span>
  Normal credit underwriting standards including serviceability and verification rules apply.
 </span>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    If the loan application requires and is acceptable for mortgage insurance, refer to
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000725">
     <i>
      Lenders Mortgage Insurance
     </i>
    </a>
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    where required.
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <h3>
  <a name="R_Eligibility_criteria">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      2.3 Eligibility criteria
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h3>
 Migrant lending policy is available to applicants that meet the following criteria :
 <ul>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       The applicant’s permanent or temporary visa must be listed as an acceptable migrant visa type and number within the
       <a data-tagid="2.9.1 Acceptable Visas" href="#2.9.1 Acceptable Visas">
        <em>
         <span>
          <span>
           Acceptable
          </span>
         </span>
        </em>
       </a>
       <a data-tagid="2.9.1 Acceptable Visas" href="#2.9.1 Acceptable Visas">
        <em>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            Visa matrix
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </em>
       </a>
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         Applicant’s employment status and income are compliant with the
         <a data-tagid="2.9.1 Acceptable Visas" href="#2.9.1 Acceptable Visas">
          <em>
           <span>
            Acceptable Visa matrix
           </span>
          </em>
         </a>
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          A copy of the migrant’s passport and evidence of Australian visa details (excluding the Australian visa number) must be obtained and held on file. Where the applicant:
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
   <ul>
    <li>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            Does not hold a passport( e.g. a refugee may only hold a Protection visa subclass 866), the application may be referred to Credit for further consideration.
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </li>
    <li>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            Has an expired passport
            <strong>
             <span>
              but
             </span>
            </strong>
            holds a permanent residence visa
            <strong>
             <span>
              and
             </span>
            </strong>
            resides in Australia, a copy of the expired passport, supported by a copy of the current visa is acceptable.
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </li>
   </ul>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          Certain migrant visa holders may not have access to all products and reference must be made to the
          <a data-tagid="R_Applicant_via_Resident_Type_Matrix" href="#R_Applicant_via_Resident_Type_Matrix">
           <i>
            Applicant via Resident Type matrix
           </i>
          </a>
          <em>
          </em>
          prior to providing a product.
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          Applicants who hold a:
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
   <ul>
    <li>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            Permanent visa but reside overseas and are purchasing an investment property must have a minimum of 12 months remaining on their Australian Visa (unless the visa does not have an expiry date).
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </li>
    <li>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            Temporary visa must have a minimum of 12 months remaining on their Australian Visa, for a:
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             <span>
              Non-mortgage insured loan, a visa with no expiry date is considered to have met the minimum 12 month rule.
             </span>
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             <span>
              Mortgage insured loan, the Mortgage Insurer may consider any referral on a case-by-case basis, outside of the above, with supporting commentary (i.e. visa does not have an expiry date for visa 309 and 820 with confirmation of current status)
             </span>
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
       <br/>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             <b>
              Note:
             </b>
             Where the application is mortgage insured, the Visa must be acceptable to the Mortgage Insurer, refer
             <a data-tagid="R_Applicant_via_Resident_Type_Matrix" href="#R_Applicant_via_Resident_Type_Matrix">
              <i>
               <u>
                Applicant via Resident Type Matrix
               </u>
              </i>
             </a>
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </li>
   </ul>
  </li>
 </ul>
 <div>
  <div>
   <div id="_com_1" language="JavaScript">
   </div>
  </div>
 </div>
 <h3>
  <a name="R_Income_and_employment_verification">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      2.4 Income and employment verification
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h3>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    <span>
     Where the application includes foreign income, or Australian Dollar (AUD) income from foreign PAYG employment, refer to and follow the requirements in:
    </span>
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <ul>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000721">
      Verifying Income
     </a>
     <span>
      <span>
      </span>
     </span>
     &gt; Foreign income and / or employment
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000684">
         Loan to Value Ratio (LVR)
        </a>
        policy &gt; LVR by borrower type and income source and
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <a data-tagid="R_Applicant_via_Resident_Type_Matrix" href="#R_Applicant_via_Resident_Type_Matrix">
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       Applicant via Resident Type matrix
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </a>
  </li>
 </ul>
 <h3>
  <a name="R_Own_contribution_validation">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      2.5 Own contribution validation
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h3>
 <span>
  <span>
   Funds to complete or own contribution is generally considered to be the shortfall between the purchase price (inclusive of legal and stamp duty) and the loan being provided by the Bank.
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    Some migrant visa holders must provide evidence of their funds to complete / own contribution via account statements, to confirm that the source of funds is from a genuine financial institution (e.g. bank), refer
    <a data-tagid="R_Applicant_via_Resident_Type_Matrix" href="#R_Applicant_via_Resident_Type_Matrix">
     <em>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          Applicant via Resident Type matrix
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </em>
    </a>
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    <strong>
     Note:
    </strong>
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    Where the account statement(s) does not evidence the full funds to complete / own contribution, it is acceptable to proceed, where a satisfactory explanation is entered in application supporting notes, e.g. the applicant has paid a deposit on the property being purchased and where combined with funds evidenced via account statements, confirms funds to complete / own contribution.
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <h3>
  <a name="R_Document_translation">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      2.6 Document translation
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h3>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    In the event foreign income and other supporting documents (e.g. account statements used to verify own contribution) are not in English or
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    display a currency other than AUD, refer to
    <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000692">
     Document Standards
    </a>
    policy &gt; When supporting documents are not in English or display a currency other than AUD.
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    The  original documents, translated documents and
    <em>
     <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/ci/okcsFattach/getFile/1000702/03.13%20Translation%20Checklist%20CSH.xlsm">
      Foreign currency translation checklist
     </a>
    </em>
    are to be retained in the loan file
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    .
    <br/>
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <h3>
  <a name="R_Applications_with_multiple_applicants_">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      2.7 Applications with multiple applicants and varying visa types, citizenship or residency status
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h3>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    Where there are joint / multiple applicants, all applicants must be eligible as per policy requirements, regardless of their contribution to the loan, i.e. if the applicant type or visa held is not acceptable to the bank then the individual cannot to be a borrower, guarantor or owner of the security property. The following additional conditions apply:
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <ul>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      The LVR may be restricted based on the visa type of the co-applicant.
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   Loan applications with multiple borrowers on the loan but only a single title holder are not permitted where one or more of the applicants is currently, or will continue to reside overseas post settlement. No financial benefit can be demonstrated for an applicant(s) that will continue to reside overseas post settlement, where they have no ownership in the security collateral.
  </li>
  <li>
   Refer to
   <a href="#RT_Visa_matrix_and_Applicant_via_Residen">
    <em>
     <span>
      Visa matrix
     </span>
    </em>
   </a>
   and
   <a href="#R_Applicant_via_Resident_Type_Matrix">
    <em>
     Applicant via Resident Type matrix
    </em>
   </a>
   for restrictions affecting each applicant type and to identify if mortgage insurance is available.
  </li>
 </ul>
 <h3>
  <a name="R__Approval_from_foreign_investment_revi">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      2.8 Approval from foreign investment review board (FIRB)
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h3>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    Holders of Australian temporary residency visas require approval from the Federal Government Treasury – Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB). It is the responsibility of the purchaser to ensure approval is held.
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <br/>
 <span>
  Where the borrower is, or will be on the title, a copy of the FIRB approval must be held prior to issuing a formal approval.
 </span>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    The loan application must be validated against the FIRB approval to ensure the application complies with the conditions under which the FIRB approval was issued.
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <span>
  <br/>
  <br/>
  <u>
   <strong>
    FIRB exception:
   </strong>
  </u>
  The
  <b>
   only
  </b>
  allowable exception to the FIRB requirement is where the applicant is purchasing or owns a property as Joint Tenants* (50/50), with an Australian or New Zealand citizen, or a Permanent Resident, who is their spouse.
 </span>
 <br/>
 <span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <b>
   *
  </b>
  The exception does not apply where the property ownership is Tenants in Common (e.g. 80/20).
 </span>
 <br/>
 <br/>
 <span>
  Where the applicant lives and works overseas and FIRB indicates approval is for their principal place of residence
  <sup>
   #
  </sup>
  , then the property:
 </span>
 <ol>
  <li>
   <span>
    Must be their principal place of residence while in Australia.
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    Cannot be used for investment (rental) or holiday purposes and
   </span>
   <span>
    rental income against this property is not acceptable.
   </span>
  </li>
 </ol>
 <span>
  <span>
   <strong>
    <span>
     Notes:
    </span>
   </strong>
  </span>
 </span>
 <ul>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     In some cases FIRB approval is granted to a specific development. The developer may receive a certificate identifying that further foreign investment approval is not required when sales are made to foreign persons.
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     A copy of the FIRB approval issued to the developer is to be retained on file. The offered security property (for purchase or refinance) should match the property identified in the FIRB approval.
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
 </ul>
 <span>
  <span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <h3>
  <a name="RT_Visa_matrix_and_Applicant_via_Residen">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      2.9 Visa matrix and Applicant via Resident Type Matrix Overview
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h3>
 Applications may be accepted for consumer mortgage lending where the visa number is acceptable and any other conditions as detailed in the Acceptable
 <a data-tagid="2.9.1 Visa Matrix" href="#2.9.1 Visa Matrix">
  <em>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      Visa matrix
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </em>
 </a>
 and
 <a data-tagid="R_Applicant_via_Resident_Type_Matrix" href="#R_Applicant_via_Resident_Type_Matrix">
  <i>
   Applicant via Resident Type matrix
  </i>
 </a>
 are met.
 <br/>
 <br/>
 The
 <a data-tagid="2.9.1 Acceptable Visas" href="#2.9.1 Acceptable Visas">
  Acceptable Visa matrix
 </a>
 details the:
 <ul>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       Visa subclass number
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          Category of the visa type e.g. permanent or temporary
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          If the visa type is acceptable to Westpac Group
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          If the visa type is acceptable to the mortgage insurer
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          Acceptable employment status
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          Acceptable income type
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
 </ul>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       The
       <a data-tagid="R_Applicant_via_Resident_Type_Matrix" href="#R_Applicant_via_Resident_Type_Matrix">
        Applicant via resident type matrix
       </a>
       details additional policy rules and conditions.
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      Also refer to
      <a data-tagid="2.9.2 Unacceptable Visas" href="#2.9.2 Unacceptable Visas">
       Unacceptable Visas
      </a>
      .
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <b>
       Notes:
      </b>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <ul>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      Where an applicant holds a temporary or permanent visa that is:
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
   <ul>
    <li>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         Not currently on the
         <a data-tagid="2.9.1 Acceptable Visas" href="#2.9.1 Acceptable Visas">
          acceptable visa list
         </a>
         , or the visa is no longer available, or you have been made aware of a new visa number (or subclass), then these can be referred to Credit for consideration and must be supported with detailed comments / notes and justification for acceptance.
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </li>
    <li>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         Listed on the
         <a data-tagid="2.9.2 Unacceptable Visas" href="#2.9.2 Unacceptable Visas">
          Unacceptable visa list
         </a>
         , then no lending is permitted either as a borrower or guarantor, no exceptions permitted even by Credit, refer
         <a data-tagid="2.9.2 Unacceptable Visas" href="#2.9.2 Unacceptable Visas">
          Unacceptable Visas
         </a>
         .
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </li>
   </ul>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      Migrant lending customers will only be acceptable if all conditions set out in the
      <a data-tagid="2.9.1 Acceptable Visas" href="#2.9.1 Acceptable Visas">
       Acceptable Visa matrix
      </a>
      <span>
       <span>
       </span>
      </span>
      <strong>
       <span>
        and
       </span>
      </strong>
      the
      <a data-tagid="R_Applicant_via_Resident_Type_Matrix" href="#R_Applicant_via_Resident_Type_Matrix">
       Applicant via resident type matrix
      </a>
      ,
      <span>
       <span>
       </span>
      </span>
      and any additional policy requirements and visa conditions are met, e.g.:
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
   <ul>
    <li>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         Business visa types should reflect income status and documentation from within Australia.
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </li>
    <li>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         Sponsored visa types should reflect income from that region, i.e. state or territory sponsored visa's should reflect income earned within Australia.
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </li>
   </ul>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      Applications that meet
      <a data-tagid="R_Migrant_lending" href="#R_Migrant_lending">
       Migrant Lending
      </a>
      policy requirements and require Mortgage Insurance, the Mortgage Insurer may consider any referral on a case-by-case basis with supporting commentary.
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
 </ul>
 <span>
  <span>
  </span>
 </span>

        <span>
         <span>
          Applicants using Visa 111 must be referred to Credit for acceptance. Authorities to Return (ATR) and Return Endorsements (RE) are old style return visas issued to permanent residents between 1 March 1976 and 31 December 1986. Evidence was issued in the form of a stamp or label in the holder’s passport and contain the words ‘Authority to Return’ or ‘Return Endorsement’. Authorities to Return and Return Endorsements can no longer be granted but may still be valid. The issue with the ATR/RE is they may only be evidenced in the passport and the Department of Home Affairs will not know from their own systems whether or not the visa was ever granted.

    </td>
    <td>
     <span>

       <span>
        Evidence of Approved Permanent visa is to be held on file and verified by Mortgage Services. Acceptable document may be any one of:
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       A copy of an Approved Permanent visa (refer Approved Migrant Visas: Migrant lending package)
      </li>
      <li>
       A copy of a current foreign passport with proof of permanent residence status
      </li>
      <li>
       A copy of a certificate of residence
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          or the original Visa grant approval letter
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
       issued by the Department of Home Affairs
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>

          <a href="https://online.immi.gov.au/evo/firstParty?actionType=query%20">
           https://online .immi.gov.au/evo/firstParty?actionType=query%20

        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>

    </td>

         <span>

 <h3>
  <a id="2.12 Non-Resident Lending" name="2.12 Non-Resident Lending">
   <strong>
    <span>
     <span>
      2.12 Non-Resident Lending
     </span>
    </span>
   </strong>
  </a>
 </h3>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    A non-resident is defined as an individual who:
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <ul>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       Does not hold Australian Citizenship or an approved Australian Permanent residency visa, or
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          Holds an approved Australian Temporary residency visa, however, does not ordinarily reside in Australia
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
 </ul>
 <strong>
  <span>
   <span>
    <span>
     Note:
    </span>
   </span>
  </span>
 </strong>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    New Zealand citizens living in Australia are not considered non-residents for the purpose of this policy.
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <span>
  Lending to a non-resident applicant(s) is
  <b>
   not permitted
  </b>
  either as a borrower or guarantor, even where the non-resident income is not relied on to meet serviceability, for:
 </span>
 <ul>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       A new consumer mortgage, or
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          An increase to an existing consumer mortgage, or
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          A variation activity which requires a serviceability assessment
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
 </ul>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    <b>
     No exceptions to the above are permitted (including Credit).
    </b>
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>

 <h2>
  <a name="P_Process_to_follow">
  </a>

   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      3. Process to follow
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h2>
 <h3>
  <a name="P_Migrant_lending_package_application_pr">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      3.1 Migrant lending package application process
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h3>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    Process application as per normal and upload a copy of customer's visa type within ApplyOnline in accordance with section 3.2 below. In loan application notes, add any supporting information (excluding applicant’s Australian visa number).
    <br/>
    <br/>
    <strong>
     <span>
      Note:
     </span>
    </strong>
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    All other lending criteria and process remain unchanged, such as the customer
    <strong>
     <span>
      must
     </span>
    </strong>
   </span>
   hold a valid IDV and income documents.
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    All migrant temporary visa borrowers must provide a copy of their Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB) approval (where applicable), refer
    <a href="#R__Approval_from_foreign_investment_revi">
     Approval from FIRB
    </a>
    , which must be complied with and uploaded into ApplyOnline.
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <h3>
  <a name="P_Evidencing_migrant_visa">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      3.2 Evidencing migrant visa
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h3>
 <ul>
  <li>
   Migrant status must be evidenced via provision of a:
   <ul>
    <li>
     copy of a work visa approval issued by Department of Home Affairs – Immigration and citizenship; or
    </li>
    <li>
     printout supplied by the customer from the VEVO website
     <a href="https://online.immi.gov.au/evo/firstParty?actionType=query">
      <em>
       https://online.immi.gov.au/evo/firstParty?actionType=query
      </em>
     </a>
    </li>
   </ul>
  </li>
  <li>
   Where an applicant’s migrant category is Investor Visa type, evidence is to be provided of approved deposit funds held with State Treasury
  </li>
 </ul>

 <h2>
  <a name="A_About_this_policy">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     1. About this policy
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h2>
 <h3>
  <a name="A_Why_this_policy">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     1.1 Why this policy
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h3>
 <span>
  <span>
   This policy outlines the parameters for assessing loan applications that involves non-resident borrower(s) in a consumer mortgage application.
  </span>
 </span>
 <h3>
 </h3>
 <h2>
  <a name="R_Rules_you_must_apply">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     2. Rules you must apply
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h2>
 <h3>
  <a name="R_Definitions_of_non-residents_lending">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     2.1 Definitions of non-residents lending
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h3>
 <span>
  <span>
   For residential lending purposes a non-resident individual is defined as:
  </span>
 </span>
 <ul>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     A person who does not hold Australian Citizenship or approved Australian Permanent residency visa, or
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     A person who does hold an approved Australian Temporary residency visa however does not ordinarily reside in Australia
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
 </ul>
 <strong>
  <span>
   <span>
    Note:
   </span>
  </span>
 </strong>
 <ul>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     New Zealand citizens living in Australia are not considered non-residents for the purposes of this policy
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     This policy does not apply to migrant applicants. Refer to
     <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000702">
      <em>
       <span>
        Migrant Lending
       </span>
      </em>
     </a>
    </span>
    policy for further information
   </span>
  </li>
 </ul>
 <span>
  <span>
   <br/>
   Where
   <strong>
    <span>
     any one or more
    </span>
   </strong>
  </span>
  <strong>
   <span>
    borrower or guarantor
   </span>
  </strong>
 </span>
 meets the definition of ‘non-resident’, none of the below lending activities are permitted, even if the ’non-resident’s’ income is not relied on to meet serviceability:
 <ul>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     New loan
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     For existing loans involving a non-resident borrower or guarantor:
    </span>
   </span>
   <ul>
    <li>
     <span>
      <span>
       Loan Increase/Top Up
      </span>
     </span>
    </li>
    <li>
     <span>
      <span>
       Refinance
      </span>
     </span>
    </li>
    <li>
     <span>
      <span>
       Cash out
      </span>
     </span>
    </li>
    <li>
     <span>
      <span>
       Servicing (Variation) activity that requires a loan origination (as refinance is not permitted)
      </span>
     </span>
    </li>
   </ul>
  </li>
 </ul>
 <span>
  <span>
   No exceptions to the above are permitted by any credit risk authority holder (including Credit).
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <h3>
  <a name="R_Establishing_citizenship/residency_sta">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     2.2 Establishing citizenship / residency status
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h3>
 <span>
  <span>
   Non-resident status may be identified where a foreign passport is presented for identification purposes or the applicant(s) is identified as residing overseas.
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   A customer’s citizenship, visa type or non-residency status must be established at initial application stage.
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <br/>
 <br/>
</div>

 <h2>
  <a name="A_About_this_policy">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     1. About this policy
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h2>
 <h3>
  <a name="A_Why_this_policy?">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     1.1 Why this policy?
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h3>
 <span>
  <span>
   The Bank requires acceptable building insurance cover on a replacement and reinstatement basis over the real estate property used as security collateral for the loan.
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   Insurance cover will protect the value of the secured asset in the event the owner and Bank is required to rely upon it.
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   Adequate insurance cover is to be maintained for the duration of the loan.
   <br/>
  </span>
 </span>
 <h2>
  <a name="R_Rules_you_must_apply">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     2. Rules you must apply
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h2>
 <h3>
  <br/>
  <a name="R_Responsibilities">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     2.1 Responsibilities
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h3>
 <span>
  <span>
   It is the responsibility of the borrower to:
  </span>
 </span>
 <ul>
  <li>
   Take up the building insurance cover prior to loan settlement with an Australian insurer
  </li>
  <li>
   Take out any other insurances required by policy, such as builder’s risk insurance
  </li>
  <li>
   Negotiate with the insurer on the minimum cover amount with a recommendation of full replacement cost
  </li>
  <li>
   Have a current or renew building insurance policy during the loan contract term. Failure to do so is a breach under the terms of the contract and mortgage by borrower/ mortgagor.
  </li>
 </ul>
 <span>
  <span>
   The Bank cannot suggest a minimum amount the property must be insured for.
   <br/>
  </span>
 </span>

  </span>

 <ul>

  </li>
  <li>

  </li>
  <li>

  </li>
  <li>
   Adequate description of the location of the security collateral, e.g. address, title details
  </li>
  <li>
   Amount of cover on a replacement and reinstatement basis for an amount at least equal to the full replacement cost
  </li>
 </ul>

 <h2>
  <a name="A_About_this_policy">
   <strong>
    <span>
     <span>
      1. About this policy
     </span>
    </span>
   </strong>
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>

    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h2>
 <h3>
  <a name="A_Why_this_policy">
   <strong>
    <span>
     <span>
      1.1 Why this policy
     </span>
    </span>
   </strong>
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     .
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h3>
 <span>
  <span>
   This section outlines the policies for assessing self-employed applicants within a consumer mortgage application.
   <br/>
   <br/>
   Throughout this policy when the term 'business' is used it may include income generated by a sole trader, personal services, partnership, company, or trust.
   <br/>
   <br/>
   You may also need to refer to other lending policy rules, including but not limited to:
  </span>
 </span>
 <ul>
  <li>
   <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000721">
    <em>
     <u>
      <span>
       Verifying Income
      </span>
     </u>
    </em>
   </a>
  </li>
  <li>
   <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000694">
    <em>
     <u>
      <span>
       Eligibility
      </span>
     </u>
    </em>
   </a>
  </li>
  <li>
   <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000714">
    <em>
     <u>
      <span>
       Medico Sector
      </span>
     </u>
    </em>
   </a>
  </li>
 </ul>
 <span>
  <span>
   If the loan application requires mortgage insurance, refer to
   <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000725">
    <em>
     Lenders Mortgage Insurance
    </em>
   </a>
   where required.
   <br/>
   <br/>
  </span>
 </span>
 <h2>
  <a name="R_Rules_you_must_apply">
   <strong>
    <span>
     <span>
      2. Rules you must apply
     </span>
    </span>
   </strong>
  </a>
 </h2>
 <h3>
  <a name="R_Assessing_Self-employed_applications">
   <strong>
    <span>
     <span>
      2.1 Identifying and Assessing self-employed applications
     </span>
    </span>
   </strong>
  </a>
 </h3>
 Where the applicant earns PAYG income (or other supplementary income) but also has a
 <span>
  <span>
   directorship
  </span>
 </span>
 <sup>
  <span>
   <span>
    1
   </span>
  </span>
 </sup>
 or ABN for a business, and the applicant is not being assessed under Fast Track, Lenders / Assessors are required to identify how the applicant is related to the business and if the applicant is a director and / or shareholder.  Where the applicant is a director and / or shareholder, further investigation of the business is to be completed (even where income from the business is not being used for serviceability assessment) to establish the below:
 <ul>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     When the applicant became a director;
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        The percentage of shareholding;
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        If the business is trading / non-trading; and
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        If the business is profitable or able to able to service it's own commitments
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
 </ul>
 <sup>
  1
 </sup>
 Where the applicant is either an Independent director or an Executive director they are not considered to be the business owner and do not need to be assessed as a self-employed applicant.
 <ul>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <b>
      Independent director
     </b>
     : A director that does not have a vested interest i.e. they are not a shareholder and the directorship is not held in a business that is owned (shareholding &gt; 0%) or controlled (directorship) by a spouse or family member (e.g. child or parent) or a subsidiary entity of the director or director's spouse / family member.
    </span>
   </span>
   <br/>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <b>
         Executive director
        </b>
        : A director that does have a vested interest (a minor % shareholding of &lt;=5%) however limited to also being an independent PAYG employee.  E.g. the CEO of Westpac is a director but also an independent PAYG employee (PAYG employee of a business that is not their own business).
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
 </ul>
 For further information about how to investigate directorships refer to
 <a data-tagid="R_completing_ABN_business_name_or_compan" href="#R_completing_ABN_business_name_or_compan">
  Completing ABN, business name or company searches
 </a>
 .
 <br/>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   Assessing self-employed applicants is different from assessing PAYG applicants for a number of key reasons as follows:
  </span>
 </span>
 <ul>
  <li>
   Salary or drawings taken from a business by a self-employed applicant may not reflect the underlying sustainable earnings capability of the business. The owner may be draining the business of its reserves by paying him/herself an inflated salary, over and above what the business can afford.
  </li>
  <li>
   The earnings of a self-employed applicant may vary significantly from year to year depending on business cycles and how well the business is performing. Significant variations may affect the applicant's ability to repay the loan and therefore the variability of income is to be included as part of the assessment process.
  </li>
  <li>
   Private and business expenses can become intermingled.
  </li>
  <li>
   Self-employed people have a greater opportunity to adjust their income to indicate servicing capacity that may not exist.
  </li>
  <li>
   Self-employed people may have a number of sources of income that have to be taken into account when assessing their capacity to service.
  </li>
 </ul>
 <span>
  <span>
   A separate process is necessary for self-employed applications to:
  </span>
 </span>
 <ul>
  <li>
   Determine real income available for loan servicing.
  </li>
  <li>
   Ensure an appropriate legal structure for the loan.
  </li>
  <li>
   Ensure appropriate security arrangements for the loan.
  </li>
 </ul>
 <span>
  <span>
   Any non self-employed income is to be verified as per policy contained in
   <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000721">
    <em>
     <u>
      <span>
       Verifying Income
      </span>
     </u>
    </em>
   </a>
  </span>
 </span>
 <span>
  <span>
   .
   <br/>
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <strong>
  <span>
   <span>
    Supporting Documents
   </span>
  </span>
 </strong>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   All supporting documents are to be uploaded to ApplyOnline and Tax file numbers must be redacted from any document provided to the bank.
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>

   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Use of undistributed company profits towards individual serviceability calculations
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Where the borrower(s) is both a current company director
       <strong>
        <span>
         and
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
      a shareholder,
      <strong>
       <span>
        and
       </span>
      </strong>
     </span>
     owns a controlling interest in a company* (i.e. ≥ 50% shareholding) currently and for the two financial years being assessed (or one year where acceptable to use one year’s financials, e.g. Medico)
     <strong>
      <span>
       and
      </span>
     </strong>
     there is a shortfall in serviceability from the borrowers individual incomes, undistributed company earnings may be added to the borrowers' incomes,
     <strong>
      <span>
       only proportionate to the level of ownership / shareholding held
      </span>
     </strong>
     <span>
      <span>
       .
       <br/>
       <br/>
       To establish that the borrower(s) has met the eligibility criteria for use of undistributed company profits, the Broker / Assessor must complete a company search and review the search to confirm the borrower(s):
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Is a current director
       <strong>
        <span>
         and
        </span>
       </strong>
      </li>
      <li>
       Currently holds &gt;=50% shareholding in the company
       <strong>
        <span>
         and
        </span>
       </strong>
      </li>
      <li>
       Was a director and &gt;=50% shareholder in the company for the two financial years being assessed (including where backdated), or one year where acceptable to use one year’s financials (e.g. Medico)
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <span>
       Refer to
       <em>
        <a href="#R_completing_ABN_business_name_or_compan">
         completing ABN, business name or company searches
        </a>
        .
       </em>
       <br/>
       <br/>
       The Broker is required to record comments in the assessment system confirming the above and upload to ApplyOnline the company search and any relevant document search relating to a change(s) to directorship and / or shareholding.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       The borrower(s) will be ineligible to use undistributed company profit where they are not currently a director and &gt;=50% shareholder, have been added as a director and /or shareholder
       <sup>
        <span>
         #
        </span>
       </sup>
       or their shareholding has increased to ≥50% (including where backdated), during the two financial years used in the serviceability assessment (or one year where acceptable to use one year’s financials, e.g. Medico).
       <br/>
       <br/>
       Where it is evident over the two financial years (or one year where acceptable to use one year’s financials, e.g. Medico) used in the serviceability assessment or in the period preceding the loan application submission, that a borrower’s shareholding in a company:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Meets the minimum 50% ownership requirement, but has increased (e.g. FY19 50% shareholding and FY20 70% shareholding), then the lower historical shareholding ownership percentage (e.g. 50%) of the banks calculated adjusted net profit after tax and repayments may be used in serviceability assessment
      </li>

    <td>
     <span>
      <span>

        <span>

        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
     </span>
     <span>
      <span>
       where the individual receiving the distribution from the trust, is contributing to the serviceability assessment, i.e. are joint applicants or assessed under Apportioned shared commitments. Refer to
       <em>
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000710">
         Serviceability
        </a>
        &gt; Apportioned shared commitments.
       </em>
       <br/>
       <br/>
       Where the recipient of the distribution is not the trustee of the trust:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Refer to
       <a href="#R_Unacceptable_self-employed_income">
        <em>
         <u>
          <span>
           Unacceptable self-employed  income
          </span>
         </u>
        </em>
       </a>
       <u>
        .
       </u>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <span>
       <br/>
       Where the borrower or borrower's entity, have not previously received a distribution from the trust in prior years, only Credit may consider the use of this income towards serviceability calculations. Redirection of trust distributions from other beneficiaries may have adverse financial impacts.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       Trust distributions must be traced back to the original earning entity to ensure the distribution does not exceed the adjusted net profit after tax and repayments and beneficiary’s income for Serviceability.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       The adjusted net profit and or beneficiary’s income for Serviceability value’s may be less than the actual distribution reflected in the personal return because the trust expenses may only include items that are claimable for taxation purpose.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       Expenses such as principal loan repayment obligations may not be included with the expenses. As a result, the actual trust disbursement received by an individual may be inflated.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       Trust distributions used in the serviceability assessment must also not exceed the beneficiary’s historical distribution percentage.
      </span>

      <li>

       <br/>

       <br/>

       <br/>

 <span>

   Applicants that have been self-employed for more than 12 months but less than two full financial years are considered an exception to policy and will require referral to Credit for consideration.
   <br/>

 <h4>
  <a name="R__SE_activity_has_made_a_loss_or_cannot">
   <strong>
    <span>
     <span>
      2.1.2 Self-employed activity has made a loss or if it has been identified it cannot service its commitments on its own
     </span>
    </span>
   </strong>
  </a>
 </h4>
 <ul>
  <li>
   The loss must be reflected in the serviceability assessment.  Applicants will need to explain how any ongoing business commitments will be met.  It is vital to understand if the individuals are going to be negatively impacted by the business's financial position.  Loan application notes must capture outcomes of the Broker’s discussion with the applicant.
  </li>
  <li>
   If the business is trading at a loss
   <strong>
    <u>
     <span>
      or
     </span>
    </u>
   </strong>
   if it has been identified it cannot service its commitments on its own, you are unable to rely on ‘latest year’ financial information or 'Accountants letter/email advice’.
  </li>
  <li>
   Where a borrower’s shareholding in a company has reduced (e.g. 80% to 20%) across the two financial years used in the serviceability assessment or in the period preceding loan application submission and the company is trading at a loss, then the loss must be apportioned to the borrower based on the borrower’s highest percentage ownership (e.g. 80%), over the period being assessed.
  </li>
 </ul>
 <span>
  <span>
   Refer to
   <a href="#R_completing_ABN_business_name_or_compan">
    <em>
     completing ABN, business name or company searches
    </em>
   </a>
   <em>
    <span>
     <span>
      .
     </span>
    </span>
   </em>
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   <br/>
   Complete requirements as per:
  </span>
 </span>
 <ul>
  <li>
   <a href="#R_Applications_by_income_source">
    <em>
     <u>
      <span>
       Applications by income source
      </span>
     </u>
    </em>
   </a>
  </li>
 </ul>

 <h4>
  <a name="R_Unacceptable_self-employed_income">
   <strong>
    <span>
     <span>
      2.1.4 Unacceptable self-employed income
     </span>
    </span>
   </strong>
  </a>
 </h4>
 <ul>
  <li>
   Company / business income that is not sustainable (derived from a once off event, including but not limited to: sale of an asset, capital gains, drawing from prior years retained profits). Also see
   <em>
    Non-Recurring items.
   </em>
  </li>
  <li>
   Income from an entity that may have strike off action recorded or is under external administration.
  </li>
  <li>
   Company or trust distribution from an unrelated entity (the borrower is not a trustee of the trust nor a director / shareholder of the company). For acceptability of income from these sources refer to
   <em>
    <u>
     <span>
      Verifying Income
     </span>
    </u>
   </em>
   policy.
  </li>
  <li>
   In all instances, foreign self-employed income is not acceptable. Applications may only proceed where Credit approve an exception. It is recommended that you discuss your scenario with your dedicated Credit contact prior to accepting the application from the customer.
  </li>
 </ul>

          Loan Application and Approval
         </a>
         policy
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <strong>
       <span>
       </span>
      </strong>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      Same as Fully verified– 2 year average &gt; Non-mortgage insured
      <b>
       plus
      </b>
      :
     </span>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       Latest year income may be considered for serviceability assessment where:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           The latest years income
           <sup>
            1
           </sup>
           is lower than the prior year income
           <sup>
            1
           </sup>
           <b>
            or
           </b>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           The latest years income
           <sup>
            1
           </sup>
           is higher than the prior year income
           <sup>
            1
           </sup>
           <strong>
            <span>
             and
            </span>
           </strong>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           The increase to income can be confirmed as sustainable
           <strong>
            <span>
             . Sustainability is measured through a volatility test which is defined as t
            </span>
           </strong>
           he 2 years average income is &lt;= 130% of the prior year’s income figure. (
           <span>
            Where
           </span>
           <span>
            the 2 years average income is &gt; 130% of the prior year’s income,
           </span>
           <span>
            refer to
           </span>
           <span>
            Serviceability calculations, approval conditions and authority level - fully verified self-employed assessment.)
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <span>
      The following are not eligible to be assessed using Fully verified - Latest year income assessment:
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         Applications assessed using
         <strong>
          <span>
           Fast track self-employed assessment
          </span>
         </strong>
         policy
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         When the income assessment reflects the business is running at a loss in the latest year
         <sup>
          1
         </sup>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         When the business has been trading for &lt; 2 full financial years
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      Mortgage insured applications are not eligible for assessment using latest year income
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="3">
     <span>
      <b>
       Notes:
      </b>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <sup>
       1
      </sup>
      For a sole trader or partnership this is the “Adjusted Net Profit” and for a company / Trust this is the “Adjusted Net Profit After Tax and Repayments” figure from the self-employed income calculator
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
  </tbody>
 </table>

 <h4>

 <h4>
  <a name="R_Rental_income_-_standard_assessment_2_">
   <strong>
    <span>
     <span>
      2.2.2 Rental income - fully verified self-employed assessment
     </span>
    </span>
   </strong>
  </a>
 </h4>
 <span>
  <span>
   This rental income policy applies to all fully verified self-employed assessment methods including but not limited to:
  </span>
 </span>
 <ul>
  <li>
   <a href="#R_Fully_verified_SE_standard_assessment_">
    <em>
     Fully verified self-employed - 2 year average
    </em>
   </a>
  </li>
  <li>
   <a href="#R_fully_verified_-_latest_year_income">
    <em>
     Fully verified self-employed - Latest year income
    </em>
   </a>
  </li>
 </ul>
 <span>
  <span>
   Rental income, expenses and any interest or tax deductibility must align to the owner of the property, to ensure serviceability is correctly calculated. To correctly assess the investment property income and expenses the investment property assessment table (below) must be followed.
   <br/>
  </span>
 </span>
 <table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="1">
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2">
     <h4>
      <span>
       <strong>
        <span>
         Investment property assessment
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
     </h4>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <h4>
      <span>
       <strong>
        <span>
         Scenario
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
     </h4>
    </td>
    <td>
     <h4>
      <span>
       <strong>
        <span>
         Action
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
     </h4>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       1. Investment property is being
       <strong>
        <span>
         purchased
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
      in this transaction ( by an individual or by an entity
      <sup>
       <span>
        *
       </span>
      </sup>
      )
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Rental income is to be verified as per
       <em>
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000721">
         Verifying income
        </a>
        &gt;
       </em>
       <em>
        <span>
         Rules you must apply &gt; Supplementary Income
        </span>
       </em>
      </li>
      <li>
       Rental must be loaded in ApplyOnline
      </li>
      <li>
       Related expenses to be loaded in ApplyOnline with the real estate collateral. Refer to
       <em>
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000700">
         Living Expense
        </a>
        &gt; Rules you must apply &gt; expense category table.
       </em>
      </li>
     </ul>
     When the borrower is an individual:
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         Enter any rental income tax deduction / negative gearing via ApplyOnline. Refer to
         <em>
          <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000710">
           Serviceability Assessment
          </a>
          &gt; Rules you must apply &gt; Rental income tax deductions for Australian investment properties (Negative Gearing)
         </em>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
     When the borrower is an entity:
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          Rental income tax deduction / negative gearing is not available
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
       <span>
        <span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       2. Investment property is
       <strong>
        owned by an individual
       </strong>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Rental income is to be verified as per
       <em>
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000721">
         Verifying income
        </a>
        &gt;
       </em>
       <em>
        <span>
         Rules you must apply &gt; Supplementary Income
        </span>
       </em>
      </li>
      <li>
       Rental must be loaded in ApplyOnline
      </li>
      <li>
       Related expenses to be loaded in ApplyOnline with the real estate collateral. Refer to
       <em>
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000700">
         Living Expense
        </a>
        &gt; Rules you must apply &gt; expense category table.
       </em>
      </li>
      <li>
       Enter any rental income tax deduction / negative gearing via ApplyOnline. Refer to
       <em>
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000710">
         Serviceability Assessment
        </a>
        &gt; Rules you must apply &gt; Rental income tax deductions for Australian investment properties (Negative Gearing
       </em>
       )
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       3. Investment property owned by an entity
       <sup>
        <span>
         *
        </span>
       </sup>
       , currently rented, and rented for
       <strong>
        <span>
         the entire period
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
      covered by the tax returns, used for serviceability assessment.
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <ul>
      <li>
       The Net rental feature must be used (located within the Serviceability Income Calculator)
      </li>
      <li>
       Capture the gross rent for the investment property from the entity tax return rental schedule only
      </li>
      <li>
       Capture the number of weeks the property was rented from the entity tax return rental schedule
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <span>
       The net rental feature will shade the rental income and calculate a rental adjustment figure that must be loaded with the self-employed income and included in the serviceability assessment.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       <strong>
        <span>
         Note
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
     </span>
     <span>
      <span>
       : Investment property expenses do not need to be captured as are already included in the tax return net profit and property expense floor rate will not apply.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       Rental income tax deduction / negative gearing is not available. Interest, depreciation (including capital allowance) and any once off expenses can be added back to the entity (do not use the net rental feature for addbacks
      </span>
     </span>
     <span>
      <span>
       ), weher eplicy allows the addback type. Refer to
       <a href="#R_Allowable_addbacks">
        <em>
         Allowable addbacks
        </em>
       </a>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       4. Investment property owned by an entity
       <sup>
        <span>
         *
        </span>
       </sup>
       , currently rented but rented for
       <strong>
        <span>
         only part of the period
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
      covered by the tax returns, used for serviceability assessment.
     </span>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Rental income is
        <b>
         <u>
          not
         </u>
        </b>
        received on a short term basis
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        (e.g. the property is not holiday or student accommodation)
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <ul>
      <li>
       The Net rental feature must be used (located within the Serviceability Calculator)
      </li>
      <li>
       Capture the gross rent for the investment property from the entity tax return rental schedule
      </li>
      <li>
       Capture the number of weeks the property was rented from the entity tax return rental schedule
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <span>
       The net rental feature will calculate a rental adjustment figure that must be loaded with the self-employed income and included in the serviceability assessment.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       The net rental adjustment is based on:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       annualising the rental income
      </li>
      <li>
       adjust for shading, however an additional 10% rental shading (over and above the standard minimum 20% rental shading) will be included, to account for investment property expenses (irrespective of whether the property was rented for 1 week or 51 weeks of the financial year).
      </li>
      <li>
       the rental income already received will then be subtracted.
      </li>
     </ul>
     <strong>
      <span>
       <span>
        Note
       </span>
      </span>
     </strong>
     <span>
      <span>
       : Investment property expenses do not need to be captured as are already included in the tax return net profit, plus an additional 10% shading and property expense floor rate will not apply.
       <br/>
       Rental income tax deduction / negative gearing is not available. Interest, depreciation (including capital allowance) and any once off expenses can be added back to the entity (do not use the net rental feature for addbacks), where policy allows the addback type. Refer to
       <a href="#R_Allowable_addbacks">
        <em>
         Allowable addbacks
        </em>
       </a>
       <br/>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       5. Investment property owned by an entity
       <sup>
        <span>
         *
        </span>
       </sup>
       and currently rented but
       <strong>
        <span>
         not rented in the period covered by the tax returns
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
      , used in the serviceability assessment.
     </span>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Rental income is
        <b>
         <u>
          not
         </u>
        </b>
        received on a short term basis
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        (e.g. the property is not holiday or student accommodation)
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Rental income is to be verified as per
       <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000721">
        <em>
         Verifying income
        </em>
       </a>
       &gt;
       <em>
        <span>
         Rules you must apply &gt; Supplementary Income
        </span>
       </em>
      </li>
      <li>
       Related expenses to be confirmed.
       <em>
        <em>
         Refer to
        </em>
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000700">
         Living Expense
        </a>
        &gt; Rules you must apply &gt; expense category table
       </em>
       .
      </li>
      <li>
       The Net rental feature (located within the Serviceability Calculator ) must be used
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <span>
       The net rental feature will shade the rental income, subtract the investment property expenses, and calculate a rental adjustment figure that is loaded with the self-employed income (in the latest financial year only) as a taxed add back and included in the serviceability assessment.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       Rental income tax deduction / negative gearing is not available. Interest, depreciation (including capital allowance) and any once off expenses can be added back to the entity (do not use the Serviceability Calculator for addbacks), where policy allows the addback type. Refer to
       <a href="#R_Allowable_addbacks">
        <em>
         Allowable addbacks
        </em>
       </a>
       <br/>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     6. Investment property
     <b>
      <u>
       is
      </u>
     </b>
     rented on a short term basis and owned by an entity
     <sup>
      *
     </sup>
     , currently rented / available for rent on a short term basis, but rented for
     <strong>
      <span>
       only part of the period
      </span>
     </strong>
     covered by the tax returns, used for serviceability assessment.
    </td>
    <td>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           The Net rental feature must be used (located within the Self-Employed Income Calculator)
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           Capture the gross rent for the investment property from the entity tax return rental schedule
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           Capture the number of weeks the property was rented from the entity tax return rental schedule
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
     The net rental feature will calculate a rental adjustment figure that must be loaded with the self-employed income and included in the serviceability assessment.
     <br/>
     <br/>
     The net rental adjustment is based on:
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           Gross actual rental income (no annualising)
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           adjust for shading, however an additional 10% rental shading (over and above the standard minimum rental shading) will be included, to account for investment property expenses (irrespective of whether the property was rented for 1 week or 51 weeks of the financial year).
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           the rental income already received will then be subtracted.
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <div>
      <div>
       <div id="_com_1" language="JavaScript">
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <strong>
            Note
           </strong>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           : Investment property expenses do not need to be captured as are already included in the tax return net profit, plus an additional 10% shading.
           <br/>
           Rental income tax deduction / negative gearing is not available. Interest, depreciation (including capital allowance ) and any once off expenses can be added back to the entity (do not use the net rental feature for add backs) where policy allows the addback type. Refer to
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <a data-tagid="R_Allowable_addbacks" href="#R_Allowable_addbacks">
            Allowable addbacks
           </a>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     7. Investment property
     <b>
      <u>
       is
      </u>
     </b>
     rented on a short term basis and owned by an entity
     <sup>
      *
     </sup>
     is currently rented / available for rent on a short term basis, but
     <strong>
      <span>
       not rented in the period covered by the tax returns
      </span>
     </strong>
     , used in the serviceability assessment.
    </td>
    <td>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           Rental income cannot be used in the serviceability assessment
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           Capture the customer declared investment property expenses
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        The net rental feature will calculate a rental adjustment figure that must be loaded with the self-employed income and included in the serviceability assessment.
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2">
     <span>
      <span>
       <sup>
        <span>
         *
        </span>
       </sup>
       <strong>
        <span>
         Note
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
      :  An entity includes a partnership, company, or trust
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
  </tbody>
 </table>
