 <h4>
  <a name="R_Allowable_addbacks">
   <strong>
    <span>
     <span>
      2.3.1 Allowable addbacks
     </span>
    </span>
   </strong>
  </a>
 </h4>
 <span>
  <span>
   Where Addbacks are being used for income assessment the
  </span>
 </span>
 <span>
  <span>
   Broker / Assessor
  </span>
 </span>
 <span>
  <span>
   must ensure their loan assessment notes identify the addbacks being used and explain why it should be considered.
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <strong>
  <span>
   <span>
    Note:
   </span>
  </span>
 </strong>
 <span>
  <span>
   On loans where LMI is required and addbackss other than Depreciation, Interest, Leasing and Hire purchase are required to meet servicing, such proposals must be referred to the Mortgage Insurer.
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <h4>
  <a name="R_Depreciation">
   <strong>
    <span>
     <span>
      2.3.2 Depreciation
     </span>
    </span>
   </strong>
  </a>
 </h4>
 <h4>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     Definition
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h4>
 <span>
  <span>
   Depreciation is an accounting method for allocating the cost of a tangible or physical asset over its useful life or life expectancy. Depreciation represents how much of an asset's value has been used up. Depreciation 'expenses' are generally considered not direct costs to the business, hence cash-flow should be available to meet loan repayments.
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   <strong>
    Note
   </strong>
   :
  </span>
 </span>
 <span>
  <span>
   Depreciation is not an acceptable addback for a Trust entity,  given the manner in which a trust utilises depreciation is quite unique and not comparable to other entity types. As a result of the method used by a trust to disburse profits to its beneficiaries, we cannot accurately determine if a beneficiary received a monetary benefit from the depreciation.
  </span>
 </span>
 <div>
  <div id="_com_1" uage="JavaScript">
  </div>
 </div>
 <span>
  <span>
   <br/>
   <strong>
    <span>
     When can depreciation be used as an addback for serviceability assessment
    </span>
   </strong>
  </span>
 </span>
 <table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="1">
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <h4>
      <strong>
       <span>
        <span>
         What % can I use
        </span>
       </span>
      </strong>
     </h4>
    </td>
    <td>
     <h4>
      <strong>
       <span>
        <span>
         When
        </span>
       </span>
      </strong>
     </h4>
    </td>
    <td>
     <h4>
      <strong>
       <span>
        <span>
         What do I need to do
        </span>
       </span>
      </strong>
     </h4>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       100%
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <ul>
      <li>
       The business type must be a sole trader, partnership or company;
       <strong>
        and
       </strong>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         The depreciated assets are under finance
         <strong>
          <span>
           and
          </span>
         </strong>
        </span>
       </span>
       <span>
        <span>
         a corresponding liability is evident on the balance sheet.
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       We permit the addback in this instance because if at a future point in time the asset requires renewal, the applicant may also renew the debt and in our serviceability assessment we have included the existing commitment
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <strong>
      <span>
       <span>
        Non-mortgage insured applications
       </span>
      </span>
     </strong>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       Where ApplyOnline or the Serviceability Calculator is the assessment tool:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       ensure a commitment has been loaded (refer to
       <em>
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000690">
         Commitments
        </a>
       </em>
       policy for further details about verification requirements)
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <strong>
       <span>
        Mortgage insured applications
       </span>
      </strong>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Same as non-mortgage insured applications
       <strong>
        plus
       </strong>
       , application must be referred to the Credit for consideration.
      </li>
      <li>
       Credit may choose to allow the use of depreciation in whole or part for serviceability assessment
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Depreciation addback percentage which can be used may vary between 0% - 100%
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Depreciation addback must be adjusted in line with personal use percentage
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
    <td>
     <ul>
      <li>
       The business type must be a sole trader, partnership or company;
       <strong>
        and
       </strong>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         The depreciation is in respect of an income producing asset (that is
         <strong>
          <span>
           not
          </span>
         </strong>
        </span>
       </span>
       <span>
        <span>
         under finance) and that asset is required to be maintained / updated to ensure continuance of the income.
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <span>
       <br/>
       Examples of this would include:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Taxi operators applying depreciation on their cab.
      </li>
      <li>
       Truck operators depreciating their truck/s.
      </li>
      <li>
       Excavation/Earthmoving operators applying depreciation on machinery.
      </li>
      <li>
       Restaurant equipment / furnishings or fit out.
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <span>
       In these types of scenarios, the depreciation item claimed should not be added back, as the equipment itself will require maintenance and / or replacement at some point, hence funds will need to be apportioned / set aside to be able to do this.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <strong>
      <span>
       <span>
        Non-mortgage insured applications
       </span>
      </span>
     </strong>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       You must:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       contact the applicant and obtain additional information to understand if the assets being depreciated:
       <ul>
        <li>
         are being used for personal purposes and if so, the percentage used for personal and business use (depreciation addback percentage cannot exceed the business use percentage)
         <strong>
          <span>
           and
          </span>
         </strong>
        </li>
        <li>
         the lifespan of these assets and whether these are integral to the daily operation of the business
         <strong>
          <span>
           and
          </span>
         </strong>
        </li>
       </ul>
      </li>
      <li>
       Record the outcome of the discussions in loan assessment notes
       <strong>
        <span>
         and
        </span>
       </strong>
      </li>
      <li>
       Upload to ApplyOnline any supporting documentation such as a depreciation schedule
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <strong>
       <span>
        Mortgage insured applications
       </span>
      </strong>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Same as non-mortgage insured applications
       <strong>
        plus,
       </strong>
       application must be referred to the Credit for consideration.
      </li>
      <li>
       Credit may choose to allow the use of depreciation in whole or part for serviceability assessment
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
  </tbody>
 </table>
 <h4>
  <br/>
  <span>
   <a name="R_Amortisation">
    <strong>
     <span>
      <span>
       2.3.3 Amortisation
      </span>
     </span>
    </strong>
   </a>
  </span>
 </h4>
 <span>
  <span>
   Amortisation is the deduction of capital expenses over a specific period of time. Similar to depreciation, it is a method of measuring the consumption of the value of goodwill over a period of time. Amortisation can be included as an allowable addbacks.
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <br/>
 <strong>
  <span>
   <span>
    Note
   </span>
  </span>
 </strong>
 <span>
  <span>
   : Amortisation is not an acceptable addback for a Trust entity given the manner in which a trust utilises amortisation is quite unique and not comparable to other entity types. As a result of the method used by a trust to disburse profits to its beneficiaries, we cannot accurately determine  if a beneficiary received a monetary benefit from the Amortisation.
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <h4>
  <a name="R_Interest_(bank_borrowings)_Leasing_or_">
   <strong>
    <span>
     <span>
      2.3.4 Interest (bank borrowings) Leasing or Hire Purchase fixed commitments
     </span>
    </span>
   </strong>
  </a>
 </h4>
 <table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="1">
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <h4>
      <strong>
       <span>
        <span>
         Addback type
        </span>
       </span>
      </strong>
     </h4>
    </td>
    <td>
     <h4>
      <span>
       <strong>
        <span>
         May be added back where the below conditions are satisfied
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
     </h4>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Leasing or Hire purchase fixed commitments
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <ul>
      <li>
       The full monthly repayment for the fixed commitment is included as part of the applicants outgoing costs; or
      </li>
      <li>
       The liability has been repaid since lodgement of the financial statements; or
      </li>
      <li>
       The fixed commitment is being refinanced as part of this loan application
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Interest
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <ul>
      <li>
       The full monthly repayment for the fixed commitment is included as part of the applicants outgoing costs; or
      </li>
      <li>
       The liability has been repaid since lodgement of the financial statements; or
      </li>
      <li>
       The fixed commitment is being refinanced as part of this loan application
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
  </tbody>
 </table>
 <span>
  <span>
   In ApplyOnline, load under appropriate add-back heading e.g. interest or leasing (excludes scenarios where net rental calculation worksheet has been used).
  </span>
 </span>
 <h4>
  <br/>
  <span>
   <a name="R_Superannuation">
    <strong>
     <span>
      <span>
       2.3.5 Superannuation (Sole Trader, Partnerships and Company Structures)
      </span>
     </span>
    </strong>
   </a>
  </span>
 </h4>
 <span>
  <span>
   A superannuation guarantee cost is only compulsory to a Sole Trader, Partnership that has an external employee or under a company structure.
  </span>
 </span>
 <ul>
  <li>
   Though it is not compulsory for self-employed applicants to contribute towards superannuation, in some instances, applicants do make large bulk payments to such funds. Owners of companies often make contributions on their own behalf in excess, of the statutory superannuation guarantee amount.
  </li>
  <li>
   The superannuation guarantee cost is assessed as a percentage of the salary and the director’s fees (in the case of a company) paid to the employees and company director(s). The amount of any contribution made in excess, of the statutory requirement, may be used as an addbacks. This will only be considered appropriate when the Profit and Loss statement clearly shows payments were made on behalf of the applicants and not the employees and it can be demonstrated that the excess contributions are not required to service any Self-Managed Super Fund (SMSF) borrowings that the self-employed applicant may have.
  </li>
 </ul>

 <h4>
  <br/>
  <span>
   <a name="R_Non_recurring_items">
    <strong>
     <span>
      <span>
       2.3.6 Non-recurring items
      </span>
     </span>
    </strong>
   </a>
  </span>
 </h4>
 <span>
  <span>
   Self-employed applicants may incur significant one-off expenses or income items that are not part of normal business activities. Where one of these items are incurred, for the purposes of the Bank's income assessment, the non-recurring
   <u>
    expense
   </u>
   should be added back to the net income prior to taxation being calculated and the non-recurring
   <u>
    income
   </u>
   item, must be subtracted from the net income prior to taxation being calculated.
   <br/>
   <br/>
   Example of one-off income:
  </span>
 </span>
 <ul>
  <li>
   Capital gain following the sale of an asset.
  </li>
  <li>
   The profit received from the sale of an asset.
  </li>
  <li>
   Non-recurring interest.
  </li>
  <li>
   Employee fringe benefit contribution.
  </li>
  <li>
   Any grant or boost payment.
  </li>
 </ul>
 <span>
  <span>
   Examples of one-off expenses:
  </span>
 </span>
 <ul>
  <li>
   The loss realised following the disposal of an asset.
  </li>
  <li>
   Once off significant bad debt write-off.
  </li>
 </ul>
 <span>
  <span>
   <br/>
   Addbacks from Capital accounts are not acceptable for income assessment purposes as they reflect a reduction in the net worth of the entity.
  </span>
 </span>
 <h4>
  <br/>
  <span>
   <a name="R_Working_Capital">
    <strong>
     <span>
      <span>
       2.3.7 Working Capital
      </span>
     </span>
    </strong>
   </a>
  </span>
 </h4>
 <span>
  <span>
   If the business is one that requires working capital, i.e., manufacturing, trading, etc ensure sufficient working capital is available.
   <br/>
   If undistributed profits are to be used in the serviceability assessment, consideration needs to be made whether the loss of funds will affect the business / company.
   <br/>
  </span>
 </span>
 <h3>
  <br/>
  <span>
   <a name="R_Fast_track_self-employed_assessment">
    <strong>
     <span>
      <span>
       2.4 Fast track self-employed assessment
      </span>
     </span>
    </strong>
   </a>
  </span>
 </h3>
 <span>
  <span>
   Fast Track assessment is a simple Self-Employed income assessment method relying on the applicants 2 year’s personal Australian Taxation Office (ATO) Notice of Assessments (NOA's). To assess income under the Self-employed Fast Track income verification method:
  </span>
 </span>
 <ul>
  <li>
   The eligibility criteria must be met.
  </li>
  <li>
   Income from the self-employed applicant is to be verified completely from the applicants personal ATO NOA's, i.e. no further self-employed income documentation (within age of documentation requirements) is to be held or requested, where servicing is met using income from the ATO NOA’s.
  </li>
  <li>
   An ABN search must be performed on all associated self-employed entities to confirm a minimum of two full financial years self-employment. Refer to
   <a href="#R_completing_ABN_business_name_or_compan">
    <em>
     completing ABN, business name or company searches
    </em>
   </a>
  </li>
 </ul>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   If the applicant is self-employed and also has a second completely independent PAYG job, the PAYG income will also be verified from the ATO NOA’s only. If the PAYG employment commenced after the period covered by the ATO NOAs, and the income is required for serviceability assessment, then Fast Track is
   <strong>
    <span>
     not
    </span>
   </strong>
  </span>
  available and one of the
  <a href="#R_Fully_verified_SE_standard_assessment_">
   <em>
    <u>
     <span>
      Fully verified self-employed assessment
     </span>
    </u>
   </em>
  </a>
 </span>
 <span>
  <span>
   policies must be used.
   <br/>
   <br/>
   The
   <strong>
    <span>
     only
    </span>
   </strong>
  </span>
 </span>
 <span>
  <span>
   exception where income can be considered that is not captured in the ATO NOA’s held is rental income where the rental income commenced, after the financial years covered by the ATO NOA’s provided. In this instance investment property expenses must be identified and included in-line with Living Expenses policy.
   <br/>
   <br/>
   When the applicant has investment properties that earned rental income during the ATO NOA period (either part of, or the entire period), then it is acceptable to load a $0 investment property expense for this real estate, as the expenses are already captured in the ATO NOA taxable income figure.  In this scenario the following comment, or similar, must be entered as the $0 expense explanation:
   <br/>
   <em>
    <span>
     “Nil investment property expenses captured as the rental property was owned during the period covered by the ATO NOAs (or part thereof), and the rental expenses are factored into the total taxable income figure sourced from the ATO NOA.”
    </span>
   </em>
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   <strong>
    <span>
     Notes
    </span>
   </strong>
  </span>
  :
 </span>
 <ul>
  <li>
   When a property is only rented for part of the period covered by the ATO NOA’s no annualisation of rental income is permitted under Fast Track and there is no expectation to load additional investment property expenses.  If rental income of this nature requires annualisation for the serviceability assessment then Fast Track is
   <strong>
    <span>
     not
    </span>
   </strong>
   available and one of the
   <a href="#R_Fully_verified_SE_standard_assessment_">
    <em>
     <u>
      <span>
       Fully verified self-employed assessment
      </span>
     </u>
    </em>
   </a>
   policies must be used.
  </li>
  <li>
   When the ATO NOA shows franking credits, no adjustment of the taxable income is required to account for the franking credit. A franking credit must not be added to or subtracted from the Taxable income figure.
  </li>
  <li>
   When serviceability is assessed under the Fast Track method, a self-employed entity (e.g. company or trust) must not be included separately in the serviceability assessment, and verification of any commitments related to the company and / or Trust (with corporate trustee) is not required.
  </li>
 </ul>
 <strong>
  <span>
   <span>
    Exception authorities do not extend to Fast Track eligibility criteria.
   </span>
  </span>
 </strong>
 <br/>
 <h4>
  <a name="R__Eligibility_criteria_-_fast_track">
   <strong>
    <span>
     <span>
      2.4.1 Eligibility criteria – Fast track self-employed assessment
     </span>
    </span>
   </strong>
  </a>
 </h4>
 <span>
  <span>
   Applicant has been Self-employed for more than 2 full financial years; and
  </span>
 </span>
 <ul>
  <li>
   Borrower type - individual, joint applicants, individuals as trustee for a trust, joint applicants as trustee for a trust (
   <strong>
    <span>
     note
    </span>
   </strong>
   : also refer to
   <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000694">
    <em>
     <u>
      <span>
       Eligibility
      </span>
     </u>
    </em>
   </a>
   policy)
  </li>
  <li>
   Income to be assessed from
   <strong>
    <span>
     2 years
    </span>
   </strong>
   ATO Notice of Assessments that meet age of document requirements. It is mandatory to hold all pages of the ATO NOAs for Fast Track Self-employed
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       The ATO Notice of assessments used must be from the period of applicants self-employment
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       The
       <b>
        <u>
         only
        </u>
       </b>
       self-employed income verification documents that have been provided to the bank or held on file (within age of document requirements) are the ATO NOAs
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   The self-employed entity(s) from which the applicant derives their income, must have been established
   <strong>
    <span>
     and
    </span>
   </strong>
   trading for a minimum of two full financial years
  </li>
  <li>
   Any capital gains income on the ATO NOA are excluded and must be deducted for income assessment
  </li>
  <li>
   Where rental income commenced, after the financial years covered by the ATO NOA’s:
   <ul>
    <li>
     Evidence
     <sup>
      #
     </sup>
     is required to confirm the property was acquired, or the property was only rented, after the end of the financial years ATO NOA's held. ( Evidence of the purchase date of the property may be via a Conveyancers Settlement Statement or for existing customers, a prior mortgage application ); and
    </li>
    <li>
     Rental income must be assessed inline with Verifying income policy. Refer
     <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000721">
      Verifying Income
     </a>
     <em>
      &gt; Rules you must apply &gt; Supplementary Income
     </em>
    </li>
   </ul>
  </li>
  <li>
   Negative Gearing / Tax deductibility can only be considered where rental income commenced after the financial years covered by the ATO NOA. Where Negative Gearing can be considered refer to
   <em>
    <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000710">
     Serviceability Assessment
    </a>
    &gt; Rules you must apply &gt; Rental income tax deductions for Australian investment properties
   </em>
   (Negative Gearing)
  </li>
  <li>
   Loan is
   <strong>
    <span>
     not
    </span>
   </strong>
   Mortgage Insured
  </li>
 </ul>
 <sup>
  <span>
   <span>
    #
   </span>
  </span>
 </sup>
 <span>
  <span>
   If evidence of the purchase date, or commencement date of the rental contract is
   <strong>
    <span>
     unable
    </span>
   </strong>
  </span>
  to be supplied, the rental income is to be removed from the application / serviceability calculation. In addition, no tax deduction is allowed.
 </span>
 <br/>
 <br/>
 <h4>
  <a name="R_Exclusion_criteria_-_Fast_track">
   <strong>
    <span>
     <span>
      2.4.2 Exclusion criteria – Fast track self-employed assessment
     </span>
    </span>
   </strong>
  </a>
 </h4>
 <span>
  <span>
   Where the following apply the Fast Track process cannot be used:
  </span>
 </span>
 <ul>
  <li>
   Application has mortgage insurance
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       The bank is provided with or holds any self-employed income verification documents (within age of document requirements)
       <b>
        <u>
         other
        </u>
       </b>
       than the ATO NOAs.
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   Foreign income is received by the applicant
  </li>
  <li>
   Undistributed company profit is required in addition to the Fast Track income to meet serviceability.
   <strong>
    <span>
     Note:
    </span>
   </strong>
   Dividends (either from own company or other ASX shares) and / or Trust distribution income included in the applicants’ ATO NOAs is acceptable and should not be adjusted in any way.
  </li>
  <li>
   Rental income has been entered separately in the loan application
   <strong>
    <span>
     and
    </span>
   </strong>
   it has been earned in any year covered by the ATO Notice of Assessment provided
  </li>
  <li>
   Applicant has been self-employed for less than 2 full financial years
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      ATO Notice of assessments used do not match applicants time as self-employed.
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
 </ul>
 <span>
  <span>
   In some cases Credit may decide the application needs to be assessed using one of the
   <a href="#R_Fully_verified_SE_standard_assessment_">
    <em>
     <u>
      <span>
       Fully verified self-employed assessment
      </span>
     </u>
    </em>
   </a>
  </span>
 </span>
 <span>
  <span>
   policy criteria, where this occurs the applicant will need to provide additional information.
   <br/>
   <br/>
   Where applicants are unable to satisfy
   <strong>
    <span>
     all
    </span>
   </strong>
  </span>
  of the above conditions the applicant must be assessed using one of the
  <a href="#R_Fully_verified_SE_standard_assessment_">
   <em>
    <u>
     <span>
      Fully verified self-employed assessment
     </span>
    </u>
   </em>
  </a>
 </span>
 <span>
  <span>
   policy criteria.
   <br/>
   <br/>
   <strong>
    <span>
     Note:
    </span>
   </strong>
  </span>
  Where there are multiple self-employed applicants and the applicants receive income from the same self-employed business or if any of the self-employed entities are inter linked ( between the applicants ), then the income must be verified using the same assessment method.  It is however acceptable to verify one applicant under Fast Track and another applicant under one of the
  <a href="#R_Fully_verified_SE_standard_assessment_">
   <em>
    <u>
     <span>
      Fully verified self-employed assessment
     </span>
    </u>
   </em>
  </a>
 </span>
 <span>
  <span>
   policies when their business entities are completely independent of each other and the applicants do not receive income from the same entity.
   <br/>
   <br/>
   Where 2 or more applicants share investment properties, and they are assessed by different assessment methods (i.e. applicant 1 is Fast Track and applicant 2 is PAYG or applicant 1 is Fast Track and Applicant 2 is Fully verified self-employed) any shared rental income cannot be entered for the non Fast Track applicant to ensure it is not double counted or overinflated.  If the non Fast Track applicant’s share of rent is required to meet serviceability then the Fast Track applicant must be assessed using one of the
   <a href="#R_Fully_verified_SE_standard_assessment_">
    <em>
     <u>
      <span>
       Fully verified self-employed assessment
      </span>
     </u>
    </em>
   </a>
  </span>
 </span>
 <span>
  <span>
   policies.
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <h4>
  <a name="R_Serviceability_assessment_-_Fast_track">
   <strong>
    <span>
     <span>
      2.4.3 Serviceability Assessment – Fast track self-employed assessment
     </span>
    </span>
   </strong>
  </a>
 </h4>
 <span>
  <span>
   The income used for serviceability assessment is outlined in the table below:
   <br/>
  </span>
 </span>
 <table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="1">
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <h4>
      <strong>
       <span>
        <span>
         Income used for serviceability assessment - Fast track
        </span>
       </span>
      </strong>
     </h4>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       When most recent year’s income is lower than the prior year, serviceability assessment will use the most recent year’s income.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td rowspan="2">
     <span>
      <span>
       When the most recent year’s income is higher than the prior year, serviceability will be based on the average of the most recent year’s and the prior year’s income.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
   </tr>
  </tbody>
 </table>
 <h3>
  <br/>
  <span>
   <a name="R_Accountants_letter">
    <strong>
     <span>
      <span>
       2.5 Accountants letter
      </span>
     </span>
    </strong>
   </a>
  </span>
  <br/>
 </h3>
 <strong>
  <span>
   <span>
    Accountants letter / Accountants email advice mandatory requirements
   </span>
  </span>
 </strong>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   An Accountants letter or Accountants email advice may only be used to support the specific assessment methods as per the table below:
   <br/>
  </span>
 </span>
 <table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="1">
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <strong>
         <span>
          Action required
         </span>
        </strong>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        In all Instances w
        <strong>
         <span>
          here a letter / email from the business’s accountant is permitted for use as a supporting document
         </span>
        </strong>
        <strong>
         <span>
          you must
         </span>
        </strong>
        <strong>
         <span>
          :
         </span>
        </strong>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           Adhere to the standards outlined in
           <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000692">
            Documents standards
           </a>
           policy:
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
       <ul>
        <li>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             Accountants letter
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             Accountants email advice
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
       </ul>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           Verify the Accountant’s or Accounting firm’s tax agent / BAS agent registration status is current, using
           <a href="https://www.tpb.gov.au/registrations_search">
            https://www.tpb.gov.au/registrations_search
           </a>
           . Upload to OBP the search result. The Tax Practitioner Board (TPB) number may be required to perform this search, so it is preferable for the TPB Number be included on the Accountant Letter / email, however, this is not mandatory

 <h3>
  <a name="F_Frequently_Asked_Questions">
   <strong>
    <span>
     <span>
      3. Frequently Asked Questions - FAQs
     </span>
    </span>
   </strong>
  </a>
 </h3>
 <table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="1">
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <h4>
      <strong>
       <span>
        <span>
         Question
        </span>
       </span>
      </strong>
     </h4>
    </td>
    <td>
     <h4>
      <strong>
       <span>
        <span>
         Answer
        </span>
       </span>
      </strong>
     </h4>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       My customer was running a lawn mowing franchise in 2017 / 2018 financial year and is now a finance broker in 2018/2019.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       They have greater than 2 years history of being self-employed and more than 2 years of financials, so why would I need to refer my application to Credit?
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       The self-employed industry / field
       <strong>
        <span>
         is not
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
      the same, so this is not considered continuous. This does not qualify under self-employed policy. If an exception is supported, the loan application must be referred to credit with supporting mitigating reasons outlined
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       If I don't need the income from my customer's company for servicing, why do I need to get the financials?
       <br/>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Financials are required to ensure the entity was not running at a loss, the income paid to the individual is sustainable and has not been paid from an unsuitable source, e.g. as prior year retained profit or profit from sale of an asset.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       How would my customer be negatively impacted by their company making a loss? Isn't the company a separate entity?
       <br/>
       <br/>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       A trading / operating entity cannot sustain a loss indefinitely. Distributions made to the individual or other entities would not be sustainable so the income would not be acceptable. It is assumed the individual is propping up the entity keeping it afloat attempting to trade out of the loss.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       If my tax returns show a dependant, but the customer says they have no dependants, do I need to comment in the assessment notes?
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Yes, if your supporting documents indicate a dependant, then your assessment notes are to explain why you have not included the dependant for serviceability assessment.
       <br/>
       Refer to:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000700">
        <em>
         Living expenses
        </em>
       </a>
       &gt;
       <em>
        <span>
         Rules &gt; definition of a dependant
        </span>
       </em>
      </li>
      <li>
       <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000698">
        <em>
         <u>
          <span>
           Loan Application and Approval &gt; Validation of information provided by the customer
          </span>
         </u>
        </em>
       </a>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       How do I know what commitments my business, company or trust have?
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       There are a number of ways to obtain information about both assets and liabilities (commitments):
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Customer interview
      </li>
      <li>
       Completion of finance application
      </li>
      <li>
       Review of profit and loss statements and balance sheet
      </li>
      <li>
       Regular outgoings on statements
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <span>
       <br/>
       If your supporting documents conflict with the information provided by the customer, then remember to either amend the load or include an explanation in your assessment notes.
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <br/>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       If my customer has been trading for less than a year and I don't need the income for serviceability, (because the proposed new loan services on the PAYG applicant’s income only), why does the Bank need information about the self-employed entity and to evidence if the business is trading at a profit?
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Even for a newly established entity, there may have been debts or commitments that would impact the household's ability to borrow personally.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       A new business may not yet, be generating enough income to pay commitments and may be reliant on the PAYG individual helping to fund any shortfall.
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       We want to help customers achieve their financial goals whilst continuing to be responsible lenders.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>

 </table>
 <h3>
  <a name="R_completing_ABN_business_name_or_compan">
   <strong>
    <span>
     <span>
      4. Completing ABN, business name or company searches
     </span>
    </span>
   </strong>
  </a>
 </h3>
 <span>
  <span>
   To determine if an applicant is an owner or part owner of a Company a Broker should review the applicants Credit Bureau report. This credit bureau report will show any related directorships.
   <br/>
   <br/>
   While the Directors of the company have responsibility for the day to day management, we need to also consider who the shareholders are of the company when determining what income we can use in the loan assessment, i.e. share of profit based on being a director and percentage of shareholding. A company search will reflect the applicants current Shareholding of that entity, in addition to documenting any change(s) to shareholders and/or shareholdings since establishment of the company, where applicable.
   <br/>
   <br/>
   If the related entity is to a business trading name (e.g. Bluey's convenience store) but not a company (e.g. Blue Star Pty Ltd), then a business name search will reflect the applicant's relationship to the business.
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   An ABN search can confirm if the ABN is active, how long the ABN has been active and the GST registration status. Complete an ABN search using
  </span>
 </span>
 <span>
  <span>
   ABN Look-up via
  </span>
 </span>
 <a href="http://www.abr.business.gov.au/">
  <em>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      www.abr.business.gov.au
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </em>
 </a>
 <span>
  <span>
   .
  </span>
 </span>
 <ul>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      Where the search result shows the ABN is 'cancelled' or 'in-active':
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
   <ul>
    <li>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Include a comment in AOL
        <em>
         <span>
         </span>
        </em>
       </span>
       and;
      </span>
     </span>
    </li>
    <li>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Upload the ABN search to AOL.
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </li>
   </ul>
  </li>
 </ul>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    If the applicant discloses the entity has commitments or if it is evident via the Bank's systems, the commitments must be included in the serviceability assessment.  See example of
    <span>
     non- trading entity verified by ABN search
    </span>
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   When the application is assessed under Fast Track, an ABN search is required on all self-employed entities the applicant derives an income from, to confirm the self-employed entities have been established and trading for a minimum of two full financial years.
   <br/>
   <br/>
   <strong>
    <span>
     Note
    </span>
   </strong>
   : only the ABN search is required under Fast Track, a company directorship search is not required.
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <br/>
 <h3>
  <a name="G_Guide_to_understanding_changes_to_busi">
   <strong>
    <span>
     <span>
      5. Guide to understanding changes to business profitability and recording supporting rationale for Fully verified - latest year assessment
     </span>
    </span>
   </strong>
  </a>
 </h3>
 <br/>
 It is best practice to record factors relating to the assessment of self-employed / business income in all cases.
 <br/>
 <br/>
 When assessing serviceability based on the latest year self-employed income and the two years average income is &gt;130% of the prior years income, it is mandatory to review the business financials and to enter supporting comments to explain:
 <ul>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       Why there has been a change from the prior year.
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       How the change to business profit is sustainable into the future.
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       Why the income can be used for serviceability assessment.
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
 </ul>
 <span>
  Supporting comments should refer to the appropriate items in the financials / tax returns where possible and may also be supported by customer conversations and additional supporting documents if appropriate.
 </span>
 <br/>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   There are many factors which can affect the profitability of business income / self-employed applicants. This guide outlines some common scenarios which may be the reason for the change in profitability.
   <br/>
   <br/>
   It is not an exhaustive list of scenarios and each source of self-employed income will have its own unique story. These scenarios are provided to help guide you to have an insightful conversation with the borrower about why the business has experienced changes to profitability.
   <br/>
   <br/>
   <strong>
    <span>
     Scenarios
    </span>
   </strong>
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   When reviewing the financial information provided by the borrower if the latest years income is higher than the prior year’s income we should try to identify if the change is due to a reduction in expenses or an increase in sales.
   <br/>
  </span>
 </span>
 <table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="1">
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="3">
     <h4>
      <span>
       <span>
        <strong>
         Increase in sales
        </strong>
       </span>
      </span>
     </h4>
     <span>
      <span>
       When the increase in net profit is due to an increase in sales, a Broker / Assessor must understand how this increase occurred and if this is sustainable.
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       In addition to understanding how a business has increased the net profit, a Broker / Assessor should also consider potential industry or market changes that are likely to have an adverse impact on the business. To use an extreme example, during COVID-19 many restrictions were imposed which had a severe impact to industries such as tourism, retail, and hospitality, just to name a few.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <h4>
      <strong>
       <span>
        <span>
         Scenario
        </span>
       </span>
      </strong>
     </h4>
    </td>
    <td>
     <h4>
      <strong>
       <span>
        <span>
         Issues to consider / Potential implications
        </span>
       </span>
      </strong>
     </h4>
    </td>
    <td>
     <h4>
      <strong>
       <span>
        <span>
         What do I need to do?
        </span>
       </span>
      </strong>
     </h4>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Increase in demand for the products / services the business offers
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       How sustainable is the increase in demand?
       <br/>
       <br/>
       For Example
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       The business released a new product or service, and the new product / service is now part of the permanent suite of products / services the business offers. The new product / service has proven to be very popular and has resulted in higher trade, with trends in trade showing no signs of slowing demand.
      </li>
      <li>
       If the increase in demand is due to a ‘once off’ sale (including discontinuing a product line and selling the remaining stock at a reduced price), this would not be considered sustainable.
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
    <td rowspan="2">
     <ul>
      <li>
       Contact the borrower
       <strong>
        <span>
         and ask them
        </span>
       </strong>
       what they see as the benefits or disadvantages of the change.
      </li>
      <li>
       In your loan assessment notes explain:
       <ul>
        <li>
         Why there has been a change. Include details of the discussion with the customer.
        </li>
        <li>
         How the change to business profit is sustainable into the future.
        </li>
        <li>
         Why the income can be used for serviceability assessment.
        </li>
       </ul>
      </li>
      <li>
       Upload to ApplyOnline any supporting documentation you may have obtained from the customer.
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       The business increased the price of its goods / services.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Is the price increase permanent? Is the price increase competitive within the marketplace? Do competitors offer the same or a better product / service at a cheaper price?
       <br/>
       <br/>
       For example
       <br/>
       <br/>
       Has the business lost any customers / contracts as a result of the price increase?
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Usually, a price increase would be intended to be permanent however what if the business competitors offer the same product / service at a reduced cost. If the competitors do not increase their price, then the business may be at risk of losing customers and may need to reduce the price to complete. While the current year may show an increase in net profit this may not be sustainable into the future as customers leave. If the business has not lost any customers as a result, this is a good outcome but what supports the change as being sustainable?
      </li>
      <li>
       To ensure the business would not lose existing contracts, the business explored what their competitors offered. As well as increasing prices they added an extra feature to the product / service.  The cost of the extra feature was negligible and factored into the price change. With the enhanced product / service the business has attracted more customers since making the change. They are benefiting from both the increased sales and change to profit margin.
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
  </tbody>
 </table>
 <table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="1">
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="3">
     <h4>
      <strong>
       <span>
        <span>
         Reduction in expenses
        </span>
       </span>
      </strong>
     </h4>
     <span>
      <span>
       When the increase in net profit is a result of a reduction in expenses Brokers / Assessors should seek to understand if the reduction in expenses, is a once off or long-term cost reduction. When the reduction in expenses is a long-term cost reduction, then the loan assessment notes need to address how the reduction is sustainable and if this is expected to have any adverse impacts on the business.
       <br/>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <h4>
      <strong>
       <span>
        <span>
         Scenario
        </span>
       </span>
      </strong>
     </h4>
    </td>
    <td>
     <h4>
      <strong>
       <span>
        <span>
         Issues to consider / Potential implications
        </span>
       </span>
      </strong>
     </h4>
    </td>
    <td>
     <h4>
      <strong>
       <span>
        <span>
         What do I need to do?
        </span>
       </span>
      </strong>
     </h4>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       The business has relocated premises and secured cheaper rent.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       How will the relocation of the business impact the customers?
       <br/>
       <br/>
       For example
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       The business is a retail outlet and they have moved from a street frontage location on a busy street where they received a lot of walk-in customers.  The new premises, has no street frontage and has low foot traffic passing by.  What benefits or disadvantages come with moving?  Will they save on the rent but need to increase advertising costs to attract customers? Or have they decided they will target more online sales to counter the loss of foot traffic? If the business has fundamentally changed its target market (example: from walk in sales to online sales) then a cautious approach needs to be taken until the change has proven successful and sustainable.
      </li>
      <li>
       If the premises, is a warehouse / storage facility and not a customer facing site, the change of location may not have an adverse impact.
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
    <td rowspan="3">
     <ul>
      <li>
       Contact the borrower
       <strong>
        <span>
         and ask them
        </span>
       </strong>
       what they see as the benefits or disadvantages of the change.
      </li>
      <li>
       In your loan assessment notes explain:
       <ul>
        <li>
         Why there has been a change. Include details of the discussion with the customer.
        </li>
        <li>
         How the change to business profit is sustainable into the future.
        </li>
        <li>
         Why the income can be used for serviceability assessment.
        </li>
       </ul>
      </li>
      <li>
       Upload to ApplyOnline any supporting documentation you may have obtained from the customer.
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       The business has reduced staff costs or terminated employees.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Can the business generate the same level of sales / turnover with less staff?
       <br/>
       <br/>
       For example:
       <br/>
       <br/>
       If the business has terminated a staff member, what job role did that staff member fulfil and who is now completing that work? E.g.
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       If the staff member was the sole or highest achieving salesperson, will the business be able to sell its products / services effectively without this person? If the business owner themselves will take over the role, who will now cover the activities they were previously undertaking? Could there be a loss or run off of existing customers due to loyal customers following the prior sales person?
      </li>
      <li>
       What if the business was a logistics company and the terminated staff member was the sole truck driver, how will deliveries be made?
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       The business reduced expenses by stopping an expense such as a hire purchase for example.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       What did this expense relate to?
       <br/>
       <br/>
       Did the expense cease because a loan term was completed?
       <br/>
       <br/>
       Did the business stop hiring / leasing equipment / machinery?
       <br/>
       <br/>
       For example
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       If the expense related to hiring equipment / machinery, how will the business continue to generate the same level of profit without this equipment / machinery?
      </li>
      <li>
       If a loan term reached completion, has the funded asset also reached the end of its life? Does the asset now need to be replaced?
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
  </tbody>
 </table>
 <br/>
 <br/>
</div>

 <h2>

  </a>
  <strong>

  </strong>
 </h2>
 <h3>
 </h3>
 <h3>
  <a name="R_Debt_Service_Coverage_Ratio">
  </a>
  <strong>
   2.1 Debt Service Coverage Ratio
  </strong>
 </h3>
 <table>
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <strong>
         <span>
          Definition
         </span>
        </strong>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td colspan="3">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        For consumer mortgage loans assessed in OBP, the borrower(s) and (any) income guarantor
        <span>
         (s)
        </span>
        capacity to service all debt is rated using the ‘Debt Service Coverage’ ratio measurement (DSC).
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Refer to
        <a data-tagid="Minimum DSC required" href="#Minimum DSC required">
         ‘Minimum DSC required’
        </a>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <strong>
         <span>
          DSC Calculation
         </span>
        </strong>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td colspan="3">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        (Shaded Total Net Income – Total Expenses) / (
        <a data-tagid="R_Serviceability_Repayment_Amount" href="#R_Serviceability_Repayment_Amount">
         Serviceability repayment amount
        </a>
        <sup>
        </sup>
        used for existing commitments + new loans)
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <strong>
         <span>
          ‘Total expenses’ for the purpose of the DSC calculation
         </span>
        </strong>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td colspan="3">
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             Customer declared living expenses
            </span>
           </span>
           <a data-tagid="R_Customer_declared_living_expenses_–__n" href="#R_Customer_declared_living_expenses_–__n">
            <span>
             <span>
              <span>
               not comparable to HEM
              </span>
             </span>
            </span>
           </a>
           <span>
            <span>
             , plus
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             the higher of:
            </span>
           </span>

 <h3>
  <br/>
  <a name="R_Income">
  </a>
  <strong>
   2.2 Income
  </strong>
 </h3>
 Only income from a borrower(s) or an income guarantor(s) can be used. Refer to
 <em>
  <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000694">
   Eligibility
  </a>
 </em>
 and
 <em>
  <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000696">
   Guarantees
  </a>
  .
 </em>
 <br/>
 <br/>
 Also refer to:
 <ul>
  <li>
   <em>
    <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000721">
     Verifying Income
    </a>
   </em>
  </li>
  <li>
   <em>
    <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000694">
     Eligibility
    </a>
   </em>
  </li>
  <li>
   <em>
    <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000696">
     Guarantees
    </a>
    .
   </em>
  </li>
 </ul>
 <h3>
  <a name="R_Living_Expenses">
  </a>
  <strong>
   2.3 Living Expenses
  </strong>
 </h3>
 Borrower(s) and income guarantor(s) are required to declare all household living expenses that are in place at the time of the application, as well as those which will be in place after settlement of their loan.
 <br/>
 Also refer to:
 <ul>
  <li>
   <a href="#R_Customer_declared_living_expenses_–com">
    Customer declared living expenses –
    <em>
     compared to HEM
    </em>
   </a>
  </li>
  <li>
   <a href="#R_Customer_declared_living_expenses_–__n">
    Customer declared living expenses –
    <em>
     not compared to HEM
    </em>
   </a>
  </li>
  <li>
   <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000700">
    <em>
     Living Expenses
    </em>
   </a>
  </li>
  <li>
   <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000696">
    Guarantees
   </a>
  </li>
  <li>
   <a data-tagid="2.4.1 • Apportioned household expenses and shared commitments - Spousal same household" href="#2.4.1 • Apportioned household expenses and shared commitments - Spousal same household">
    Apportioned household expenses and shared commitments - Spousal same household
   </a>
  </li>
 </ul>
 <h3>
  <a name="R_Commitments">
  </a>
  <strong>
   2.4 Commitments
  </strong>
 </h3>
 <ul>
  <li>
   The borrower(s) and any income guarantor(s) commitments are considered in serviceability.
  </li>
  <li>
   All existing commitments are to be reflected in the application, regardless of whether they are to be closed, reduced or continued after the loan activity being assessed
  </li>
 </ul>
 Also refer to:
 <ul>
  <li>
   <em>
    <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000690">
     Commitments
    </a>
   </em>
  </li>
  <li>
   <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000696">
    Guarantees
   </a>
  </li>
 </ul>
 <h4>
  <a name="R_Default_shared_commitment_rule">
  </a>
  <strong>
   2.4.1 Default shared commitment rule
  </strong>
 </h4>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    Where an
    <b>
     existing
    </b>
    commitment is shared with another borrower ( i.e. &gt;1 borrower on the
    <b>
     existing
    </b>
    commitment ) the ‘Default shared commitment rule’ requires 100% of that commitment amount and it’s
    <a data-tagid="R_Serviceability_Repayment_Amount" href="#R_Serviceability_Repayment_Amount">
     ‘Serviceability Repayment Amount’
    </a>
    be included in the consumer mortgage
    <u>
     application
    </u>
    (aggregate)
    <u>
     level
    </u>
    serviceability assessment
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <ul>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       e.g. if a new loan / loan increase is in a sole name, but an existing commitment is held in joint / multiple names, the full amount of the existing  commitment and it’s associated
       <a href="#R_Serviceability_Repayment_Amount">
        ‘Serviceability Repayment Amount’
       </a>
       must be applied against the sole borrower.
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
 </ul>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    If serviceability fails due to the ‘Default shared commitment rule’, the application may be considered using the following options:
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <ul>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       <a data-tagid="2.4.1 • Apportioned household expenses and shared commitments - Spousal same household" href="#2.4.1 • Apportioned household expenses and shared commitments - Spousal same household">
        Apportioned household expenses and shared commitments - Spousal same household
       </a>
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       <a data-tagid="R_Apportioned_shared_commitment_rule" href="#R_Apportioned_shared_commitment_rule">
        Apportioned shared commitment rule
       </a>
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
 </ul>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    <b>
     <span>
      <span>
       <a id="2.5 Apportioned household expenses and shared commitments and Apportioned shared commitments" name="2.5 Apportioned household expenses and shared commitments and Apportioned shared commitments">
        2.5 Apportioned household expenses and shared commitments and Apportioned shared commitments
       </a>
      </span>
     </span>
    </b>
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <h4>
  <strong>
   <a id="2.4.1 • Apportioned household expenses and shared commitments - Spousal same household" name="2.4.1 • Apportioned household expenses and shared commitments - Spousal same household">
    2.5.1 Apportioned household expenses and shared commitments - Spousal same household
   </a>
  </strong>
 </h4>
 <table>
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Definition
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        This policy option allows the borrower’s serviceability to be assessed using their
        <a data-tagid="Apportioning the household living expense or commitment " href="#Apportioning the household living expense or commitment ">
         apportioned share
        </a>
        of:
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         household living expenses (both HEM comparable and non – HEM comparable expenses), and
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         repayments for any
         <b>
          existing
         </b>
         shared commitments (i.e. debts / liabilities)
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Eligibility
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           The borrower’s spouse must not be a borrower or income reliant guarantor on the consumer mortgage application being assessed,
           <strong>
            <span>
             and
            </span>
           </strong>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           The borrower and the borrower’s spouse must
           <strong>
            <span>
             live at the same address,
            </span>
           </strong>
           <strong>
            <span>
             and
            </span>
           </strong>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           The
           <b>
            only
           </b>
           borrowers on any
           <strong>
            <span>
             existing
            </span>
           </strong>
           shared commitments must be the borrower and the borrower’s spouse
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        This policy option is not available when:
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           the application is processed outside of OBP, or
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           the
           <b>
            existing
           </b>
           commitment or
           <b>
            proposed
           </b>
           consumer mortgage application being assessed has a company co-borrower, or
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           borrowers on the
           <b>
            existing
           </b>
           shared commitment are not spouse only or do not fit the banks definition of a household
           <span>
            ,
           </span>
           <span>
            or
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           either borrower of the
           <b>
            existing
           </b>
           commitment or proposed consumer mortgage application being assessed earns foreign income
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Where the borrower is not eligible for this policy, they may meet the requirements for the
        <a href="#R_Apportioned_shared_commitment_rule">
         Apportioned shared commitments rule
        </a>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <a id="Apportioning the household living expense or commitment " name="Apportioning the household living expense or commitment ">
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         Apportioning the household living expense or commitment
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </a>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        The portion of the expense or commitment repayment used in the serviceability assessment is based on the
        <a data-tagid="Evidencing the borrower’s contribution to the total household income " href="#Evidencing the borrower’s contribution to the total household income ">
         borrower’s contribution to the total household income.
        </a>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        i.e. calculating the borrower’s income as a percentage of the total household income (i.e. borrower + spouse income), and applying that same percentage to the shared household living expenses and commitments.
        <br/>
        <br/>
        When OBP is the assessment tool, the apportioned household expenses and shared commitments calculations will be automatically completed (including HEM value).
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Lenders / assessors do not need to manually adjust the borrower’s percentage ownership or amount of an expense or a commitment.
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <a id="Evidencing the borrower’s contribution to the total household income " name="Evidencing the borrower’s contribution to the total household income ">
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         Evidencing the borrower’s contribution to the total household income
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </a>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         The borrower’s contribution to household income must be evidenced by verifying both the borrower and non-borrower’s (borrower’s spouse) income.
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          The non-borrower (borrower's spouse) must be verified using the following income verification method:
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
       <ul>
        <li>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             PAYG must be verified using standard income verification policy. Refer to
             <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000721">
              Verifying Income
             </a>
             policy.
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             Self Employed non-borrower must be verified using Fast Track self-employed assessment. The full Fast Track policy including ‘Eligibility’ and ‘Exclusion’ criteria applies. Refer to
             <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000708">
              Self Employed Applicants
             </a>
             policy.
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
       </ul>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        DTI
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          The
          <b>
           entire
          </b>
          commitment value (higher of balance/limit)  is used in the DTI calculation (not the apportioned value)
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <a>
         HEM
        </a>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <strong>
         <span>
          The HEM band calculation is determined on total household income and does not change when using the apportioned household expense policy.
         </span>
        </strong>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Verification
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        The broker must:
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Comply with
       <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000690">
        Commitments
       </a>
       policy
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          Sight the non-borrower spouse privacy and consent, identification, and income verification documents AND:
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           upload documentation (to OBP) confirming :
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <ol>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           The borrower’s spouse resides at the same address as the borrower;
           <strong>
            <span>
             and
            </span>
           </strong>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           The name of the borrower’s spouse matches the employee’s name on the income documents used to verify the borrower’s spouse income, including the ATO notice of assessment where the borrower’s spouse is self-employed.
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ol>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>

        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000711">
