 <h4>
  <a name="R_Apportioned_shared_commitment_rule">
  </a>
  <strong>
   2.5.2 Apportioned shared commitment rule
  </strong>
 </h4>
 <h4>
 </h4>
 <table>
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Definition
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        This policy option:
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          can be used when serviceability fails based on the
          <a href="#R_Default_shared_commitment_rule">
           ‘Default shared commitment rule’
          </a>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          allows the borrower’s or income reliant guarantor’s  serviceability to be assessed using their apportioned share of repayments for an
          <b>
           existing
          </b>
          shared commitment (i.e. debts / liabilities)
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Eligibility
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           The borrower(s) or income guarantor(s) (WBC only) share an existing commitment with another borrower
           <b>
            who is not
           </b>
           :
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             <span>
              The spouse of the borrower and not a co-borrower on the new loan or loan variation being assessed,
              <b>
               or
              </b>
             </span>
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             <span>
              An income guarantor (WBC only) on the new loan or loan variation being assessed
             </span>
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           Apportioned shared commitment rule is
           <strong>
            <span>
             not
            </span>
           </strong>
           available when:
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         the application is processed outside of OBP
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             <span>
              The new loan or shared commitment has a company co-borrower
             </span>
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             <span>
              Foreign income is used in the serviceability assessment
             </span>
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             <span>
              Any co-borrower / income guarantor (WBC only) of the shared commitment resides outside of Australia
             </span>
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             <span>
              The existing commitment is shared between spouses only:
             </span>
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
       <ul>
        <li>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             <span>
              <span>
               <span>
                If the borrower and non-borrower spouse reside at the same address, refer to
                <a data-tagid="2.4.1 • Apportioned household expenses and shared commitments - Spousal same household" href="#2.4.1 • Apportioned household expenses and shared commitments - Spousal same household" target="_self">
                 <span>
                  Apportioned household expenses and shared commitments – Spousal same household policy
                 </span>
                </a>
               </span>
              </span>
             </span>
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             <span>
              <span>
               <span>
                If the borrower and non-borrower spouse reside at different addresses, the borrower has to take on the full responsibility for both their own as well as the spouse’s portion of the debt.
               </span>
              </span>
             </span>
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
       </ul>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td rowspan="5" valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Calculation
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        The applicant’s apportioned share of the commitment used in serviceability assessment is based on the highest of the below categories
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <b>
         Category
        </b>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Description
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        A. Repayment percentage
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        The percentage of the total minimum required loan repayment that the borrower(s) or income guarantor(s)
        <u>
         plus
        </u>
        their spouse (if their spouse is not a party on the new consumer mortgage application  or loan variation being assessed) are liable.
        <br/>
        <br/>
        This is a customer declared percentage.
        <br/>
        <br/>
        E.g. Existing borrowers = Borrower 'A' + Borrower 'A' Spouse (who is not a party on the new consumer mortgage application  or loan variation being assessed) +  Other borrower who is not a party on the new consumer mortgage application  or loan variation being assessed.
        <br/>
        <br/>
        The declared repayment percentage for Borrower 'A'
        <u>
         plus
        </u>
        their spouse was 50%.
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <strong>
         <span>
          Note:
         </span>
        </strong>
        the declared percentage is below the borrower percentage in this scenario.
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        B. Borrower Percentage
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        The borrower(s) or income guarantor (
        <u>
         plus
        </u>
        their spouse (if their spouse is not a party on the new consumer mortgage application or loan variation being assessed) as a percentage of total borrowers.
        <br/>
        <br/>
        E.g. Existing borrowers = Borrower 'A' + Borrower 'A' Spouse (who is not a party on the new consumer mortgage application  or loan variation being assessed) + Other borrower who is not a party on the new consumer mortgage application  or loan variation being assessed.
        <br/>
        <br/>
        Borrower 'A'
        <u>
         plus
        </u>
        their spouse represent
        <u>
         66.66%
        </u>
        of total borrowers (This percentage is based on the equal distribution of the commitment amongst all borrowers on the existing commitment)
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        C. Asset ownership percentage
        <br/>
        <br/>
        (Only applies where an asset secures the existing facility)
        <br/>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        The borrower(s) or income guarantor(s)
        <u>
         plus
        </u>
        their spouse’s ownership of any assets securing the existing  commitment
        <br/>
        <br/>
        This is a customer declared percentage
        <br/>
        <br/>
        E.g. Existing borrowers = Borrower 'A' owns 20% + Borrower 'A' Spouse owns 60% (if their spouse is not a party on the new consumer mortgage application  or loan variation being assessed) +  Other borrower who is not a party on the new consumer mortgage application  or loan variation being assessed owns the remaining 20%.
        <br/>
        <br/>
        Borrower 'A'
        <u>
         plus
        </u>
        their spouse own
        <u>
         80
        </u>
        % of the asset securing the existing facility
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <strong>
         <span>
          Note
         </span>
        </strong>
        : in this scenario the asset ownership percentage is higher than the repayment percentage and the borrower percentage.
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <br/>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Example
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Using the examples above, if:
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           100% of the associated
           <a href="#R_Serviceability_Repayment_Amount">
            ‘Serviceability Repayment Amount’
           </a>
           under the ‘
           <a href="#R_Default_shared_commitment_rule">
            Default shared commitment rule’
           </a>
           is $3,000, then
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        the associated
        <a href="#R_Serviceability_Repayment_Amount">
         ‘Serviceability Repayment Amount’
        </a>
        if using the ‘
        <a href="#R_Apportioned_shared_commitment_rule">
         Apportioned shared commitment rule’
        </a>
        , would be $2,400 using C. Assets ownership percentage of 80%, as this is the highest percentage in the above examples.
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        DTI
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          The
          <b>
           entire
          </b>
          commitment value (higher of balance/limit)  is used in the DTI calculation (not the apportioned value)
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     Verification
    </td>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     The broker must:
     <ul>
      <li>
       Comply with
       <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000690">
        Commitments
       </a>
       policy
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Related
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000710">
         Serviceability Assessment
        </a>
        policy
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        The commitment type must allow an apportioned serviceability repayment amount. To identify if the commitment is eligible to be apportioned, refer to following sections in this chapter:
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             <span>
              <a data-tagid="R_Serviceability_Repayment_Amount" href="#R_Serviceability_Repayment_Amount" target="_self">
               <span>
                Serviceability repayment amount
               </span>
              </a>
             </span>
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             <span>
              <a data-tagid="R_Benchmark_Repayment_Amount_-_Mortgage" href="#R_Benchmark_Repayment_Amount_-_Mortgage" target="_self">
               <span>
                Benchmark repayment amount – Mortgage
               </span>
              </a>
             </span>
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
       <ul>
        <li>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             <span>
              <span>
               <span>
                <span>
                 Benchmark repayment amount calculation – New and existing internal mortgage
                </span>
               </span>
              </span>
             </span>
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             <span>
              <span>
               <span>
                <span>
                 Benchmark repayment amount calculation – External existing mortgage
                </span>
               </span>
              </span>
             </span>
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
       </ul>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
  </tbody>
 </table>

 <h4>
  <strong>
   <a name="R_Serviceability_Repayment_Amount">
   </a>
   2.5.3 Serviceability Repayment Amount
  </strong>
 </h4>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    The
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <i>
  <span>
   <span>
    <span>
     Serviceability Repayment Amount
    </span>
   </span>
  </span>
 </i>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    is the repayment amount which is ultimately used within the serviceability assessment. The repayment amount is determined by the type of liability and can be either:
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <ul>
  <li>
   <em>
    Benchmark Repayment Amount -
   </em>
   refers to repayment value which has been calculated by the Bank for serviceability purposes only
  </li>
  <li>
   <em>
    Customer Declared Contracted Repayment Amount -
   </em>
   refers to the contracted repayment amount for the commitment as declared by the customer
  </li>
  <li>
   The higher of the commitment
   <strong>
    current
   </strong>
   balance or limit is used in the
   <em>
    Benchmark Repayment Amount
   </em>
   calculation, except where the below apply:
   <ul>
    <li>
     <a href="#R_Commitment_being_refinanced_using_loan">
      <em>
       Commitment being refinanced using loan funds
      </em>
     </a>
    </li>
    <li>
     <a href="#R_Amended_current_commitment">
      <em>
       Amended current commitment
      </em>
     </a>
    </li>
   </ul>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      Loans originated concurrently, or existing loans with a concurrent loan activity, it is important that the correct repayment is assigned to the associated liability in each application
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
 </ul>

      </li>

     <span>
      <strong>
       <span>
        <span>
         A ‘standard’ payment plan arrangement
        </span>
       </span>

      </span>
     </span>
     <ol>

      </li>
      <li>
       remaining (excluding the final) payments of consistent frequency and amount e.g. $198.83 per fortnight
      </li>
      <li>
       a final payment which is the lowest payment and sees the debt repaid in full, e.g. $180.29
      </li>
     </ol>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>

       </span>

       <span>

        <br/>

     <ol>

          </span>

This can be entered against the borrower as:
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>

              </span>

            </span>
           </span>
          </span>

              </span>
             </span>
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>

      </li>

     <span>
      <a>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          Where
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </a>
      <a data-tagid="2.4.1 Apportioned household expenses and shared commitments - Spousal same household" href="#2.4.1 Apportioned household expenses and shared commitments - Spousal same household" target="_self">

         </span>
        </span>

        <span>
         policy has been applied, t
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <span>
      <span>

      </span>

      <b>
      </b>
     </span>
     <ol start="3">
      <li>

         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             The borrower and their spouse rent a property and are applying for a new loan in joint names. The total contracted rent may be loaded in full against either borrower, or split between both borrowers, providing the total contracted rental outgo is entered and the combined expense ownership reflects 100%.
             <a data-tagid="2.4.1 Apportioned household expenses and shared commitments - Spousal same household" href="#2.4.1 Apportioned household expenses and shared commitments - Spousal same household">
              Apportioned household expense and shared commitments - Spousal same household
             </a>

It is acceptable to enter the borrower’s share of the total contracted rent based on the number of tenants on the lease, e.g. 3 tenants on the lease, then the borrower’s share of the rent is 33%. This can be entered as:

          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
       <ul>

An amount or expense ownership percentage equivalent to 50% of the total contracted rental outgo must be entered against each borrower, i.e. this can be entered as:

              </span>

            </span>
           </li>

               </span>
              </span>
             </span>
            </span>

 <h3>
  <a name="R_Household_Expenditure_Measure_(HEM)">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      2.8 Household Expenditure Measure (HEM)
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h3>
 <table>
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <h3>
      <span>
       <span>
        Definition
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        The HEM, developed by the Melbourne Institute, represents a broad based estimated level of absolute basic and discretionary expenditure for modern Australian households and is produced Quarterly.
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        The HEM is applied by the loan origination system and other serviceability assessment tools
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <br/>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <h3>
      <span>
       <span>
        Used for
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            It is an index used by the Bank to set the minimum surplus rule for serviceability.
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        May be used for the allocation of living expenses within an application —see
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <a href="#R_Monthly_Household_Expenditure_Measure_">
         <em>
          <span>
           Monthly Household Expenditure Measure Table
          </span>
         </em>
        </a>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <h3>
      <span>
       <span>
        Categorised according to
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         Borrower income band
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         Geographical location of the  borrower’s place of residence (including overseas residence)
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         Marital status
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         Number of dependants
         <em>
          <span>
           (refer to
          </span>
         </em>
        </span>
       </span>
       <span>
        <span>
         <em>
          <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000700">
           Living Expenses
          </a>
         </em>
        </span>
       </span>
       <span>
        <span>
         <em>
          <span>
           <a>
           </a>
          </span>
         </em>
         <em>
          <span>
           policy)
          </span>
         </em>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <h3>
      <span>
       <span>
        Rules
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         The geographical location is based on the  borrower’s residential postcode post loan settlement - see
        </span>
       </span>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <a href="#2.8.4 Monthly Household Expenditure Measure - Geographic Location">
           <em>
            <span>
             Monthly Household Expenditure Measure - Geographic location
            </span>
           </em>
          </a>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
       <span>
        <span>
         <a href="#R_Monthly_Household_Expenditure_Measure">
          .
         </a>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          The post settlement postcode is mandatory to calculate HEM. If the application is an In Principal Approval, the post settlement postcode is to be captured as accurately as possible.
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           A
           <span>
            <span>
             pplicant's gross income for the HEM band is calculated based on the total:
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
       <ul>
        <li>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             <span>
              <span>
               Gross annual salary / wages income (unshaded)
               <b>
                <i>
                 plus
                </i>
               </b>
              </span>
             </span>
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             <span>
              <span>
               Gross annual rental income (unshaded)
               <b>
                <i>
                 less
                </i>
               </b>
               the
               <b>
                <i>
                </i>
               </b>
               higher of
               <b>
                <i>
                </i>
               </b>
               (customer declared investment property costs or 10% of gross unshaded rental income)
               <b>
                <i>
                 less
                </i>
               </b>
               investment loan interest costs (where negative gearing has been used)
               <b>
                <i>
                 plus
                </i>
               </b>
              </span>
             </span>
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             <span>
              <span>
               All other gross annual income (unshaded)
              </span>
             </span>
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
       </ul>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <h3>
      <span>
       <span>
        Household definition
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Refer to
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000723">
         Glossary
        </a>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>

 </table>
 <h3>
 </h3>
 <h4>
  <a name="R_Monthly_Household_Expenditure_Measure_">
   <strong>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       2.8.1 Monthly Household Expenditure Measure - Table
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </strong>
  </a>
 </h4>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    Minimum surplus requirements are set out below based on HEM Quarter information shown in the HEM Tables. Source: Melbourne Institute.
    <br/>
    <br/>
    The HEM table includes a split by applicant’s *household income, geographical location, marital status and number of dependants.
    <br/>
    <br/>
    To manually calculate the HEM value:
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <ol>
  <li>
   Calculate
  </li>
 </ol>
 <ul>
  <li>
   <span>
    Gross annual salary / wages income (unshaded)
    <strong>
     <em>
      <span>
       plus
      </span>
     </em>
    </strong>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    Gross annual rental income (unshaded)
    <strong>
     <em>
      <span>
       less
      </span>
     </em>
    </strong>
   </span>
   investment property operating costs/expenses
   <strong>
    <em>
     <span>
      less
     </span>
    </em>
   </strong>
   investment loan interest costs (where negative gearing has been used)
   <strong>
    <em>
     <span>
      plus
     </span>
    </em>
   </strong>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    all other gross annual income (unshaded)
   </span>
  </li>
 </ul>
 <ol>
  <li value="2">
   Determine if applicants post settlement postcode is classified as ‘HEM Remote postcode’ or not
  </li>
  <li>
   To determine the applicable HEM value, go to the Monthly Household Expenditure Measure Table taking into account:
  </li>
 </ol>
 <ul>
  <li>
   <span>
    Income as calculated above at step 1.
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    Geographical location based on the applicant’s post settlement postcode from step 3.
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    Marital status
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    Number of dependants
   </span>
   <span>
    *In the case of ‘Joint with Spouse’ applicants living in the same household, a combined HEM household income is used to determine the HEM band to be used. For other applicant’s, the individual HEM household income is used to determine the applicable HEM band.
   </span>
  </li>
 </ul>
 <br/>
 <span>
  The table below provides details of how the HEM values apply.
  <br/>
 </span>

 <br/>
 <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/ci/okcsFattach/getFile/1000710/03.17%20HEM%20Table.xlsx">
  <em>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      HEM tables
     </span>

 </a>
 <br/>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    For household incomes greater than $614k gross per annum the loan origination system platform will extrapolate the HEM value using the following calculation:
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <ul>
  <li>
   (Household Income amount / Mid-point of top HEM band) x (Top band HEM value – Second Top band HEM value) + Second Top band HEM value).
  </li>
 </ul>
 <h4>
  <a id="2.8.4 Monthly Household Expenditure Measure - Geographic Location" name="2.8.4 Monthly Household Expenditure Measure - Geographic Location">
   <strong>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       2.8.2 Monthly Household Expenditure Measure - Geographic Location
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </strong>
  </a>
 </h4>
 <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/ci/okcsFattach/getFile/1000710/03.17%20HEM%20Remote%20Postcodes.xlsx">
  <em>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      HEM Remote postcode listing
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </em>
 </a>
 <br/>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    Where postcode is listed treat as ‘Remote Location’ in HEM calculation.
    <br/>
    <br/>
    Where postcode is not listed treat as ‘Rest of Australia' in HEM calculation.
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <h4>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      Overseas
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h4>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    Remote Location / Australian average postcode segregation does not apply and all overseas postcodes are treated as ‘Rest of Australia'.
    <br/>
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <h4>
  <a name="R_Customer_declared_living_expenses_–com">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      2.8.3 Customer declared living expenses –compared to HEM
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h4>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    For the purposes of assessing the borrower(s) and (any) income guarantor(s) capacity to repay the Bank, the higher of Household Expenditure Measure (HEM) and Customer Declared '
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    Living Expenses compared to HEM'
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    per household will be used.
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    Refer to
    <a>
     Living Expenses &gt;
    </a>
    <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000700">
     Living Expenses compared to HEM
    </a>
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <h4>
  <br/>
  <br/>
  <a id="2.8.6 Customer declared living expenses are &lt; 70% of HEM" name="2.8.6 Customer declared living expenses are &lt; 70% of HEM">
   2.8.4 Customer declared living expenses are less than 70% of HEM
  </a>
 </h4>
 When the total of the borrower’s declared '
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    Living Expenses compared to HEM'
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 are less than 70% of HEM at application level, brokers / assessors must:
 <ul>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       Discuss the declared level of expenses with the applicant(s) noting that they appear relatively low. (Refer to
       <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000700">
        Living Expenses
       </a>
       &gt; Conflicting information)
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       For all expense categories, undertake any relevant / appropriate scrutiny of account or transactional information, and make further enquiries where any information is identified which conflicts with the customer declared expenses
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
   <ul>
    <li>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         Ensure any expense fields entered as $0 had commentary added to explain why the expense does not apply to the applicants
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </li>
   </ul>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       Record the outcome of these discussions with the applicant(s) in the loan origination system to document the rationale behind why the expenses are low. Refer to Rational examples below.
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        It is not a requirement to obtain further supporting documents to specifically validate this information.
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
 </ul>
 <b>
  Rational
 </b>
 <b>
  examples
 </b>
 <br/>
 <table>
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <h4>
      Satisfactory rationale examples
     </h4>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <h4>
      Unsatisfactory rationale examples
     </h4>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       Customer declared living expenses are &lt; 70% of HEM, customer has confirmed expenses are low due to:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         currently focusing on saving for construction in the future
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         both applicants are working from home with scheduled breaks, they can pick and drop their kids to school which allow them to save from Out of School Hours Care (OSHC) costs
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         living at home with parents and do not pay any other insurances or utilities
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         confirmed with customer that Customer declared expenses are accurate to their everyday spending, review of information held supports conversation
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         Expense check complete
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         Discussed expenses with customer
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         Ok to proceed
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>

 <h4>
  <a name="R_Customer_declared_living_expenses_–__n">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      2.8.5 Customer declared living expenses – not compared to HEM
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h4>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    Refer to
    <a>
     Living Expenses &gt;
    </a>
    <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000700">
     Living Expenses compared to HEM
    </a>
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    Investment property costs - r
   </span>
   efer to
   <em>
    <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000700">
     Living Expenses
    </a>
    not compared to HEM&gt; Expense categories - Investment Property Costs (Including Insurance)
   </em>
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   Where the serviceability assessment includes self-employed income, refer to
  </span>
 </span>
 <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000708">
  <span>
   <span>
    <span>
     Self-employed Applicants
    </span>
   </span>
  </span>
 </a>
 <span>
  <span>
   &gt; Rental income – Fully verified self-employed assessment
   <strong>
    and
   </strong>
   Rental Income – Fast track self-employed assessment
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <br/>
 <a id="2.8.6 Investment Property Expense Floor" name="2.8.6 Investment Property Expense Floor">
  <span>
   <span>
    <span>
     <strong>
      <span>
       <span>
        2.8.6 Investment Property Expense Floor
       </span>
      </span>
     </strong>
    </span>
   </span>
  </span>
 </a>
 <br/>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    An investment property expense floor will be used for serviceability for residential properties that earn long term rental income.
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    The investment property costs used for serviceability will be assessed on the higher of:
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <ul>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      Customer declared investment property costs: OR
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
  <li>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      10% of Gross Rental Income
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </li>
 </ul>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    Investment Property Expense floor does not apply for:
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <ul>
  <li>
   <span>

 <h3>
  <a id="2.9 Bridging / Relocation and Reverse Mortgage Loans" name="2.9 Bridging / Relocation and Reverse Mortgage Loans">
   <strong>
    <span>
     <span>
      <span>
       2.9 Reverse Mortgage Loans
      </span>
     </span>
    </span>
   </strong>
  </a>
 </h3>
 <table>
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Definition
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            A reverse mortgage is designed for people aged over 60 years or older using the equity in the  Owner Occupied property as security, to advance funds.
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            The borrower is not required to make repayments, interest and fees compound and add to the principal amount borrowed. Normally the loan is repaid in full when the borrower (or deceased estate) sells the security.
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Verification
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Applications involving an ongoing (not clearing or excluded) existing Reverse Mortgage loan must be referred to credit for acceptance. Credit manager referral is required to validate:
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           That the repayment used for serviceability (being $0 or Interest Only) is appropriate, taking into consideration:
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
       <ul>
        <li>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             Whether the loan has matured
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             Whether the loan will be maturing in the very near term
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             Whether it is reasonable to extend further borrowing to a customer with an ongoing existing Reverse Mortgage Loan
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
       </ul>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Supporting Information
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Detail explaining why the  borrower is seeking additional borrowings as a standard loan product when they have an existing Reverse Mortgage loan
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Supporting Documentation requirements
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        A copy of the associated loan contract is to be provided
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
  </tbody>
 </table>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>

 <h4>
  <a name="R_Serviceability_Assessment_Rate_(SAR)-M">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      2.10.1 Serviceability Assessment Rate (SAR) - Mortgage
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h4>
 <span>
  <span>
   <span>
    For new and existing consumer mortgage products only, an interest rate buffer and floor rate are considered in the Benchmark Repayment Amount calculation applied to the mortgage commitment, and the interest rate applied is the Serviceability Assessment Rate (SAR).
    <br/>
   </span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="1" width="628">
  <thead>
   <tr>
    <th>
     <h4 align="center">
      <strong>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          Interest Rate
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </strong>
     </h4>
    </th>
    <th>
     <h4 align="center">
      <strong>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          Policy rules
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </strong>
     </h4>
    </th>
   </tr>
  </thead>
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Buffer rate
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        The buffer rate is determined by the Bank; it reflects the potential for interest rate increases and seeks to ensure that potential increases in interest rates do not adversely impact on a borrower’s capacity to repay a loan.
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Effective 29 October 2021 the buffer rate is
        <strong>
         <span>
          3.00%p.a.
         </span>
        </strong>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Floor rate
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        The Bank maintains a minimum floor rate which is used in conjunction with the buffer rate. The floor rate is the lowest benchmark rate that the Bank has set for testing a customer’s ability to repay the loan.
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <strong>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         Note:
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </strong>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        The floor rate is also internally referred to as the 'Minimum Credit Assessment Rate (MCAR)'
        <br/>
        Effective 9 October 2020 the floor rate is
        <strong>
         <span>
          5.05%
         </span>
        </strong>
       </span>
       p.a.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Serviceability Assessment Rate (SAR)
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        The SAR refers to the interest rate which is applied in the Benchmark Repayment Amount calculation.
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       If the final rate on the loan plus the interest rate buffer of 3.00% p.a. is less than the floor rate, then the floor rate is applied as the SAR.
      </li>
      <li>
       If the final rate on the loan plus the interest rate buffer of 3.00% p.a. is greater than the floor rate, then the actual rate on the loan plus the interest rate buffer is applied as the SAR
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2">
     <b>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         Note:
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </b>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        A modified SAR may be applied to applications to refinance an existing mortgage (internal or external), where the application meets all eligibility criteria and conditions under Streamlined Refinance
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
  </tbody>
 </table>
 <span>

    <br/>

     <b>
      or
     </b>
     customer funds prior to drawdown of the new loan (non-refinance).
     <br/>
     <br/>
     For a clearing Bridging loan (ICAP
     <b>
      or
     </b>
     I/O), refer to:
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         Commitment being refinanced using Loan funds &gt; Any liability is being
         <strong>
          <span>
           cleared and closed
          </span>
         </strong>
         using loan funds
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         Excluded mortgaged liability &gt; A mortgage liability is to be
         <strong>
          <span>
           cleared and closed
          </span>
         </strong>
         independently by the customer via the associated property sale,
         <strong>
          <span>
           after
          </span>
         </strong>
         Unconditional Approval but prior to or simultaneous with drawdown / settlement
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            Amended current commitment &gt; Any liability will be
            <strong>
             <span>
              cleared and closed
             </span>
            </strong>
            independently by the customer,
            <strong>
             <span>
              prior
             </span>
            </strong>
            to Unconditional Approval
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>

    <td colspan="7">
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       <strong>
        <span>
         Legend
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       <sup>
        <span>
         1
        </span>
       </sup>
       RAMS mortgages are treated as external
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>

 <h3>
  <a name="R_Parental_leave_–use_of_‘return_to_work">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      2.11 Parental leave – use of ‘return to work’ income
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h3>
 <table>
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         Definition
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         When a borrower or income guarantor is currently on, or about to commence parental leave, we can use their ‘return to work’ income for serviceability, provided the requirements are met.
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <br/>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         Exclusions
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         Any other extended leave like Grandparental Leave or Career Breaks are ineligible as this isn’t covered under Government Legislation like Parental Leave where a person is guaranteed for their job to be held open for 12 months.
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <br/>
    </td>
   </tr>
  </tbody>
 </table>
 <table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="1">
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <h4>
      <strong>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          Condition
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </strong>
     </h4>
    </td>
    <td>
     <h4>
      <strong>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          Requirement
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </strong>
     </h4>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <h3>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         In all cases where ‘return income’ is to be used for serviceability
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        An employer’s letter is held which:
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Meets
       <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000692">
        Document Standards
       </a>
       of ‘Employer’s letter - general use’, and
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          Displays:
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
       <ul>
        <li>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            The return to work date.
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            Conditions under which the employee will return, i.e. Full time or Part time
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            Return to work income as per the
            <strong>
             <span>
              <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/ci/okcsFattach/getFile/1000692/03.08%20MDSM.xls">
               'Document Standards
              </a>
              ’
             </span>
            </strong>
           </span>
           of ‘Employer’s letter-general use’
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
       </ul>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <b>
            Only
           </b>
           ‘Base income’ can be used in the serviceability assessment
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             <span>
              Include all children as dependants in OBP. (Including where the expected child(ren) has / have not yet been born, noting this is a variance to the "Definition of Dependant" rules in the
              <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000700">
               Living Expense
              </a>
              policy).
             </span>
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             <span>
              Any supporting documents provided are required to be retained in the loan application.
             </span>
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Where the loan will be advanced and the first repayment is due
        <strong>
         <span>
          after
         </span>
        </strong>
       </span>
       the return to work date
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <b>
       For Mortgage insured and Non-mortgage insured loans
      </b>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          Use ‘Return to Work’ income i.e. reflecting the gross ‘base’ income amount which will be received once returning to work.
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Where the loan will be advanced and the first repayment is due
        <strong>
         <span>
          before
         </span>
        </strong>
       </span>
       the return to work date
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <b>
       For Mortgage insured loans
      </b>
      :
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           Requests for new or increased loans for purposes of “Investment” are not acceptable.
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           Must be referred to Credit and will be considered on a case-by-case basis,  to a maximum LVR of 90% inclusive of any capped premium.
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <br/>
     <span>
      All other requirements as per below
     </span>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <b>
       For both Mortgage insured and Non-mortgage insured loans:
      </b>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <span>
      The following is required to calculate any servicing shortfall prior to the return to work:
     </span>
     <br/>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           The expected settlement date (mandatory);
           <b>
            and
           </b>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           Any income that is currently,
           <b>
            or
           </b>
           will be received during the parental leave period must be verified to policy, refer
           <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000721">
            Verifying Income
           </a>
           ;
           <b>
            and
           </b>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           The number of weeks that the income will be received during the parental leave period;
           <b>
            and
           </b>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           The ‘Return to Work’ gross ‘base’ income amount that will be received once returning to work and the return-to-work date.
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      Where a servicing shortfall amount is evident, the Broker must:
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           Confirm how the shortfall will be covered whilst during the parental leave period;
           <b>
            and
           </b>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           Verify that sufficient funds are held to cover the shortfall via supporting documents (e.g. bank statement / transaction listing from external provider
           <sup>
            1
           </sup>
           , internal extract or enquiry). The shortfall must be covered in addition to any funds required to fund the application. The supporting documents provided must meet
           <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000692">
            Document Standards
           </a>
           ;
           <b>
            and
           </b>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           Enter comments into ApplyOnline detailing the explanation and the evidence used to confirm how the shortfall will be met, prior to return to work.
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2">
     <strong>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         Legend
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </strong>
     <br/>
     <sup>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         1
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </sup>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        SGB, BoM, BSA and RAMS are considered to be external providers
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <strong>
       <span>
        <span>
         Note:
        </span>
       </span>
      </strong>
     </span>
     <span>
      <span>
       If the applicant is seeking to manage
      </span>
      <strong>
       <span>
        existing home loans
       </span>
      </strong>
     </span>
     <span>
      , Mortgage Repayment Pause Option or switching to Interest Only repayments may better suit the customer’s situation.
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
  </tbody>
 </table>
 <h3>
  <br/>
  <br/>
  <span>
   <span>
    <a name="R_Rental_income_tax_deductions_for_Austr">
    </a>
    <strong>
     <span>
      <span>
       2.12 Rental income tax deductions for Australian investment properties (Negative Gearing)
      </span>
     </span>
    </strong>
   </span>
  </span>
 </h3>
 <table>
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <strong>
         <span>
          Definition
         </span>
        </strong>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td colspan="3">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Generally negative gearing occurs when a rental property’s expenses (including interest) are greater than income earned from the rental property.
        <br/>
        <br/>
        The Australian tax system allows individuals with rental properties that are negatively geared, to deduct the loss against other income (e.g. PAYG income).
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <b>
         Serviceability
        </b>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td colspan="3">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           The use of negative gearing in serviceability is not mandatory
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td rowspan="12" valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <strong>
         <span>
          Eligibility
         </span>
        </strong>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td colspan="3">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Negative gearing can be included in the serviceability assessment under the following conditions:
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <strong>
         <span>
          Feature
         </span>
        </strong>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <strong>
         <span>
          Condition
         </span>
        </strong>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Application type
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Available for both non-mortgage insured and mortgage insured loans
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Employment type
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <a>
            Available for both PAYG and Self Employed applicants
           </a>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Income
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          The applicant’s income must be subject to Australian taxation law, i.e. applicant is ordinarily resident in Australia and
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          Loan serviceability must
          <strong>
           <span>
            not
           </span>
          </strong>
          be assessed using the Self-Employed fast track process unless the rental income commenced after the financial years covered by the ATO NOA. Refer to
          <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000708">
           Self-employed Applicants &gt; Rules you must apply &gt; Fast track self-employed assessment.
          </a>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td rowspan="5">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Applicable to the negatively geared loan:
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <br/>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Interest Rate
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        The actual current interest rate must be used in the negative gearing calculation
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Borrower
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        The deduction can only be applied to an applicant who is a borrower on the loan which is being negatively geared
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Loan purpose
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           The loan must be / have been taken out for the purpose of investing in residential real estate
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           For both an existing mortgage or the new loan, negative gearing benefits can be included when all or part of a loan is for the purpose of investing in the specific rental property negative gearing is being applied to
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Deductible loan amount
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Only the loan portion used for investing in the specific rental property negative gearing is being applied to can be used.
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        The customer must declare the amount of the loan that is eligible or that is already being negatively geared
        <br/>
        <br/>
        The amount of negative gearing used
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           May include:
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
       <ul>
        <li>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             the purchase price of the property
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li>

          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             any associated costs in obtaining the investment property (e.g., stamp duty and legal costs).
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
       </ul>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <u>
            Must be the lower of
           </u>
           the customer declared deductable loan amount
           <b>
            or
           </b>
           the actual loan balance
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Verification
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        As per
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000690">
         Commitments
        </a>
        <a>
         policy
        </a>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Residential property that the negative gearing applies to
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           The percentage of tax deduction for Bank serviceability purposes that an applicant may claim is based on their share of property ownership.
          </span>

        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           The property securing the loan must
           <strong>
            <span>
             not
            </span>
           </strong>
           be vacant land
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           The property must have rental income verified in line with policy and used in the serviceability assessment
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           The property must be owned by an individual (
           <strong>
            <span>
             not
            </span>
           </strong>
           a partnership, company or trust including an individual as trustee for (ATF))
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           When the property is rented on a short term basis, a rental income tax deduction / negative gearing can only be applied in serviceability when the property is already owned and the rental schedule confirms the property was rented / available for rent, for the full 52 weeks of the financial year. Also see
           <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000721">
            Verifying Income
           </a>
           policy &gt; Supplementary Income &gt; Rental income (in AUD) Rent received on a short term basis.
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Rental arrangement
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        The rental income cannot be from a National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS), Specialist Disability Accommodation (SDA) property
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
  </tbody>
 </table>
