 <br/>
 <h2>
  <a name="R_Rules_you_must_apply">
   <strong>
    <span>
     <span>
      2. Rules you must apply
     </span>
    </span>
   </strong>
  </a>
 </h2>
 <h3>
  The below standards are the minimum requirements for income to be verified.
  <br/>
 </h3>
 <h3>
  <a id="2.1 Verifying PAYG Salary or Wage Income" name="2.1 Verifying PAYG Salary or Wage Income">
   <strong>
    2.1 Verifying PAYG Salary or Wage Income
   </strong>
  </a>
 </h3>
 <strong>
 </strong>
 <table width="100%">
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <h3>
      <strong>
       Base Income (AUD)
      </strong>
     </h3>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <a data-tagid="Base Income (AUD) using payslips" href="#Base Income (AUD) using payslips">
        <u>
         Base Income (
        </u>
        <u>
         AUD)
        </u>
        <u>
         using payslips
        </u>
       </a>
      </li>
      <li>
       <a data-tagid="Base Income (AUD) using Direct Salary Credits" href="#Base Income (AUD) using Direct Salary Credits">
        <u>
         Base Income (AUD) using Direct Salary Credits
        </u>
       </a>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <strong>
      Definitions and ‘time in employment’ rules
     </strong>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     Base Income: A regular fixed income from salary or wages
     <b>
      excluding
     </b>
     bonus payments, overtime, allowances, commissions, etc.
     <br/>
     <br/>
     Time in employment:  Refer to
     <a data-tagid="1.6 PAYG Salary or Wage income - Definitions and Time in Employment" href="#1.6 PAYG Salary or Wage income - Definitions and Time in Employment">
      PAYG salary or wage - Definitions and Time in Employment
     </a>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <strong>
      E
     </strong>
     <strong>
      xclusions
     </strong>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     Not applicable to
     <ul>
      <li>
       family employees
      </li>
      <li>
       casual income
      </li>
      <li>
       borrower or income guarantor being assessed under the Emergency Services Employee method
      </li>
      <li>
       borrower or income guarantor receiving PAYG income from own company / business – refer to
       <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000708">
        Self Employed Applicants
       </a>
       policy
      </li>
      <li>
       <strong>
        foreign employment
       </strong>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
  </tbody>
 </table>
 <table width="100%">
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <a id="Base Income (AUD) using payslips" name="Base Income (AUD) using payslips">
      Base Income (AUD) using payslips
     </a>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <b>
      DOCUMENTS
     </b>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <ul>
      <li>
       1 YTD payslip covering last 2 pay cycles
      </li>
     </ul>
     Where this cannot be provided:
     <ul>
      <li>
       Last 2 consecutive payslips (can be YTD or non-YTD).
      </li>
     </ul>
     <br/>
     <b>
      OR
     </b>
     <br/>
     Where the above documents cannot be provided due to:
     <ul>
      <li>
       A recent increase to their base income (i.e. consecutive payslips have different base income amounts or the YTD earnings do not support the annualisation of the new base income),
       <b>
        or
       </b>
      </li>
      <li>
       Having recently commenced new employment*
      </li>
     </ul>
     <b>
      Then:
     </b>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <ul>
        <li>
         1 payslip detailing the new base income (may be a YTD or non-YTD payslip);
         <strong>
          and
         </strong>
        </li>
        <li>
         Employer’s letter / Employer’s email advice / Employment contract – for general use. In addition to meeting the requirements in
         <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000692">
          Document Standards
         </a>
         policy, the document must support the new gross base income / employment as shown on the payslip
        </li>
       </ul>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <strong>
      *Note
     </strong>
     : Any minimum time in employment requirement must be met for mortgage insured loans
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <b>
      ASSESSMENT / INCOME CALCULATION
     </b>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     Annualised base salary from payslip assessed at 100%
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <b>
      ADDITIONAL CONDITIONS
     </b>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     Varying base hourly rate or hours on document
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     Use the lowest:
     <ul>
      <li>
       hourly rate, and
      </li>
      <li>
       number of paid hours excluding unpaid leave
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     Base Income not available on document
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     Verify income using Casual method (casual time in employment rules do not apply where full-time or part-time employed )
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     Salary Sacrifice / Fringe Benefit / Pre-Tax deductions
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     If documents indicate any pre-tax deductions, refer to
     <a data-tagid="PAYG Salary or Wage- Salary Sacrifice / Fringe Benefit deduction / Pre - Tax deductions" href="#PAYG Salary or Wage- Salary Sacrifice / Fringe Benefit deduction / Pre - Tax deductions">
      Salary Sacrifice / Fringe Benefit / Pre-Tax deductions
     </a>
     <br/>
    </td>
   </tr>
  </tbody>
 </table>
 <table width="100%">
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <a id="Base Income (AUD) using Direct Salary Credits" name="Base Income (AUD) using Direct Salary Credits">
      <b>
       Base Income (AUD) using Direct Salary Credits
      </b>
     </a>
     <br/>
     <b>
     </b>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <b>
      DOCUMENTS
     </b>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <ul>
      <li>
       Any of the below covering the latest 3 months:
       <ul>
        <li>
         Westpac Group or Other Financial Institution (OFI):
         <ul>
          <li>
           Account statement;
           <b>
            or
           </b>
          </li>
          <li>
           Account Summary / Extract / Overview;
           <b>
            or
           </b>
          </li>
          <li>
           Account Transaction listing
           <br/>
          </li>
         </ul>
        </li>
       </ul>
      </li>
      <li>
       The salary credit description must specify the employer name,
       <b>
        and
       </b>
      </li>
      <li>
       Salary credit
       <b>
        can
       </b>
       be split between Westpac Group Brands or multiple other financial institutions,
       <b>
        and
       </b>
      </li>
      <li>
       The most recent salary credit must not exceed minimum age of document requirements as per
       <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000692">
        Document Standards
       </a>
       policy
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <b>
      ASSESSMENT / INCOME CALCUALTION
     </b>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     Annualised base salary from lowest salary credit - assessed at 100%
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <b>
      ADDITIONAL CONDITIONS
     </b>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     Eligibility
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     This method
     <b>
      cannot
     </b>
     be used if salary credit includes:
     <ul>
      <li>
       non-base income;
       <b>
        or
       </b>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <ul>
      <li>
       bonus income
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     Income Frequency
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <ul>
      <li>
       The supporting document must confirm the frequency and cycle of salary credits align with the customer declared information
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     Salary Credit Variance
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <ul>
      <li>
       If there is a variance between salary credits, the lowest salary credit must be used for serviceability assessment. The maximum variances allowed is:
       <ul>
        <li>
         1 variance where the pay cycle is monthly
        </li>
        <li>
         2 variances where the pay cycle is fortnightly
        </li>
        <li>
         4 variances where the pay cycle is weekly
        </li>
       </ul>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <br/>
     If above is not met, assess as per ‘
     <a data-tagid="Base Income (AUD) using payslips" href="#Base Income (AUD) using payslips">
      Base Income using payslips
     </a>
     ’
    </td>
   </tr>
  </tbody>
 </table>
 <b>
 </b>
 <h4>
  <strong>
  </strong>
 </h4>
 <table width="100%">
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <h3>
      <a id="Base plus Non- Base Income (AUD)" name="Base plus Non- Base Income (AUD)">
       <strong>
        Base plus Non- Base Income (AUD)
       </strong>
      </a>
     </h3>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <a data-tagid="Base Plus Non-base income (AUD) - Standard" href="#Base Plus Non-base income (AUD) - Standard">
        <u>
         Base plus non-base income
        </u>
        <u>
         (AUD)
        </u>
        <u>
         – Standard
        </u>
       </a>
      </li>
      <li>
       <a data-tagid="Base Plus Non-base income (AUD) - Non-Standard ‘Base income increase’" href="#Base Plus Non-base income (AUD) - Non-Standard ‘Base income increase’">
        <u>
         Base plus non-base income
        </u>
        <u>
         (AUD)
        </u>
        <u>
         – Non-standard ‘Base income increase’
        </u>
       </a>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <strong>
      Definitions and ‘time in employment’ rules
     </strong>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     Non-base income:
     <ul>
      <li>
       forms part of the total remuneration
       <b>
        in addition to
       </b>
       the base salary or wages.
      </li>
      <li>
       can vary in consistency and frequency of payment to base salary or wages
      </li>
      <li>
       Includes:
       <ul>
        <li>
         Car allowances
        </li>
        <li>
         Director fees (other than from own company)
        </li>
        <li>
         Commissions
        </li>
        <li>
         Overtime
        </li>
        <li>
         Shift allowances
        </li>
        <li>
         Specific industry payment (all allowances)
        </li>
       </ul>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <br/>
     Time in employment: Refer to
     <a data-tagid="1.6 PAYG Salary or Wage income - Definitions and Time in Employment" href="#1.6 PAYG Salary or Wage income - Definitions and Time in Employment">
      PAYG salary or wage - Definitions and Time in Employment
     </a>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <strong>
      E
     </strong>
     <strong>
      xclusions
     </strong>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     Not applicable to
     <ul>
      <li>
       family employees
      </li>
      <li>
       casual income
      </li>
      <li>
       borrower or income guarantor being assessed under the
       <a data-tagid="Emergency Services Employee (AUD)" href="#Emergency Services Employee (AUD)">
        Emergency Services Employee
       </a>
       method
      </li>
      <li>
       borrower or income guarantor receiving PAYG income from own company / business – refer to
       <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000708">
        Self Employed Applicants
       </a>
       policy
      </li>
      <li>
       <strong>
        foreign employment
       </strong>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
  </tbody>
 </table>
 <strong>
 </strong>
 <table width="100%">
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <a id="Base Plus Non-base income (AUD) - Standard" name="Base Plus Non-base income (AUD) - Standard">
      <b>
       Base Plus Non-base income (AUD) - Standard
      </b>
     </a>
     <br/>
     <b>
     </b>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <b>
      DOCUMENTS
     </b>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     YTD Payslip – covers
     <br/>
     a minimum of 3 months
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <ul>
      <li>
       1 YTD payslip covering a minimum of 3 months and detailing base income (non-base income is evidenced by the YTD figure)
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     YTD Payslip – covers less than 3 months
     <br/>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <b>
      <u>
       Where YTD payslip covers 2 pay cycles
      </u>
     </b>
     <ul>
      <li>
       1 YTD payslip from
       <b>
        current
       </b>
       financial year detailing base income, covering last 2 pay cycles. Non-base income is evidenced by the YTD figure,
      </li>
     </ul>
     <b>
      and
     </b>
     <ul>
      <li>
       One of the following documents from immediately
       <b>
        previous
       </b>
       financial year and from the same employer as listed on above payslip:
       <ul>
        <li>
         Final YTD payslip from immediately previous financial year and from the same employer as detailed on the payslip, or
        </li>
        <li>
         Latest tax ready ATO Income Statement;
         <b>
          or
         </b>
        </li>
        <li>
         Latest PAYG payment summary;
         <b>
          or
         </b>
        </li>
        <li>
         Latest Australian tax return
         <b>
          and
         </b>
         Australian Taxation Office Notice of Assessment;
         <b>
          or
         </b>
        </li>
        <li>
         ATO Pre-filling report from an authorised tax agent. It is not mandatory to hold all pages of the document, but the pages held must display the ‘Taxpayer details’ and ‘PAYG Payment summaries’
        </li>
       </ul>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <b>
     </b>
     <br/>
     <b>
      <u>
       Where YTD payslip covers 1 pay cycle
      </u>
     </b>
     <br/>
     <ul>
      <li>
       1 YTD payslip from current financial year detailing base income, covering 1 pay cycle,
      </li>
     </ul>
     <b>
      and
     </b>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Final YTD payslip from immediately previous financial year and from the same employer as listed on the above payslip
      </li>
     </ul>
     <br/>
     <b>
      Where combined documents do not cover a minimum of 3 months, assess as per base income
     </b>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     Non-YTD Payslip
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <br/>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <b>
      <u>
       Where ATO YTD statement covering 3 months can be provided
      </u>
     </b>
     <br/>
     <ul>
      <li>
       1 non-YTD payslip detailing base and non-base income,
      </li>
     </ul>
     <strong>
      and
     </strong>
     <ul>
      <li>
       ATO YTD income statement covering both a minimum of 3 months and
       <strong>
        the same pay
       </strong>
       period (pay date) as the non-YTD payslip. Non-base income is evidenced by the ATO YTD figure
      </li>
     </ul>
     <b>
     </b>
     <br/>
     <b>
      <u>
       Where ATO YTD statement can be provided covering less than 3
      </u>
     </b>
     <b>
      <u>
      </u>
     </b>
     <b>
      <u>
       months
      </u>
     </b>
     <br/>
     <b>
     </b>
     <ul>
      <li>
       1 non-YTD payslip from
       <b>
        current
       </b>
       financial year detailing base income,
       <b>
        and
       </b>
      </li>
      <li>
       ATO YTD Income statement covering both the last 2 pay cycles and the same pay period (pay date) as the non-YTD payslip. Non-base income is evidenced by the ATO YTD figure
      </li>
     </ul>
     <strong>
     </strong>
     <br/>
     <strong>
      AND
     </strong>
     <ul>
      <li>
       One of the following documents from
       <b>
        previous
       </b>
       financial year and from the same employer as listed on the above payslip:
       <ul>
        <li>
         Latest tax ready ATO Income Statement,
         <b>
          or
         </b>
        </li>
        <li>
         Latest PAYG payment summary;
         <b>
          or
         </b>
        </li>
        <li>
         Latest Australian tax return and Australian Taxation Office Notice of Assessment;
         <b>
          or
         </b>
        </li>
        <li>
         ATO Pre-filling report from an authorised tax agent. It is not mandatory to hold all pages of the document, but the pages held must display the 'Taxpayer details' and 'PAYG Payment summaries'
        </li>
       </ul>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <b>
      Where ATO YTD statement cannot be provided
     </b>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Last 2 consecutive non-YTD payslips from
       <b>
        current
       </b>
       financial year detailing base and non-base income,
       <b>
        or
       </b>
      </li>
      <li>
       For pay cycles from 1 July to 30 Sept only (due to new financial year):
       <ul>
        <li>
         most recently issued payslip from current financial year
         <b>
          and
         </b>
        </li>
        <li>
         the final payslip from the immediately
         <b>
          previous
         </b>
         financial year

      </li>

      </li>
      <li>
       <b>
        &lt; prior year total gross income, then non-base income (including bonus) is the lower of:

        </li>
        <li>

 <table width="100%">
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <a id="Dependent Contractor (AUD)" name="Dependent Contractor (AUD)">
      <b>
       Dependent Contractor (AUD)
      </b>
     </a>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <b>
      Definitions and ‘Time in Employment’ rules
     </b>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <u>
      Dependant Contractor:
     </u>
     <br/>
     Persons employed on a commercial contract but with work arrangements consistent with them being an employee will be classified as a dependant contractor.
     <br/>
     <br/>
     For policy assessment purposes all Dependant Contractors:
     <ul>
      <li>
       Have a regular number of contracted hours either working full time or part time
      </li>
      <li>
       Have access to annual leave and sick leave*
      </li>
      <li>
       May not subcontract the work out to another party
      </li>
      <li>
       Have all income taxes, deductions and superannuation paid by the employer
      </li>
      <li>
       Do not take any commercial risk i.e. the employer is legally responsible for the work done
      </li>
      <li>
       Do not direct how the work is done i.e. the employer has the right to direct how the work is completed
      </li>
     </ul>
     <sup>
     </sup>
     <br/>
     <u>
      Time in employment
     </u>
     :  Refer to
     <a data-tagid="1.6 PAYG Salary or Wage income - Definitions and Time in Employment" href="#1.6 PAYG Salary or Wage income - Definitions and Time in Employment">
      PAYG salary or wage - Definitions and Time in Employment
     </a>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <b>
      DOCUMENTS
     </b>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <ul>
      <li>
       <b>
        If the contractor:
       </b>
       <ul>
        <li>
         <b>
          Has
         </b>
         access to annual leave and sick leave, assess as per:
         <ul>
          <li>
           <a data-tagid="Base Income (AUD) using payslips" href="#Base Income (AUD) using payslips">
            Base Income
           </a>
           ,
           <b>
            or
           </b>
          </li>
          <li>
           <a data-tagid="Base plus Non- Base Income (AUD)" href="#Base plus Non- Base Income (AUD)">
            Base plus non-base income (standard or non-standard method)
           </a>
           ,
           <b>
            or
           </b>
          </li>
          <li>
           <a data-tagid="Bonus Income (AUD)" href="#Bonus Income (AUD)">
            Bonus Income (AUD)
           </a>
          </li>
         </ul>
        </li>
        <li>
         <b>
          Does not
         </b>
         have access to annual leave and sick leave, assess as per:
         <ul>
          <li>
           <a data-tagid="Casual Income (AUD)" href="#Casual Income (AUD)">
            Casual Income (AUD)
           </a>
          </li>
         </ul>
        </li>
       </ul>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <b>
      AND
     </b>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Employment contract;
       <b>
        or
       </b>
      </li>
      <li>
       Employer's email;
       <b>
        or
       </b>
      </li>
      <li>
       Employer's letter
      </li>
     </ul>
     Document must confirm contract term, contract expiry date and if the contract includes annual leave and sick leave entitlements.
    </td>
   </tr>

     </b>
    </td>

       </a>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>

   <tr>

   <tr>
    <td colspan="3" valign="top">
     <a id="Emergency Services Employee (AUD)" name="Emergency Services Employee (AUD)">
      <b>
       Emergency Services Employee (AUD)
      </b>
     </a>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     Optional (Brokers can choose to process under an alternate PAYG Salary or Wage method)
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <b>
      Definitions and ‘Time in Employment’ rules
     </b>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <u>
      Emergency Services Employee:
     </u>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     A person employed as a:
     <ul>
      <li>
       Front-line Fire Officer and / or front-line Fire Fighter;
      </li>
      <li>
       Front-line Police Officer;
      </li>
      <li>
       Front-line Ambulance Officer and / or front-line Paramedic;
      </li>
      <li>
       Hospital employed medical staff limited to:
       <ul>
        <li>
         Nurse
        </li>
        <li>
         Doctor
        </li>
        <li>
         Surgeon
        </li>
        <li>
         Specialist
        </li>
       </ul>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <br/>
     <strong>
      Excludes:
     </strong>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <a data-tagid="Casual Income (AUD)" href="#Casual Income (AUD)">
        Casual
       </a>
      </li>
      <li>
       <a data-tagid="Dependent Contractor (AUD)" href="#Dependent Contractor (AUD)">
        Dependant contractor
       </a>
      </li>
      <li>
       Temporary
      </li>
      <li>
       Self-employed
      </li>
      <li>
       Office based emergency services staff
      </li>
      <li>
       non-hospital based employment positions (e.g. nurses / doctors)
      </li>
     </ul>
     <u>
     </u>
     <br/>
     <u>
      Time in employment
     </u>
     :  Refer to
     <a data-tagid="1.6 PAYG Salary or Wage income - Definitions and Time in Employment" href="#1.6 PAYG Salary or Wage income - Definitions and Time in Employment">
      PAYG salary or wage - Definitions and Time in Employment

     <a data-tagid="1.6 PAYG Salary or Wage income - Definitions and Time in Employment" href="#1.6 PAYG Salary or Wage income - Definitions and Time in Employment">

    </td>

   <tr>

       <b>
        current
       </b>
       financial year covering last 2 pay cycles
      </li>
     </ul>
     <br/>
     <b>
      AND
     </b>
     one of the following  from immediately
     <b>
      previous
     </b>
     financial year and same employer:

       </b>

     </b>
     one of the following from immediately
     <b>
      previous
     </b>

       </b>

      </li>

    </td>

     <ul>
      <li>

       <b>
        and
       </b>
      </li>
      <li>
       annual previous financial year income
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>

      <u>
       Family employee - Non-spousal family member of the business owner
      </u>
     </strong>
     <br/>

     <br/>
     <strong>
     </strong>
     <br/>
     <strong>
      <u>
       Family employee - Spouse of business owner
      </u>
     </strong>
     <br/>
     Borrower or income guarantor has PAYG income from a business wholly or partially owned by their spouse. Borrower or income guarantor is not an owner of the business.
     <br/>
     <strong>
     </strong>
     <br/>
     <strong>
      <u>
       In all cases
      </u>
     </strong>
     <br/>
     An
     <b>
      owner
     </b>
     of the business must be assessed as self-employed. Refer to
     <a data-tagid="2.4 Verifying Self-employed Income" href="#2.4 Verifying Self-employed Income" target="_self">
      Self-employed
     </a>
     .
     <br/>
     <b>
     </b>

     </b>

 <table width="100%">
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="3" valign="top">
     <a id="Stipend Income (AUD)" name="Stipend Income (AUD)">
      <b>
       Stipend Income (AUD)
      </b>
     </a>
     <br/>
     <b>
     </b>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <b>
      Definitions
     </b>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <strong>
      <u>
       Stipend:
      </u>
     </strong>
     <br/>
     A fixed, regular payment in recognition of services rendered, usually paid at a lower rate than a salaried
     <br/>
     <br/>
     The income is usually paid to cover a specific cost e.g. payments for food, housing, phone, or motor vehicle costs
     <br/>
     <b>
     </b>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="3" valign="top">
     <b>
      DOCUMENTS
     </b>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="3" valign="top">
     <ul>
      <li>
       Employer's letter-for general use;
      </li>
     </ul>
     <b>
      or
     </b>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Employer's email advice-for general use
      </li>
     </ul>
     <br/>
     The document must confirm that the borrower’s or income guarantor 's package includes stipend income
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="3" valign="top">
     <b>
      ASSESSMENT / INCOME CACULATION
     </b>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="3" valign="top">
     100%- subject to Credit approval
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="3" valign="top">
     <b>
      ADDITIONAL CONDITIONS
     </b>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <strong>
      Eligibility
     </strong>
    </td>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <ul>
      <li>
       Borrower or income guarantor must be a
       <b>
        member of the clergy
       </b>
      </li>
      <li>
       Must be referred to and accepted by Credit
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <b>
      Tax Treatment
     </b>
    </td>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <ul>
      <li>
       Can be considered on an 'un-taxed' basis when that portion of the stipend is currently paid on an untaxed basis and will continue to be paid on an un-taxed basis without condition or subject to change, otherwise it must be treated as taxed income
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <strong>
      Commitments or expenses
     </strong>
    </td>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <ul>
      <li>
       Any commitment or expense which is related to the stipend, must be included in the serviceability assessment
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
  </tbody>
 </table>
 <table width="100%">
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <a id="Temporary Employment (AUD)" name="Temporary Employment (AUD)">
      <b>
       Temporary Employment (AUD)
      </b>
     </a>
     <br/>
     <b>
     </b>
     <br/>
     Employment is generally short term, of a seasonal nature or has a termination date.
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <b>
      Acceptable
     </b>
     temporary employment types and rules:
     <ul>
      <li>
       Employment via an annual contracts* directly with an employer where there is a defined start and end date to their employment period (.
      </li>
     </ul>
     <br/>
     It is acceptable for the annual employment contract to state employment is on a Temporary or Casual basis.
     <br/>
     <br/>
     If the borrower or income guarantor meets the above and:
     <ul>
      <li>
       <ul>
        <li>
         <b>
          has
         </b>
         access to annual leave and sick leave, assess as per:
         <ul>
          <li>
           <a data-tagid="Dependent Contractor (AUD)" href="#Dependent Contractor (AUD)" target="_self">
            Dependent Contractor
           </a>
          </li>
         </ul>
        </li>
        <li>
         <b>
          does not
         </b>
         have access to annual leave and sick leave, assess as per:
         <ul>
          <li>
           <a data-tagid="Casual Income (AUD)" href="#Casual Income (AUD)">
            Casual
           </a>
          </li>
         </ul>
        </li>
       </ul>
      </li>
      <li>
       Employment via a contract with an employment agency where:
       <ul>
        <li>
         the employee has a history of continual employment through the temp agency (often referred to as 'temps')
        </li>
        <li>
         the employment agency can place the employee on various assignments for any length of time at external businesses.
        </li>
        <li>
         the employer remains the employment agency, not the company the employee is on assignment at.
        </li>
        <li>
         These employees are to be assessed as per
         <a data-tagid="Casual Income (AUD)" href="#Casual Income (AUD)">
          Casual
         </a>
         policy
        </li>
       </ul>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <br/>
     <sup>
      *
     </sup>
     Examples of acceptable temporary contractors employed via an annual contract include (but are not limited to), teachers whose payslip or employment contract may state they are employed on a Temporary or Casual basis, but they have a defined start and end date in their contract.
    </td>
   </tr>
  </tbody>
 </table>
 <table width="100%">
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="3" valign="top">
     <a id="PAYG Salary or Wage- Salary Sacrifice / Fringe Benefit deduction / Pre - Tax deductions" name="PAYG Salary or Wage- Salary Sacrifice / Fringe Benefit deduction / Pre - Tax deductions">
      <b>
       PAYG Salary or Wage - Salary Sacrifice / Fringe Benefit deduction / Pre-Tax deductions
      </b>
     </a>
     <br/>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <b>
      Definitions
     </b>
    </td>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     Salary sacrifice / Fringe benefit deduction / Pre-tax deductions on a payslip are deductions from gross income.
     <br/>
     An employee may choose to have their taxable wage or salary reduced (sacrificed) via a deduction to their gross salary or wage. Some common examples include:
     <ul>
      <li>
       <ul>
        <li>
         Additional superannuation contributions above the Australian Super Guarantee (SG)
        </li>
        <li>
         Repayment of car leases (e.g. novated leases) or other loan repayment,
        </li>
        <li>
         Purchased leave
        </li>
        <li>
         Payment of childcare and school fees
        </li>
       </ul>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <br/>
     If the pre-tax deduction is
     <b>
      not
     </b>
     <b>
      required
     </b>
     for serviceability, it is acceptable to proceed with the lower income figure with the pre-tax deduction amount excluded. No further investigation is required, however, if it is related to a
     <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000690">
      Commitment
     </a>
     and/or
     <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000700">
      Living Expense
     </a>
     , ensure it has been reflected in the application.
     <br/>
     <br/>
     If the pre-tax deduction
     <b>
      is required
     </b>
     for serviceability, comply with the below
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="3" valign="top">
     <b>
      DOCUMENTS
     </b>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="3" valign="top">
     Documents N/A - salary sacrifice details are to be captured via ApplyOnline application input
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <b>
      Deduction type
     </b>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <b>
      Can be added back to gross income for servicing:
     </b>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <ul>
      <li>
       Superannuation contribution
      </li>
      <li>
       Purchased leave
      </li>
      <li>
       Salary packaging
      </li>
      <li>
       Other purposes not documented below:
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <ul>
      <li>
       After confirming with the customer that:
       <ul>
        <li>
         <strong>
          the deduction is voluntary
         </strong>
         , can be cancelled at any time and received as taxable income;
         <strong>
          and
         </strong>
        </li>
        <li>
         <strong>
          the
         </strong>
         customer will cancel the pre-tax deduction if required to meet their existing commitments and the repayments for the loan they have
        </li>
       </ul>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     Novated leases and other commitments
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     When the related commitment is captured in the loan application and verified as per
     <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000690">
      <em>
       Commitments
      </em>
     </a>
     policy
     <br/>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="3" valign="top">
     <b>
      ASSESSMENT / INCOME CALCULATION
     </b>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="3" valign="top">
     100% of the deduction added back to base income
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="3" valign="top">
     <b>
      ADDITIONAL CONDITIONS
     </b>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <b>
      Additional Superannuation contribution
     </b>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     Brokers / assessors must confirm that the contributions
     <strong>
      are not:
     </strong>
     <br/>
     <strong>
     </strong>
     <br/>
     <strong>
      Compulsory
     </strong>
     employee superannuation contributions by the borrower’s or income guarantor’s employer.
     <br/>
     <br/>
     There may be a description of ‘Comp’ or similar alongside the amount on the payslip, but be aware that this amount may include both
     <strong>
      compulsory
     </strong>
     and
     <strong>
      non-compulsory
     </strong>
     <strong>
      amounts
     </strong>
     .
     <br/>
     <br/>
     Any
     <b>
      non-compulsory
     </b>
     portion as confirmed by the broker / assessor is eligible.
     <br/>
     <br/>
     For
     <strong>
      compulsory
     </strong>
     employee superannuation contributions deducted Post-Tax, refer to
     <a data-tagid="PAYG Salary or Wage -After tax / post tax deductions" href="#PAYG Salary or Wage -After tax / post tax deductions" target="_self">
      Post-Tax deductions
     </a>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <strong>
      Commitments or expenses
     </strong>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     Any commitment or living expense which is related to the deduction amount, must be included in the serviceability assessment
     <br/>
    </td>
   </tr>
  </tbody>
 </table>
 <b>
 </b>
 <br/>
 <table width="624">
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <a id="PAYG Salary or Wage -After tax / post tax deductions" name="PAYG Salary or Wage -After tax / post tax deductions">
      <b>
       PAYG Salary or Wage -After tax / post tax deductions
      </b>
     </a>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     After Tax or Post Tax deductions are deductions from the net salary, i.e.
     <strong>
      after
     </strong>
     tax has been applied and deducted.
     <br/>
     The post-tax deduction is
     <b>
      not
     </b>
     to be removed from or added to the base income figure from the payslip.
     <br/>
     The deduction must be assessed and entered in the application as per:
     <ul>
      <li>
       <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000700">
        Living expense
       </a>
       policy, refer specific expense category &gt; expense category table;
       <strong>
        or
       </strong>
      </li>
      <li>
       <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000690">
        Commitments
       </a>
       policy, as per the individual commitment type
      </li>
     </ul>
     <b>
     </b>
    </td>
   </tr>
  </tbody>
 </table>

 <table width="100%">

   <tr>
    <td colspan="3" valign="top">

      </a>

     <br/>
     <b>
     </b>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <b>
      Definitions
     </b>
    </td>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     A pension paid to a person from monies invested in savings schemes or mutual funds run by insurance companies
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="3" valign="top">
     <b>
      DOCUMENTS
     </b>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="3" valign="top">
     <ul>
      <li>
       Private pension provider's letter;
      </li>
     </ul>
     <strong>
      or
     </strong>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Private pension provider's email advice
      </li>
     </ul>
     <br/>
     <strong>
      And one of the following:
     </strong>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Account transaction listing produced internally from a Westpac Group system, showing receipt of payments over a 6 month period, with the credit narrative aligned to the income;
      </li>
     </ul>
     <strong>
      or
     </strong>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Account statement from other financial institution, showing receipt of payments over a 6 month period, with the credit narrative aligned to the income;
      </li>
     </ul>
     <strong>
      or
     </strong>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Account transaction listing from another financial institution
       <strong>
        and
       </strong>
       Account statement collectively covering receipt of payments over a 6 month period, with the credit narrative aligned to the income. Final transaction on the statement must be no older than 12 months from the
       <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000698" target="_blank">
        Responsible Lending Start Date
       </a>
       .
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="3" valign="top">
     <b>
      ASSESSMENT / INCOME CALCULATION
     </b>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="3" valign="top">
     100%
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="3" valign="top">
     Lower of:
     <ul>
      <li>
       the letter or email advice from the provider,
       <b>
        and
       </b>
      </li>
      <li>
       average of the last 6 months payments to account (do not tax).
      </li>
     </ul>
     <b>
     </b>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="3" valign="top">
     <b>
      ADDITIONAL CONDITIONS
     </b>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <strong>
      Eligibility
     </strong>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <ul>
      <li>
       Income must be able to be sustained for term of the loan, as evidenced by:
       <ul>
        <li>
         The provider’s document showing that the remaining term of the payment is equal to or greater than the loan term,
         <b>
          or
         </b>
        </li>
        <li>
         If the providers document does not show the remaining term of the payment:
         <ul>
          <li>
           The income calculated multiplied by the term of the loan is less than or equal to the investment / superannuation balance
          </li>
          <li>
           For defined benefits private pension, only apply the above calculation for any portion of superannuation income which is
           <b>
            not
           </b>
           a defined benefits payment
          </li>
         </ul>
        </li>
       </ul>
      </li>
      <li>
       Payments only made annually may be referred to Credit for exception consideration
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <b>
      Tax Treatment
     </b>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     Depending on the borrower’s or income guarantor ’s age and type of income stream, may have one or more of:
     <ul>
      <li>
       A taxed component – tax has already been paid by the fund on a portion of the benefit
      </li>
      <li>
       An untaxed component – portion of benefit that is still taxable as tax has not been paid in the fund
      </li>
      <li>
       A tax-free component – portion of benefit that is tax-free
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>

         </a>
         policy &gt; Rental income - fully verified self-employed assessment
        </li>
       </ul>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <strong>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         Essential repairs noted on Full Valuation
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </strong>
    </td>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Where a valuer comments that the property is unsuitable to rent due to repairs being required, and the value of the repairs is within acceptable tolerances, refer
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000686">
         Security Collateral Value Assessment
        </a>
        &gt; Risk Rating in Valuation Report, and:
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          The valuer has provided an estimated rental amount, subject to the repairs being completed,
          <b>
           and
          </b>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          The borrower(s) has sufficient funds to complete the repairs, as evident in the borrower’s declared asset position
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <b>
         Then
        </b>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          The Valuers rental estimate (where acceptable as detailed above), post the repairs being completed, may be included in the Serviceability assessment.
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <b>
         Note:
        </b>
        Where the Valuer has not provided an estimated cost of the repairs or recommends an independent professional opinion be sought, then rental income cannot be included for that property unless:
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          an estimated cost / quote(s) for the repairs is held,
          <b>
           and
          </b>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          the borrower(s) has sufficient funds to complete the repairs, as evident in the borrower’s asset position.
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Where the cost of the repairs exceeds acceptable tolerances, refer
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000686">
         Security Collateral Value Assessment
        </a>
        &gt; Risk Rating in Valuation Report, the application must be referred to Credit consideration
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
  </tbody>
 </table>

    <td valign="top">
     <b>
      Definitions
     </b>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     A pension paid to a person from monies invested in a Retail, Industry, Public sector, or Corporate superannuation fund
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <b>
      DOCUMENTS
     </b>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <ul>
      <li>
       Superannuation fund letter;
      </li>
     </ul>
     <strong>
      or
     </strong>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Superannuation fund email advice
      </li>
     </ul>
     <br/>
     <strong>
      And one of the following:
     </strong>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Account transaction listing produced internally from a Westpac Group system, showing receipt of payments over a 6 month period, with the credit narrative aligned to the income,
      </li>
     </ul>
     <strong>
      or
     </strong>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Account statement from other financial institution, showing receipt of payments over a 6 month period, with the credit narrative aligned to the income,
      </li>
     </ul>
     <strong>
      or
     </strong>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Account transaction listing from another financial institution
       <strong>
        and
       </strong>
       Account statement collectively covering receipt of payments over a 6 month period, with the credit narrative aligned to the income. Final transaction on the statement must be no older than 12 months from the
       <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000698" target="_blank">
        Responsible Lending Start Date
       </a>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <b>
      ASSESSMENT / INCOME CALCULATION
     </b>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     100%
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     Income used is the lower of:
     <ul>
      <li>
       the cycle payment amount detailed on the provider letter or email,
       <b>
        or
       </b>
      </li>
      <li>
       average of the last 6 months payments to account (do not tax)
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2" valign="top">
     <b>
      ADDITIONAL CONDITIONS
     </b>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <strong>
      Eligibility
     </strong>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <ul>
      <li>
       Income must be able to be sustained for term of the loan, as evidenced by:
       <ul>
        <li>
         The provider’s document showing that the remaining term of the payment is equal to or greater than the loan term,
         <b>
          or
         </b>
        </li>
        <li>
         If the providers document does not show the remaining term of the payment:
         <ul>
          <li>
           The income calculated multiplied by the term of the loan is less than or equal to the investment / superannuation balance
          </li>
          <li>
           For defined benefits superannuation payment, only apply the above calculation for any portion of superannuation income which is
           <b>
            not
           </b>
           a defined benefits payment
          </li>
         </ul>
        </li>
       </ul>
      </li>
      <li>
       Payments only made annually may be referred to Credit for exception consideration
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <b>
      Tax Treatment
     </b>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <ul>
      <li>
       Depending on the borrower’s or income guarantor’s age and type of income stream, may have one or more of:
       <ul>
        <li>
         A taxed component – tax has already been paid by the fund on a portion of the benefit
        </li>
        <li>
         An untaxed component – portion of benefit that is still taxable as tax has not been paid in the fund
        </li>
        <li>
         A tax-free component – portion of benefit that is tax-free
        </li>
       </ul>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>

 <h3>
  <a id="2.4 Verifying Self-employed Income" name="2.4 Verifying Self-employed Income">
   2.4 Verifying Self-employed Income
  </a>

 <table width="100%">
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <b>
      Definitions
     </b>
    </td>
    <td colspan="3" valign="top">
     A borrower or income guarantor may need to be assessed as self-employed where they earn income or have a loss from a business related to them, which may include:
     <ul>
      <li>
       PAYG income
       <u>
        and / or
       </u>
       Directors fees
       <b>
        from own company
       </b>
      </li>
      <li>
       Distribution of income from a trust
      </li>
      <li>
       They are a sole trader, earning Personal Services (PSI) income or in a partnership
      </li>
      <li>
       borrower or income guarantor is an Individual ATF a trust
      </li>
      <li>
       When undistributed company profits are being used for individual serviceability assessment
      </li>
      <li>
       Dividend received from own company and used for serviceability assessment
      </li>
      <li>
       Independent contractors
      </li>

   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <strong>
      Definitions
     </strong>
    </td>
    <td colspan="4" valign="top">
     <p>
      Applications are to be assessed using this policy, where a borrower, income guarantor (WBC only) or individual assessed under
      <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000710">
       <i>
        Serviceability Assessment policy
       </i>
      </a>
      <i>
       &gt; Apportioned household expenses and shared commitments – Spousal same household:
      </i>
     </p>
     <ul>
      <li>
       is earning income in a foreign currency,
       <b>
        or
       </b>
      </li>
      <li>
       is not working in Australia and its territories, this includes, but is not limited to, applicants employed by an Australian entity, but working outside Australia and its territories,
       <b>
        or
       </b>
      </li>
      <li>
       is employed by a foreign employer which is not registered in Australia, i.e. does not have an Australian Business Number (ABN).
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <strong>
      Restrictions
     </strong>
    </td>
    <td colspan="4" valign="top">
     <ul>
      <li>
       Not available to company and / or trusts
      </li>
      <li>
       No self-employed income can be used in the serviceability assessment
      </li>
      <li>
       Foreign income is not acceptable to be used for
       <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000710">

 <h3>
  <a name="P_Assessing_base_income">
   <strong>
    <span>
     <span>
      3.1 Assessing Base Income
     </span>
    </span>
   </strong>
  </a>
 </h3>
 <table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="1">
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2">
     <h3 align="center">
      <strong>
       <span>
        <span>
         Base income
        </span>
       </span>
      </strong>
     </h3>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Be aware YTD income figures on a payslip may be provided as YTD total gross earnings (being income prior to tax or other pre-tax deductions) or YTD total taxable earnings (being after pre-tax deductions). Where the payslip provides both figures, use the YTD total gross earnings figure in the employer income calculator
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <a name="P_Base_income_Payslips">
     </a>
     <span>
      <span>
       Base Income
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Payslips
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <span>
       Also see:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <a href="#R_S_or_W_Base_income_-_payslips">
        <em>
         verifying
        </em>
       </a>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Add income as
       <strong>
        <span>
         Base Salary.
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       If income documents indicate any pre-tax deductions, refer to
      </span>
      <a href="#P_Salary_Sacrifice_Fringe_Benefit_Pre_ta">
       <span>
        Process &gt;
       </span>
       <em>
        <span>
         Salary Sacrifice / Fringe Benefit deduction / Pre-Tax deductions
        </span>
       </em>
      </a>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <a name="P_Base_income_Direct_salary_Credits">
     </a>
     <span>
      <span>
       Base income
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Direct salary credits
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <span>
       Also see:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <a href="#R_S_or_W_Base_income_-_direct_salary_cre">
        <em>
         Verifying
        </em>
       </a>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       1. Use the employer income calculator, ensure you complete the fields:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Income verification type &gt;
       <strong>
        <span>
         Account Credits
        </span>
       </strong>
      </li>
      <li>
       Net pay amount. If salary credits differ the lower amount is to be used to annualise income
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <span>
       2. The calculator will:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Determine base
      </li>
      <li>
       Provide gross income amount to enter into ApplyOnline
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <span>
       3. Create a PDF copy of the employer income calculator outcome and retain the PDF in the file.
       <br/>
       4. If a loan application is referred to Credit a copy of the calculation must be available with the loan documentation for reference.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <a name="P_Salary_Sacrifice_Fringe_Benefit_Pre_ta">
     </a>
     <span>
      <span>
       Salary Sacrifice or
       <br/>
       Fringe Benefit deduction or
       <br/>
       Pre-Tax deduction
       <br/>
       <br/>
       <strong>
        <span>
         Note
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
     </span>
     <span>
      <span>
       : If the salary sacrifice deduction is not required
       <br/>
       to be included in gross income for serviceability calculations,
       <br/>
       it is acceptable to proceed with the lower income figure.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       In these instances you must still include any commitment or living expense which is related to the deduction amount.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       Also see:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <a href="#R_S_or_W_Salary_Sac_deductions">
        <em>
         Verifying
        </em>
       </a>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
    <td>
     <strong>
      <span>
       <span>
        In all cases
       </span>
      </span>
     </strong>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       Complete the fields within the employer income calculator tool as per the specific income scenario until you reach the "Salary Sacrifice" fields, then refer to below for individual deduction type:
       <br/>
       <br/>
       <strong>
        <span>
         For Additional Superannuation Contributions
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
      <br/>
      <strong>
       <span>
        Steps
       </span>
      </strong>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       1
       <strong>
        <span>
         .
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
     </span>
     <span>
      <span>
       Review the payslip and identify the Superannuation Guarantee (SG) contribution amount and the voluntary additional superannuation contribution.  If the payslip only shows a single superannuation deduction, then further investigation is required.  If it is identified that the superannuation deduction relates solely to the SG amount, then do not proceed further.
       <br/>
       Where you have confirmed the deduction is a voluntary superannuation contribution, proceed to step 2.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       2. Have the applicant complete the Salary Sacrifice Declaration form. Check the form has been completed in line with requirements as per
       <a href="#R_S_or_W_Salary_Sac_deductions">
        <strong>
         <span>
          Rules
         </span>
        </strong>
       </a>
      </span>
      <a href="#R_S_or_W_Salary_Sac_deductions">
       &gt; Base income
       <strong>
        <span>
         &gt;
        </span>
       </strong>
      </a>
     </span>
     <a href="#R_S_or_W_Salary_Sac_deductions">
      <em>
       <span>
        <span>
         Salary Sacrifice, Fringe Benefit deduction, Pre-tax deductions
        </span>
       </span>
      </em>
     </a>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <strong>
       <span>
        Notes:
       </span>
      </strong>
     </span>
     <span>
      <span>
       You cannot use the salary sacrificed income for serviceability calculations if the applicant has not:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         indicated the deduction is voluntary 9i.e. because it relates to a compuslroy super contribution);
         <strong>
          and
         </strong>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         indicated the deduction can be cancelled at any time and received as taxable income;
         <strong>
          and
         </strong>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         confirmed (where policy requires this declaration) that they would cancel the deduction if required to meet their existing commitments and the repayments for the loan they have requested.
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       3. In the employer income calculator,
       <strong>
        <span>
         ensure you complete the fields
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
      :
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Pre-tax deductions required for servicing?
       <strong>
        <span>
         Yes / No
        </span>
       </strong>
      </li>
      <li>
       Pre-tax deduction &gt; Input the actual amount from the payslip.  (The amount field must be completed even where the income is not used for serviceability assessment)
      </li>
     </ul>
     <strong>
      <span>
       <span>
        Note:
       </span>
      </span>
     </strong>
     <span>
      <span>
       The salary sacrifice (pre-tax deduction) amount loaded must be &gt;=$0. All salary sacrifice fields displayed are to be completed. For example, where more than single years documents are obtained complete both the Current Year and Prior Year columns.  Where there has been a change to base income, the pre-tax deduction amount prior to the base increase must also be entered.  The salary sacrifice amount can vary depending on the applicant's salary sacrifice arrangements at any point in time.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       4. If a PAYG Payment Summary or ATO Income Statement is required in the income calculation the amount shown at "Reportable employer superannuation contributions" may be added to the "Gross payments" amount.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       5. The calculator will:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Determine base and non-base income
      </li>
      <li>
       Provide gross income amount to enter into ApplyOnline
      </li>
      <li>
       Provide an Annual gross income amount to enter into ApplyOnline
      </li>
      <li>
       Provide an Annual 'Bonus' amount to enter into ApplyOnline
      </li>
     </ul>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       6.
      </span>
     </span>
     Create a PDF copy of the employer income calculator outcome and retain the PDF in the file.
     <span>
      <span>
       Assessment notes are to be completed and provide a clear explanation regarding the income used for serviceability assessment and compliance with this policy.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       7. If a loan application is referred to Credit a copy of the calculation must be available with the loan documentation for reference.
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <strong>
       <span>
        For Purchased leave and other purposes
       </span>
      </strong>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <strong>
      <span>
       Steps
      </span>
     </strong>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       1. Have the applicant complete the Salary Sacrifice Declaration form. Check the form has been completed in line with requirements as per
       <strong>
        <span>
         <a href="#R_S_or_W_Salary_Sac_deductions">
          Rules
         </a>
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
      <a href="#R_S_or_W_Salary_Sac_deductions">
       &gt;  Base income &gt;
      </a>
     </span>
     <a href="#R_S_or_W_Salary_Sac_deductions">
      <em>
       <span>
        <span>
         Salary Sacrifice, Fringe Benefit deduction, Pre-Tax deductions
        </span>
       </span>
      </em>
     </a>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <strong>
       <span>
        Note:
       </span>
      </strong>
     </span>
     <span>
      <span>
       If the applicant has not indicated the deduction is voluntary, can be cancelled at any time and received as taxable income then you can-not use the salary sacrificed income for serviceability calculations.
       <br/>
       In addition, (where policy requires this declaration) if the applicant has not confirmed they would cancel the deduction if required to meet their existing commitments and the repayments for the loan they have requested, then you can-not use the salary sacrificed income for serviceability calculations.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       2.  In the employer income calculator,
       <strong>
        <span>
         ensure you complete the fields
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
      :
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Pre-tax deductions required for servicing?
       <strong>
        <span>
         Yes / No
        </span>
       </strong>
      </li>
      <li>
       Pre-tax deduction &gt;
       <strong>
        <span>
         Input the actual amount from the payslip
        </span>
       </strong>
       .  (The amount field must be completed even where the income is not used for serviceability assessment)
      </li>
     </ul>
     <strong>
      <span>
       <span>
        Note:
       </span>
      </span>
     </strong>
     <span>
      <span>
       The salary sacrifice (pre-tax deduction) amount loaded must be &gt;=$0. All salary sacrifice fields displayed are to be completed. For example, where more than single years documents are obtained complete both the Current Year and Prior Year columns.  Where there has been a change to base income, the pre-tax deduction amount prior to the base increase must also be entered.  The salary sacrifice amount can vary depending on the applicant's salary sacrifice arrangements at any point in time.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       3. The calculator will:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Determine base and non-base income
      </li>
      <li>
       Provide gross income amount to enter into ApplyOnline
      </li>
      <li>
       Provide an Annual gross income amount to enter into ApplyOnline
      </li>
      <li>
       Provide an Annual 'Bonus' amount to enter into ApplyOnline
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <span>
       4.
      </span>
     </span>
     Create a PDF copy of the employer income calculator outcome and retain the PDF in the file.
     <span>
      <span>
       ApplyOnline notes are to be completed and provide a clear explanation regarding the income used for serviceability assessment and compliance with this policy.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       5. If a loan application is referred to Credit a copy of the calculation must be available with the loan documentation for reference.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       6
       <strong>
        <span>
         .
        </span>
       </strong>
       Any corresponding debt / commitment that relates to the salary sacrifice amount must be included in ApplyOnline
       <br/>
       <br/>
       7. For car lease payments only the finance portion of the car lease is to be included as an outgo in ApplyOnline (i.e. the car running costs are to be included the declared Living Expenses and do not need to be included as an outgo).
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       <strong>
        <span>
         Note:
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Often a novated lease may not be cancelled and taken as an increase in gross taxable income due to the potential financial implications to the customer.
      </li>
      <li>
       Salary sacrifice may be linked to an expense. Ensure the expense is included in customer declared expenses where appropriate e.g. transport in customer declared expense, or car loan repayments in liabilities refer
       <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000700">
        <em>
         <span>
          Living expenses
         </span>
        </em>
       </a>
       .
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
  </tbody>

 <h3>
  <a name="P_Assessing_Base_plus_non_base_income">
   <strong>
    <span>
     <span>
      3.2 Assessing Base plus Non-Base income
     </span>
    </span>

  </a>
 </h3>
 <table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="1">
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2">
     <h3>
      <strong>
       <span>
        <span>
         Base plus Non-Base income
        </span>
       </span>
      </strong>
     </h3>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Be aware YTD income figures on a payslip may be provided as YTD total gross earnings (being income prior to tax or other pre-tax deductions) or YTD total taxable earnings (being after pre-tax deductions). Where the payslip provides both figures, use the YTD total gross earnings figure in the employer income calculator
      </li>
      <li>
       <strong>
        <span>
         Always use the employer income calculator and retain a copy of the calculations with other income documentation
        </span>
       </strong>
      </li>
      <li>
       Within the employer income calculator Base income will display as the selected pay frequency, whereas the non-base/bonus income will be displayed as an Annual figure
      </li>
      <li>
       The steps herein are provided for reference purposes.
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <a name="P__base_non_base_1_payslip_covering_3_mt">
     </a>
     <span>
      <span>
       #1 Base plus non-base income, YTD payslip or
       <br/>
       payslip and ATO YTD income statement covering a minimum of 3 months
       <br/>
       <br/>
       Also see:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <a href="#R_S_or_W_base_plus_non_base_1">
        <em>
         Verifying
        </em>
       </a>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
    <td>
