        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
      Ask the applicant if either the YTD payslip / ATO income statements (YTD or tax ready) includes any gross Bonus payments.  In ApplyOnline assessment notes record the amount of the payment as stated by the applicant. (Verbal enquiry is acceptable and no validation of the applicant's response is required).
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       If the customer advises the YTD income DOES include Bonus payments already received (from step 2) or the payslip provided shows a bonus payment, enter the bonus payment into the employer income calculator.  The tool will deduct this amount from the Gross YTD income figure (from either the YTD payslip or ATO Income Statement) prior to annualisation.
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <span>
       3. If projected Bonus income (or combination of projected and already received Bonus) is required for serviceability, refer to additional steps listed under '
       <em>
        Calculate the maximum projected Bonus income permitted for serviceability calculations'
       </em>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       4. If income documents indicate any pre-tax deductions refer to
       <a href="#P_Salary_Sacrifice_Fringe_Benefit_Pre_ta">
        Process &gt;
       </a>
      </span>
     </span>
     <em>
      <span>
       <span>
        <a href="#P_Salary_Sacrifice_Fringe_Benefit_Pre_ta">
         Salary Sacrifice / Fringe Benefit deduction / Pre-Tax deductions
        </a>
       </span>
      </span>
     </em>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       5. The calculator will:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Determine base and non-base income
      </li>
      <li>
       Provide gross income amount to enter into ApplyOnline.
      </li>
      <li>
       Provide an Annual gross income amount to enter into ApplyOnline
      </li>
      <li>
       Provide an Annual 'Bonus' amount to enter into ApplyOnline
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <span>
       6.
      </span>
     </span>
     Create a PDF of the PAYG YTD calculation and retain the PDF in the file.
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       7. If a loan application is referred to Credit a copy of the
      </span>
     </span>
     employer income calculator
     <span>
      <span>
       must be available with the loan documentation for reference
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <a name="P_Base_non_base_7_does_not_cover_3_mths_">
     </a>
     <span>
      <span>
       #7 Base plus non-base income, payslip does not
       <br/>
       cover 3 months^
       <strong>
        and
       </strong>
       Base income increased between 2 Jul to 29 Sep inclusive
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       ^Payslip does not cover 3 months refers to pay dates between 1 Jul and 30 Sep inclusive
       <br/>
       <br/>
       Also see:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <a href="#R_S_or_W_base_plus_non_base_7">
        <em>
         Verifying
        </em>
       </a>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      Where current year annualised income is &gt; than prior year total gross income, then:
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         Non-Base income = Prior year PAYG gross income
         <strong>
          <span>
           less
          </span>
         </strong>
        </span>
        prior year annualised base income
        <strong>
         <span>
          plus
         </span>
        </strong>
       </span>
       current year Gross YTD income
       <strong>
        <span>
         less
        </span>
       </strong>
       YTD base income
       <span>
        <span>
         <sup>
          <span>
           1
          </span>
         </sup>
         , divided by the number of pay cycles covered by both the current and prior income documents, multiplied by the number of pay cycles in the year (to return to an annual figure). Bonus income, both already received and projected to end of current financial year will be removed prior to annualisation of YTD income and assessed at 80%.
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       <strong>
        <span>
         Notes:
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <sup>
        1
       </sup>
       YTD base income = the lower base pay multiplied by the number of pay cycles in the current year on the lower base plus the higher base pay multiplied by the number of pay cycles in the current year on the higher base
      </li>
      <li>
       Where current year annualised income is &lt; prior year total gross income, then non-base income is the lower of current year annualised income less current annualised base income or prior year total gross income less current annualised base income
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <span>
       1. Use the
      </span>
     </span>
     employer income calculator
     <span>
      <span>
       , ensure you complete the fields:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Is non-base income included? &gt;
       <strong>
        <span>
         Yes
        </span>
       </strong>
      </li>
      <li>
       Has base income increased? &gt;
       <strong>
        <span>
         Yes
        </span>
       </strong>
      </li>
      <li>
       Base income increase type &gt;
       <strong>
        <span>
         Increase in transition
        </span>
       </strong>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <span>
       2
       <strong>
        <span>
         . This step to be completed in all cases.
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
      Ask the applicant if either the YTD payslip / ATO income statements (YTD or tax ready) includes any gross Bonus payments.  In ApplyOnlineassessment notes record the amount of the payment as stated by the applicant. (Verbal enquiry is acceptable and no validation of the applicant's response is required).
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       If the customer advises the YTD income DOES include Bonus payments already received (from step 2) or the payslip provided shows a bonus payment, enter the bonus payment into the income verification tool.  The tool will deduct this amount from the Gross YTD income figure (from either the YTD payslip or ATO Income Statement) prior to annualisation.
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <span>
       3. If projected Bonus income (or combination of projected and already received Bonus) is required for serviceability, refer to additional steps listed under '
       <em>
        Calculate the maximum projected Bonus income permitted for serviceability calculations'
       </em>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       4. If income documents indicate any pre-tax deductions refer to
       <a href="#P_Salary_Sacrifice_Fringe_Benefit_Pre_ta">
        Process &gt;
       </a>
      </span>
     </span>
     <em>
      <span>
       <span>
        <a href="#P_Salary_Sacrifice_Fringe_Benefit_Pre_ta">
         Salary Sacrifice / Fringe Benefit deduction / Pre-Tax deductions
        </a>
       </span>
      </span>
     </em>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       5. The calculator will:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Determine base and non-base income
      </li>
      <li>
       Provide gross income amount to enter into ApplyOnline
      </li>
      <li>
       Provide an Annual gross income amount to enter into ApplyOnline
      </li>
      <li>
       Provide an Annual 'Bonus' amount to enter into ApplyOnline
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <span>
       6.
      </span>
     </span>
     Create a PDF of the PAYG YTD calculation and retain the PDF in the file.
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       7. If a loan application is referred to Credit a copy of the
      </span>
     </span>
     employer income calculator
     <span>
      <span>
       must be available with the loan documentation for reference
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <a name="P_Base_non_base_8_projected_bonus">
     </a>
     <span>
      <span>
       #8 Projected bonus income
       <br/>
       Also See:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <a href="#R_S_or_W_base_plus_non_base_8_projected_">
        <em>
         Verifying
        </em>
       </a>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
    <td>
     <strong>
      <span>
       <span>
        Calculate the maximum projected Bonus income permitted for serviceability calculations
       </span>
      </span>
     </strong>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <strong>
       <span>
        Note:
       </span>
      </strong>
     </span>
     <span>
      <span>
       The below process steps are optional and should only be used where projected Bonus income will be used for serviceability calculations.  The steps can accommodate a scenario where the applicant has both a projected Bonus amount and the YTD income also includes Bonus already received.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       <strong>
        <span>
         Steps
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       1. Ask the applicant if they will receive a Bonus prior to the end of the current financial year (projected Bonus) and where the response is 'yes', enter the declared amount into the annualisation calculator in the current year column, projected bonus field.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       2. Obtain the required income documents as per
      </span>
     </span>
     <em>
      <span>
       <span>
        <a href="#P_Base_non_base_8_projected_bonus">
         Verifying income &gt; Projected Bonus income
        </a>
       </span>
      </span>
     </em>
     <span>
      <span>
       (including the prior year payslip(s) (historical) identifying each Bonus amount the applicant previously received). Check that the projected bonus payment cycle is expected between the date of the application and the end of the current financial year to support the use of the projected bonus.
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     3.
     <strong>
      <span>
       Where YTD payslip does not cover a minimum of 3 months,
       <u>
        or
       </u>
       non-YTD payslips are held
      </span>
     </strong>
     - Using the prior year payslips (historical) obtained at step 2, enter
     <strong>
      <span>
       the total historical
      </span>
     </strong>
     bonus amount in the Bonus already received &gt; Prior year column.
     <br/>
     Or
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        3.
        <strong>
         <span>
          Where YTD payslip is
         </span>
        </strong>
        <b>
         covering a minimum of 3 months
         <strong>
          <span>
           held
          </span>
         </strong>
        </b>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <strong>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         -
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </strong>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        From the Group 2 document, enter the previous year annual income
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       4. The
      </span>
     </span>
     employer income calculator
     <span>
      <span>
       will determine if any of the projected bonus can be used for serviceability assessment.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       5. Where the
      </span>
     </span>
     employer income calculator
     <span>
      <span>
       confirms projected bonus (part or full) can be included for serviceability assessment.  Enter the amount as displayed in the tool 'Annual bonus' field into ApplyOnline
       <br/>
       <br/>
       6. Retain the
      </span>
     </span>
     employer income calculator
     <span>
      <span>
       as a record of your calculations and retain all other income documentation.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
  </tbody>
 </table>

       If the borrower receives a defined benefits private pension payment (i.e. payment is not based on the superannuation balance) then only use the above calculation for any portion of superannuation income which is not a defined benefits payment.
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <a name="P_returns_from_self-managed_super_fund">
     </a>
     <span>
      <span>
       Returns from Self-Managed Super Fund (SMSF)
       <br/>
       <br/>
       Also see:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <a href="#R_Suppl__Returns_from_SMSF">
        <em>
         Verifying
        </em>
       </a>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       How to Calculate: source the current and previous year's gross returns from Self-Managed Super Fund (SMSF) and perform the calculation below. Repeat for the net income if applicable.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       Compare current year and prior year Income Stream payments from SMSF return:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       If the current year's returns from Self-Managed Super Fund (SMSF) are lower than previous years then = the current year's income is used.
      </li>
      <li>
       If the current year's returns from Self-Managed Super Fund (SMSF) are higher than previous years then = the average of both years income is used.
      </li>
     </ul>
     <strong>
      <span>
       <span>
        Note:
       </span>
      </span>
     </strong>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       Less than 2 years SMSF to be referred to Credit with interim financials and accountant's letter or email advice.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       If applicants are self-employed additional document may be required in terms of self-employed income verification.
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         Add income as
         <strong>
          <span>
           Returns from Self-Managed Super Fund (SMSF)
          </span>
         </strong>
        </span>
        <strong>
         <span>
          <span>
           in ApplyOnline
          </span>
         </span>
        </strong>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <a name="P_superannuation_inc">
     </a>
     <span>
      <span>
       Superannuation income
       <br/>
       (Retail, Industry, Public sector, or Corporate superannuation fund)
       <br/>
       <br/>
       Also see:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <a href="#R_Suppl_Superannuation_income">
        <em>
         Verifying
        </em>
       </a>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Add income as
       <strong>
        <span>
         Annuity, superannuation, or private pension
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
      <strong>
       <span>
        <span>
         in ApplyOnline.
        </span>
       </span>
      </strong>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <strong>
      <span>
       <span>
        How to calculate:
       </span>
      </span>
     </strong>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Use the lower of
       <ul>
        <li>
         the letter or email advice from the provider
         <strong>
          <span>
           or
          </span>
         </strong>
        </li>
        <li>
         average of the last 6 months payments to account (do not tax).
        </li>
       </ul>
      </li>
      <li>
       Demonstrate income can be sustained for term of the loan by either:
       <ul>
        <li>
         The Superannuation providers letter or email advice shows the remaining term of the payment as the same or longer than the term of the loan or
        </li>
        <li>
         The income calculated above, multiplied by the term of the loan must be less than or equal to the investment / superannuation balance*
        </li>
       </ul>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <strong>
       <span>
        *Note
       </span>
      </strong>
     </span>
     <span>
      : If the borrower receives a defined benefits superannuation payment (i.e. payment is not based on the superannuation balance) then only use the above calculation for any portion of superannuation income which is not a defined benefits payment.
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>

     <span>

       <br/>
       <br/>
       Also see:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <a href="#R_Foreign_inc_Pension">
        <em>
         Verifying
        </em>
       </a>
      </li>

    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       To calculate foreign income ensure a completed
      </span>
     </span>
     <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/ci/okcsFattach/getFile/1000702/03.13%20Translation%20Checklist%20CSH.xlsm">
      <em>
       Foreign currency translation checklist
      </em>
     </a>
     <span>
      <span>
       <em>
       </em>
       is held and complete Steps 1 to 4 below:
       <br/>
       <br/>
       <strong>
        <span>
         Step 1.
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
     </span>
     <span>
      <span>
       Calculate income from letter from the relevant government department (annualised gross amount)
       <br/>
       Convert foreign total
       <br/>
       <br/>
       <strong>
        <span>
         Step 2.
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
     </span>
     <span>
      <span>
       Calculate income from credits to bank account ((annualised net amount to account)
       <br/>
       Convert foreign total to AUD$
       <br/>
       <br/>
       <strong>
        <span>
         Step 3.
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
     </span>
     <span>
      <span>
       Accept the lower of calculation at Step 1 or 2. Compare the AUD$ amount calculated in 1. above to the AUD$ amount calculated in 2. above and accept the lowest value as the amount to be used as income.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       <strong>
        <span>
         Step 4.
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
      Calculated AUD$ amount shown in green highlighted cell in the
     </span>
     <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/ci/okcsFattach/getFile/1000702/03.13%20Translation%20Checklist%20CSH.xlsm">
      <em>
       Foreign currency translation checklist
      </em>
     </a>
     <span>
      <span>
       , is to be entered as Pension Foreign Currency Income
       <br/>
       <br/>
       <strong>
        <span>
         Note:
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       If the income amount varies between government department letter or credits to account, the lowest value on letter or credits to account is to be accepted in the Translations Checklist calculation.
      </li>
      <li>
       Exchange rate to be used is the 'monthly average' rate via
       <em>
        <span>
         <a href="https://www.westpac.com.au/content/dam/public/wbc/documents/pdf/cb/fx-monthly-averages.pdf">
          https://www.westpac.com.au/content/dam/public/wbc/documents/pdf/cb/fx-monthly-averages.pdf
         </a>
        </span>
       </em>
       . If no rate is available from the Westpac site above use
       <em>
        <span>
         <a href="http://www.xe.com/">
          http://www.xe.com/
         </a>
        </span>
       </em>
       .
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>

      <span>
       Rental Income (in foreign currency)

       <br/>

      <em>
       Foreign currency translation checklist
      </em>
     </a>
     <span>
      <span>
       <em>
       </em>
      </span>
      is held. The
     </span>
     <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/ci/okcsFattach/getFile/1000702/03.13%20Translation%20Checklist%20CSH.xlsm">
      <em>
       Foreign currency translation checklist
      </em>
     </a>
     <span>
      <em>
      </em>
     </span>
     will:
     <ul>
      <li>
       Convert foreign total to AUD using the latest 'Monthly average exchange rate', or 'xe.com' if no rate listed

      <li>

       <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/ci/okcsFattach/getFile/1000702/03.13%20Translation%20Checklist%20CSH.xlsm">
        <em>
         Foreign currency translation checklist
        </em>
       </a>
       . This is  then to be entered as rental income with Foreign currency income flag
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <strong>
       <span>
        Note:
       </span>
      </strong>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       If two rental payments differ the lower amount is to be used to annualise income
      </li>
      <li>
       Negative gearing is not available
      </li>
      <li>
       Exchange rate to be used is the 'monthly average' rate via
       <a href="https://www.westpac.com.au/content/dam/public/wbc/documents/pdf/cb/fx-monthly-averages.pdf">
        <em>
         <span>
          https://www.westpac.com.au/content/dam/public/wbc/documents/pdf/cb/fx-monthly-averages.pdf
         </span>
        </em>
       </a>
       . If no rate is available from the Westpac site above use

      </li>
      <li>
       Where calculators are used, generate a PDF copy of the calculation and retain in the file.

    </td>

   <tr>
    <td>
     <a name="P_Foreign_Self-Employed">
     </a>
     <span>
      <span>
       Foreign Self-Employed
       <br/>
       <br/>
       Foreign self-employed income is
       <strong>
        <span>
         not acceptable
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
     </span>
     <span>
      <span>
       and can only be considered by Credit as an exception
       <br/>
       <br/>
       Foreign income must be listed on the
       <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/ci/okcsFattach/getFile/1000721/03.27%20Acceptable%20country%20&amp;%20currency%20list.pdf">
        <em>
         <span>
          Acceptable country and currency list
         </span>
        </em>
       </a>
      </span>
     </span>
     <span>
      <span>
       to be acceptable.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       Also see:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <a href="#R_Foreign_inc_Self_employed">
        <em>
         Verifying
        </em>
       </a>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       To calculate foreign income ensure a completed
      </span>
     </span>
     <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/ci/okcsFattach/getFile/1000702/03.13%20Translation%20Checklist%20CSH.xlsm">
      <em>
       Foreign currency translation checklist
      </em>
     </a>
     <span>
      <span>
       <em>
       </em>
       is held
       <br/>
       <br/>
       <strong>
        <span>
         Step 1.
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
     </span>
     <span>
      <span>
       Using two years financials
       <br/>
       <br/>
       <strong>
        <span>
         Step 2.
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
      Convert foreign total to AUD using the latest 'Monthly average exchange rate', or 'xe.com' if no rate listed.
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       If the current year's total income is lower than previous years then = the current year's income is used
      </li>
     </ul>
     <ul>
      <li>
       If the current year's income is higher than previous years then = the average of both years income is used
      </li>
     </ul>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       Also refer to Self Employed Income
       <br/>
       <br/>
       <strong>
        <span>
         Note:

      </span>
      Exchange rate to be used is the 'monthly average' rate via

        <a href="https://www.westpac.com.au/content/dam/public/wbc/documents/pdf/cb/fx-monthly-averages.pdf">
         https://www.westpac.com.au/content/dam/public/wbc/documents/pdf/cb/fx-monthly-averages.pdf
        </a>
       </span>
      </em>
     </span>
     . If no rate is available from the Westpac site above use

      <span>
       <a href="http://www.xe.com/">
        http://www.xe.com/
       </a>
      </span>
     </em>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       <strong>
        <span>
         Note:

       </strong>
      </span>
      Where an applicant has foreign income and employment and they do not meet the definition of a non-resident, evidence of a work permit/work visa is to be obtained from the customer to confirm they have the ability to work and reside within the foreign country. Refer to
      <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000702">
       Lending to Non-Australian Citizens

      &gt; Rules you must apply &gt;

       <br/>
       <strong>
        <span>
         Note:

      </span>
      Self-employed income does not require verification if not required to meet serviceability. However if an application is assessed by Credit, Credit may require full self-employed income verification.

 <h4>
  <a name="P_Loan_appl_and_approval_where_appl_earn">
   <strong>
    <span>
     <span>
      3.8.2 Loan applications and approval where the applicant is earning foreign income
     </span>
    </span>
   </strong>
  </a>
 </h4>
 <strong>
  <span>
   <span>
    Loan applications
   </span>
  </span>
 </strong>
 <br/>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   No lending is permitted where any applicant is considered to be a non-resident (refer to definition as per
  </span>
 </span>
 <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000702">
  Lending to Non-Australian Citizens
 </a>
 &gt; Rules you must apply &gt; Non-Residents Lending
 <span>
  ), the following process is provided for applicants earning foreign income:
 </span>
 <ul>
  <li>
   Home Loan Application Form to be completed and signed by applicant/s and any guarantor/s
  </li>
  <li>
   Complete income assessment and verification as per preceding foreign income policy and
   <em>
    <span>
     Verifying Income
    </span>
   </em>
   policy, noting:
   <ul>
    <li>
     Where the passport country of issue does not match the country where the applicant is employed, evidence is to be supplied to show the applicant is able to reside and work within the foreign country
    </li>
   </ul>
  </li>
  <li>
   Apply Valuation policy to determine and order the appropriate valuation type, refer to
   <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000686">
    <em>
     <span>
      Security Collateral Value
     </span>
    </em>
   </a>
  </li>
  <li>
   Broker to include detailed notes in ApplyOnline
  </li>
  <li>
   Broker to confirm the customer has the funds to complete the transaction
  </li>
  <li>
   Complete the relevant section of the
   <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/ci/okcsFattach/getFile/1000702/03.13%20Translation%20Checklist%20CSH.xlsm">
    Translation Checklist
   </a>
  </li>
  <li>
   Copies of documents are to be retained in the loan file
  </li>
  <li>
   Customer's full overseas residential and mailing addresses, email and telephone numbers are to be detailed on the loan application and in ApplyOnline
  </li>
  <li>
   Undertake a servicing assessment as per
   <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000710">
    <em>
     <span>
      Serviceability Assessment
     </span>
    </em>
   </a>
   policy
  </li>
  <li>
   Tax Deductions relating to Australian investment properties or Negative gearing benefits are:
   <ul>
    <li>
     permitted where the applicant has Australian Residency / Citizenship
    </li>
   </ul>
  </li>
  <li>
   Satisfactory Bureau Check
  </li>
  <li>
   Currency must be on the approved list as per
   <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/ci/okcsFattach/getFile/1000721/03.27%20Acceptable%20country%20&amp;%20currency%20list.pdf">
    <em>
     <span>
      Acceptable country and currency list
     </span>
    </em>
   </a>
   .
  </li>
 </ul>
 <span>
  <strong>
   <span>
    Approval
   </span>
  </strong>
 </span>
 <ul>
  <li>
   Mortgage insurance is not available where the applicant earns foreign income.
  </li>
  <li>
   Applicants who are Non-residents of Australia are unacceptable to the bank
  </li>
  <li>
   Any documents used to complete assessment and issue Formal Approval are to be imaged.
  </li>
 </ul>
 <br/>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
  </span>
 </span>
 <h2>
  <a name="F_Frequently_asked_questions">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     4. Frequently asked questions
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h2>
 <h3>
  <a name="F_Foreign_income_and_employment-FAQs">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     4.1 Foreign income and employment - FAQs
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h3>
 <table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="628">
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <strong>
      <span>
       <span>
        Question
       </span>
      </span>
     </strong>
    </td>
    <td>
     <strong>
      <span>
       <span>
        Answer
       </span>
      </span>
     </strong>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       My applicant is an Australian Citizen living and working in the UK, but they don't have dual citizenship, do I need to ask them for their work visa?
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Yes, you need to confirm they are legally able to work in the UK before proceeding with the application.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       My applicant has recently become an Australian Citizen, previously they had a Chinese passport, but for this application they have provided me with a copy of their Australian passport. Because they were previously a Chinese citizen, do I still need to get a work permit if they are now living and working in China?
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       As China does not permit dual citizenship with Australia, yes, the applicant will need to provide evidence of their work permit before proceeding with the application.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       My applicant is not a resident of Australia, they live and work in China and have a Chinese passport, do I need a work permit?
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       No, as the applicant is living and working within the same country that they have citizenship with, they will not require a work permit. However, this applicant would meet the non-resident definition and is not an acceptable applicant type.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       My applicant has provided me with a copy of their Indian passport, they have also given me a copy of their Australian 190 visa, but they are currently living and working in Dubai. What do I need to do?
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       This applicant's income does not comply with the visa matrix requirements, 190 visa type must earn AUD. If the 190 visa is ignored, then this applicant is a non-resident of Australia. In both scenarios the applicant is unacceptable to the bank and no lending permitted.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
  </tbody>
 </table>
 <h3>
  <a name="F_Salary_Sacrifice-FAQs">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     4.2 Salary Sacrifice - FAQs
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h3>
 <table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="628">
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <strong>
      <span>
       <span>
        Question
       </span>
      </span>
     </strong>
    </td>
    <td>
     <strong>
      <span>
       <span>
        Answer
       </span>
      </span>
     </strong>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       The narratives on the payslips show 'voluntary superannuation contribution' or non-SG contribution - why do I still need to get the customer to complete the salary sacrifice deduction declaration form.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       The salary sacrifice deduction declaration form helps us have a conversation with our customer and record the outcome of those discussions.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       In some cases the applicant's may be unwilling or unable to cancel the deductions, it is important that we do not make an assumption that the amount of the deduction is going to be available to meet this new loan commitment.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       For example:
       <br/>
       1. The voluntary salary sacrifice deduction on the payslip is being used by the applicant towards a Self-Managed Superannuation Fund Home Loan.
       <br/>
       Because of the shortfall between rent received on the investment property and the SMSF Home loan repayment, the applicant is unable to cancel the deduction.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       2. The applicant's employer pays an additional superannuation contribution above SG where the employee makes a voluntary contribution.
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       If the employee cancels the voluntary contribution, then they will lose the benefit of the above SG employer contribution.
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       The applicant is unwilling to cancel the deduction as they will suffer a long term financial impact.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       3. The applicant has previously had a marital financial settlement.  So they can rebuild their superannuation they are making voluntary contributions.
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       As they are planning for their retirement, they are unwilling to cancel the voluntary contribution amount.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       When don't I need to get the salary sacrifice deduction declaration form
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       If the amount of the salary sacrifice deduction is not required for serviceability assessment, then you do not need a salary sacrifice deduction declaration form. Your loan serviceability assessment will be based on the lower income figure.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       The deduction is an after-tax deduction.  While you may need to include the deduction as a commitment or living expense, it is not reducing the customer's taxable income and no salary sacrifice declaration form is required.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Why would my customer not be able to cancel a deduction for purchased leave?
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       The applicant may need to contact their employer to check under what basis they are able to cancel the deduction.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       For instance if the applicant has already taken the leave, repayment amount may be spread over the remaining year and might be unable to cancel the deduction.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Why can't my customer cancel their novated lease deduction?
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Early cancellation of the novated lease may result in negative tax implications for the customer.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       They need to investigate with both their employer and seek taxation advice to make a fully informed decision about any financial implications of cancelling the novated lease.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       If I don't use the salary sacrifice deduction amount for serviceability assessment, do I still need to load the commitment or living expense?
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Yes you do.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       Even if the income is not used for serviceability assessment you must include the commitment or living expense.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Why can't I load Salary Sacrifice deduction amounts as un-taxed income?
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       If the applicant did not have the deduction pre-tax, then the income would form part of their taxable income.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       If I still have to verify details of the commitment related to the salary sacrifice deduction how has this helped me do my job?
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Prior to the introduction of the Salary Sacrifice Declaration form, our verification rules had different processes when the employer was a Government and not for profit organisations v's non-Government.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       Through the introduction of the declaration form, we could simplify the processing of applications with salary sacrifice deductions and help ensure our customers more informed of the income we are using for serviceability assessment.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
  </tbody>
 </table>
 <h3>
  <a name="F_General_-FAQs">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     4.3 General - FAQs
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h3>
 <table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" width="628">
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <strong>
      <span>
       <span>
        Question
       </span>
      </span>
     </strong>
    </td>
    <td>
     <strong>
      <span>
       <span>
        Answer
       </span>
      </span>
     </strong>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>

       <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000692">
        <em>
         Document Standards
        </em>
       </a>
       policy for an account statement
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
  </tbody>
 </table>
 <h2>
  <a name="C_Credit">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     5. Credit
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h2>
 <span>
  <span>
   Income types not specifically named in Verifying Income policy are outside of an Assessor’s authority to approve but may be considered by Credit on a case-by-case basis (for example Workers compensation / Workcover).
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <span>
  <span>
   Credit will determine how the verification is to take place and the income calculation to be used.
  </span>
 </span>
 <br/>
 <br/>
 <br/>
 <br/>
</div>

  <tbody>
   <tr>

     <strong>

   <tr>
    <td>
     <a name="A">
     </a>
     <span>
      <span>
       ABN
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Australian business number
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       ABSTUDY SSL
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       SBSTUDY student Start-up Loan
       <br/>
       See
       <a href="#Study and Training Support Loans">
        <em>
         Study and Training Support Loans
        </em>
       </a>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       ACLN
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Australian credit license number
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       ACN
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Australian company number
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Add Backs
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Used when calculating the income for self-employed applicants - adding to the net income of certain expenditure items, e.g. Depreciation and interest.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <a id="Additions to an already established dwelling" name="Additions to an already established dwelling">
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         Additions to an already established dwelling
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </a>
    </td>
    <td>
     The addition of further living area(s) to an already established dwelling.
     <br/>
     The changes may include:
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         increasing living area(s) via new rooms or extra storey, and may involve full or partial
         <a data-tagid="Demolition of an already established dwelling" href="#Demolition of an already established dwelling">
          demolition
         </a>
         of the existing dwelling,
         <b>
          or
         </b>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            the construction of an attached
            <b>
             or
            </b>
            standalone dwelling on the title, e.g. granny flat, providing no more than 2 areas of occupancy on the title
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         Refer to
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <a data-tagid="Qualifying Development Costs" href="#Qualifying Development Costs">
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          Qualifying Development Cost
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </a>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Administration fee (also known as Management fee)
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Ongoing loan fee, charged on the account monthly, for administration of the account. This is in addition to the establishment fee or loan set-up costs.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Aged care facility
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       A special-purpose facility which provides accommodation and other types of support, including assistance with day-to-day living, intensive forms of care, and assistance towards independent living. Refer
       <em>
        <span>
         <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000684">
          LVR
         </a>
         &gt; Rules &gt; Unacceptable Securities
        </span>
       </em>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       ALMI
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Arch Lenders Mortgage Indemnity
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Appropriation
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Take possession of / devote money etc to special purposes
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       APRA
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Australian Prudential Regulation Authority - The prudential regulator of the Australian financial services industry (Banks, credit unions, building societies, general insurance and reinsurance companies, life insurance, private health insurance, friendly societies and most of the superannuation industry.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       ASIC
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Australian Securities and Investments Commission - government body that acts as Australia's corporate regulator. ASIC role is to enforce and regulate company and financial services laws to protect Australian consumers, investors and creditors.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       "As is" valuation
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       This type of valuation refers to the property as it is currently presented. Properties may be a long term established property, or newly completed and never previously occupied.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Asset collateral
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Real estate property which is already owned by the borrower
       <strong>
        <span>
         but is not
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
     </span>
     <span>
      <span>
       security collateral for the loan being referred to/assessed.
       <br/>
       An 'Asset collateral' may be security collateral for
       <strong>
        <span>
         another
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
      loan (internal or external) or may be unencumbered
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Assets
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Items of value owned by a party, e.g. land, buildings equipment
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       ATO
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Australian Tax Office
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       AVM
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Automated Valuation Model. AVM is used to confirm contract of sales value in higher risk situations or to validate an estimate of the property value provided by the customer.
       <br/>
       An Automated Valuation Model (also known as Modelled Estimate, Electronic Assessment, E-Val) is a statistical estimate of the property value based on historical sales of the property and similar in the immediate area. For this reason use is restricted to areas where there have been sufficient sales of similar properties to provide a valid range of values. The AVM is used to confirm contract of sale values in higher risk situations or to validate an estimate of the property value provided by the customer. Refer
       <em>
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000686">
         Security Collateral Value
        </a>
        &gt; Rules &gt; Assessing security collateral value using Automated Valuation Model
       </em>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <a name="B">
     </a>
     <span>
      <span>
       Base Loan amount
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Is the loan amount:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Excluding MI premium capitalisation
      </li>
      <li>
       Where the MI premium is not being capitalised
      </li>
      <li>
       Where MI does not apply
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Base LVR
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Is the LVR:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Excluding MI premium capitalisation
      </li>
      <li>
       Where the MI premium is not being capitalised
      </li>
      <li>
       Where MI does not apply.
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Benchmark Repayment Amount
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       A repayment value which has been calculated by the Bank for serviceability purposes only
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     Boarder
    </td>
    <td>
     Someone who occupies a property (who has access to part
     <b>
      or
     </b>
     all of the property) but they:
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         Do not own the property (their name does not appear on the certificate of title)
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         Are not purchasing the property (their name will not appear on the certificate of title post settlement)
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         Are not formally included on any rental agreement for the property (they are not the tenant named on the rental / lease agreement)
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
     AND
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         The owner of the property (or the formal tenant) keep control over the whole premises. The owner
         <b>
          or
         </b>
         formal tenant are considered to be the landlords of the boarder.
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <b>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         Note
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </b>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        : An applicant may be considered a boarder even where no payment is made for the use of the property. Including but not limited to, where the borrower is living with their parents, spouse, another family member (e.g. sibling or dependant), friend or employer provided accommodation.
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Boarding House
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Premises that provide boarders and lodgers with sleeping and residential quarters equipped with beds and may have common and shared facilities such as kitchen, bathrooms and living area. Refer to
       <a data-tagid="Rental income received on a short term basis" href="#Rental income received on a short term basis">
        Rental income received on a short term basis
       </a>
      </span>
     </span>
     <span>
      <span>
       and
       <em>
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000684">
         LVR
        </a>
        &gt; Rules &gt; Unacceptable Securities
       </em>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Body corporate
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Statutory Corporation created under the Strata Titles Act, representing the proprietors of home units in a block of units.
       <br/>
       The Body Corporate is concerned with the control, management and administration of the building and surrounds as well as payments of insurance premiums, rates, taxes etc.
       <br/>
       Home unit owner's pay for outgoings including the cost of repair and maintenance of the building and common property areas generally - these are called Body Corporate fees. Common property is the property which is not divided into individual lots (home units), e.g. stairs, gardens etc
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       BoM
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Bank of Melbourne
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Borrowing entity
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       The debtor (i.e. the person who borrows the money). The borrower is not always the mortgagor. See definition of Mortgagor.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Break costs
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       A fee which may be payable for early payout or switch from an existing fixed rate loan.
       <br/>
       The Loan Contract will define whether these costs may be payable and how they will be applied.
       <br/>
       They are a reasonable estimate of the Bank's loss incurred when a fixed rate period is broken.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     BSA
    </td>
    <td>
     Bank of South Australia
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Buffer rate
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       An amount which is added to the customers actual final interest rate as part of determining the Serviceability Assessment Rate
       <br/>
       Refer
       <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000710">
        <em>
         Serviceability Assessment
        </em>
       </a>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Bureau Report
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Various Credit Reporting Agencies provide a report on loan applicants. E.g. Equifax and Illion.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        ‘Buy Now Pay Later - Fixed Term’
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Fixed term 'Buy Now Pay Later' commitments - where a repayment
        <b>
         term is available
        </b>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        ‘Buy Now Pay Later - Revolving Term’
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Revolving 'Buy Now Pay Later' commitments -where a repayment
        <b>
         term is not available
        </b>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <a name="C">
     </a>
     <span>
      <span>
       CAL
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Credit Approval Limit - The maximum aggregate exposure an officer can approve for a customer group. Refer Credit Approval Limits
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Capitalised Loan Amount
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Is the loan amount including LMI premium capitalisation. Refer
       <em>
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000725">
         Mortgage Insurance
        </a>
       </em>
      </span>
      .
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Capitalised LVR
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Is the LVR including LMI premium capitalisation. Refer
       <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000725">
        <em>
         <span>
          Mortgage Insurance
         </span>
        </em>
       </a>
      </span>
      .
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Cash out
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       'Cash out' is where existing funds are fully or partly released directly to the customer for an acceptable purpose as listed in the
       <em>
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000694">
         Eligibility
        </a>
       </em>
      </span>
      policy, e.g. the purchase of a property or debt refinance where the Bank will control the release of loan proceeds to complete the purchase or refinance is not considered 'cash out'.
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Caveat
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       A notice of warning given to a public authority, e.g. Titles Office, claiming entitlement to an interest in certain land.
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       The caveat is registered and remains on the books as a warning to anyone who contemplates dealing with the property. It therefore prevents any action being taken without the previous notice of the person entering the caveat (the caveator).
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Caveatee
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Is the registered owner of the property, which is the subject of the caveat.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Caveator
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Party lodging a caveat, e.g. Westpac Group.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       CCR
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Comprehensive Credit Report
        <br/>
        Various Credit Reporting Agencies (E.g. Equifax) provide a report on loan applicants which details information on credit facilities, such as financial hardship information, repayment history (both positive and negative), limits, open and closed credit dates, and credit enquiries.

The share certificate and ownership of the shares allows that person to live in the unit. Unlike strata title, the buyer of a company title home unit will not receive a certificate of title to the property.

    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       The Bank's joint account authorities, guarantee forms, etc are framed to ensure that joint account holders with debts due to the Bank or joint guarantors liable to the Bank shall be
       <strong>
        <span>
         severally
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
      liable, (i.e. individually), as well as
      <strong>
       <span>
        jointly
       </span>
      </strong>
     </span>
     <span>
      <span>
       .
       <br/>
       With joint and several liability, a creditor has as many rights of action as there are debtors - the creditor can sue them jointly or severally until payment is obtained, and an unsatisfied judgement against one debtor will not be a bar to an action against the others.
      </span>
     </span>

    <td>
     <span>
      <span>

       <br/>
       The ownership of joint tenants is not stated in a specific share or portion as they each are held to own, at law, 'half of all and half of nothing'. There is no restriction on the number of joint tenants.
      </span>

       <br/>
       Most land tax liabilities will apply to investment properties after the cumulative value threshold (as set by the government) is exceeded.

Effectively a leasing company buys an asset for the user and receives payment from the user for their exclusive use.

      </span>
     </span>

   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>

      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Lender's Mortgage Insurance (LMI) :
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       is a once-only premium payable by the borrower when the LVR is greater than a specified threshold
      </li>
      <li>
       is a contract between the Bank and the Mortgage Insurer which protects the Bank against loss should the security collateral be sold at due to borrower default and there is a shortfall in the sale proceeds
      </li>
      <li>
       does not provide any protection for the borrower
      </li>
      <li>
       the policy is a contract between the Bank and the Mortgage Insurer
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <span>
       LMI is not to be confused with Life Insurance, Mortgage Protection Insurance or Property Insurance.
      </span>
     </span>

This limitation generally appears on titles that have been converted from the Old System Title of land to Torrens Title by the Land Titles Office. Solicitors acting on the conveyance will generally treat these as 'Old System' conveyances when checking title.

     <span>
      <span>
       The estimated amount which a seller would expect to receive from an informed purchaser for the property in the current resale market with normal marketing support through an Australian based real estate agency.
       <br/>
       The market value is determined on a vacant possession basis and is to be exclusive of purchase incentives, non-fixed chattels, legal / stamp duty costs and rental guarantees.'
       <br/>
       A market value assessed on this basis will
       <strong>
        <span>
         not
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
      reflect the mortgagee in possession or other forced sale circumstances.
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Mine subsidence
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       When material is mined from underground, the land above can alter and shift, which can impact buildings and other structures. The various movements of the surface and subsurface are known as mine subsidence. Each situation of mine subsidence is different and needs to be assessed according to the local conditions. Refer
       <em>
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000682">
         Acceptable Security Collateral
        </a>
        &gt; Rules &gt; Assessing security collateral impacted by Geographical or Environmental issues
       </em>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Mixed residential and commercial property
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Properties that have an occupied residence attached to a commercial premise (e.g. shop-front with a residence above or at the rear). Refer
       <em>
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000682">
         Acceptable Security Collateral
        </a>
        &gt;
       </em>
      </span>
      <em>
       <span>
        Assessing security Collateral requirements - Non-standard Development
       </span>

    </td>

      </span>

    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Homes identified by the ACT and NSW Governments as affected by loose fill asbestos and 'tagged' with warning stickers to meter boxes and switch boards. Refer
       <em>
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000682">
         Acceptable Security Collateral
        </a>
        &gt; Rules &gt; ACT and NSW Asbestos Affected Homes (Mr Fluffy)

      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
