   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       MV
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Market Value
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     Narrative
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        (may also be known as a transaction or payment description)
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     A transaction narrative is used to identify important information relating to credit or debit transactions on an account statement or account transaction listing, e.g. who the payment is to or from, reason for the payment etc.
     <br/>
     In some cases, the transaction narratives may be restricted by character count, where this occurs the narrative may only contain a partial description of the transaction.
     <br/>
     Where a single supporting document is used for verification, the transaction narrative must contain sufficient detail to clearly identify the transaction.
     <br/>
     <b>
      Example
     </b>
     of an acceptable narrative where a single supporting document is used, may include, but is not limited to:
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          Where verifying base salary credits to an account, the employer’s name in the narrative may appear partially or in full. To be acceptable the transaction narrative must be sufficient to be able to link the payment to the employer’s name entered in the loan application
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
       <br/>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
     Where a document(s) is used in combination with another document(s), a simpler narrative may be acceptable and must adhere to any requirements detailed in the specific policy.
     <br/>
     <b>
      Example
     </b>
     of an acceptable narrative where documents are used in combination may include, but is not limited to:
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Where verifying income from a payslip and the supplied document is missing the ‘Period the payslip covers’ (e.g., weekly fortnightly, monthly),
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        an internal system extract (account transaction listing) confirms the applicant is paid weekly.  The account transaction listing may have a simplified transaction narrative of ‘wages’
        <span>
         .
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <a name="N">
     </a>
     <span>
      <span>
       NDIS
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       National Disability Insurance Scheme
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       New security collateral
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Is defined as real estate property in which the Bank does not currently hold as security collateral but offered by the borrower as security collateral  to secure a mortgage.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       NRAS
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       National Rental Affordability Scheme - A government backed incentive scheme that seeks to address the shortage of affordable rental housing by offering financial incentives to the business sector and community organisations to build and rent dwellings to low and moderate income households at lower levels compared to market rates. NRAS aims to increase the supply of new rental dwellings and improve rental affordability.
       <br/>
       There are two distinct NRAS structures:
       <br/>
       <strong>
        <span>
         Head leases
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       Some schemes operate on a head-lease structure where the scheme operator leases the property from the investor for a 10-year period and in turn sub-leases it to a qualifying tenant. Under this structure the investor has little or no control over the selection of tenants or the selection of the property manager (with the scheme operator generally taking care of both).
       <br/>
       <strong>
        <span>
         Non-entity joint ventures (NEJV)
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       Other schemes provide for the investor to select their own property manager and in turn enter into direct residential tenancy agreements with their tenants (and involve themselves in tenant selection).
       <br/>
       Refer
      </span>
     </span>
     <em>
      <span>
       <span>
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000684">
         Lending Value Ratio (LVR)
        </a>
        &gt; Rules &gt; Assessing LVR by Security Type
       </span>
      </span>
     </em>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       Refer
      </span>
     </span>
     <em>
      <span>
       <span>
        Acceptable Security Collateral
       </span>
      </span>
     </em>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       NOA
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Notice of Assessment - provided by the Australian Tax Office (ATO) summarising an individual's taxable income.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Non-Resident
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       A person who does not hold an Australian Citizenship or Australian Permanent Residency visa or a person who holds an Australian Temporary visa however does not ordinarily reside in Australia.
      </span>
     </span>
     Refer to
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000702">
         Lending to Non-Australian Citizens
        </a>
        &gt;
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <span>
      <span>
       Non-Resident Lending
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Non-Trading Entity
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       An entity that is 'Non-trading' is not involved in any production activity or sale of goods and services; there is an absence of creditors, debtors or stock on the balance sheet.
       <br/>
       Income will typically be derived from passive investments. Passive income will typically include rent, dividends or interest.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Not currently tenanted
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        The rental property is not tenanted at the time of income verification but will be tenanted after loan approval.
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <a name="O">
     </a>
     <span>
      <span>
       OBP
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       One Bank Platform
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Off-the-plan strata/unit purchase
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       The customer enters into a contract to purchase a property before or during the construction phase of the development. In general, the customer has only sighted the plans for the development not the finished property.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Old System Title
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Also called 'Common Law System Title'. Evidence of ownership of land is recorded on individual deeds that establish a chain of title. Copies of these deeds are lodged at the Land Titles Office.
       <br/>
       Accurate and correct ownership of a property under Old System Title can only be determined if the chain of title is unbroken.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Open Policy
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Refers to LMI Policy. If the application meets certain set criteria as set by ALMI then mortgage insurance can be approved without referral to the mortgage insurers.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Over 55s developments
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Residential properties held under clear title in designated communities where age restrictions (generally greater than 55 years old) must be met in order for individuals to own and live in the property.
       <br/>
       These properties are not a retirement village as defined by the Retirement Villages Act 1999 nor are they any residential facility that provides assisted living in the form of nursing care, meal support or housekeeping. Refer
       <em>
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000684">
         Lending Value Ratio (LVR)
        </a>
        &gt; Rules &gt; Assessing LVR by Security Type
       </em>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Owner Builder
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       An owner-builder is anyone who takes on the responsibility of managing their own residential building project. This includes:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Coordinating and contracting roles usually undertaken by an architect or builder.
      </li>
      <li>
       Where any portion of the construction is carried out by the owner.
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         Refer to
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <a data-tagid="Qualifying Development Costs" href="#Qualifying Development Costs">
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          Qualifying Development Cost
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </a>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <a name="P">
     </a>
     <span>
      <span>
       PAP
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Premier Advantage Package
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Part time
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Employment type
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Usually less than 32 hours of work per week
      </li>
      <li>
       Work is regular and ongoing.  The weekly hours worked would vary little or not at all.
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       PAYG Applicant
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Pay as you go - used to describe applicants who work for an employer and are salary and wage earners and describes the method of paying tax.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Peak Debt
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     Peak debt is the total outstanding loan amount that may result for a Bridging (Relocation) loan, where the interest is capitalised over the full term of that facility.
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          For a new Bridging (Relocation) loan OBP will determine the peak debt, which will be based on the bridging loan amount plus interest over the full (maximum) loan term of 12 months. The interest rate used in the peak debt calculation is the standard owner occupier (O/O) interest only (IO) variable interest rate plus a 1% buffer. No package discounts are applied to the IO variable interest rate.
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Portable/ relocatable dwellings
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       A dwelling transported to a site and not permanently affixed in place, even if connected to services such as mobile homes converted to permanent or semi-permanent residences located in holiday parks or workers camps, temporary movable farm accommodations, caravans, caravan park allotments and converted buses. Refer
       <em>
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000684">
         Loan to Value Ratio (LVR)
        </a>
        &gt; Assessing Unacceptable Securities
       </em>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Power of Attorney
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       A written authorisation to another person, or persons, to perform certain acts for the signer
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Practical Completion
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        A term commonly used in the construction industry to indicate that the work has been done according to the contract and the building is suitable for occupation or use.
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Predominant Purpose
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       The predominant purpose of a loan is the purpose for which the majority of the loan funds will be used for.  Refer to
       <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000694">
        <em>
         Eligibility
        </em>
       </a>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Private School
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       A private school is defined as an independent school which is funded by a combination of parental contribution and federal and state government funding. This includes independent non-denominational schools as well as religious schools, e.g. Catholic schools.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Progress Payment
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       The construction loan amount will be paid out progressively when requested by builder as progress payments.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Purchased Leave
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Some employers offer their employees the ability to take additional leave above standard entitlements.
       <br/>
       Instead of taking the additional leave as unpaid, purchased leave allows the employee to receive a wage during the additional leave period. This is achieved by the employee receiving a reduced wage over the non leave period, via a salary sacrifice.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Purchase price
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       An amount quoted in a contract of sale, may be used to determine the security value where we have excluded the value/cost of chattels (furnishings) and any rebates or incentives offered by the vendor
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Put or Call
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     A ‘put’ or ‘call’ option is a method that can be used in a contract of sale to reflect an agreement to sell or purchase the property for a particular price at a future point in time or on the occurrence of an event.
     <br/>
     The ‘put’ or ‘call’ option operates to provide both parties with the right (but not the obligation) to compel the other party to buy or sell the property, as follows:
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          If a buyer exercises their ‘put’ option, this allows them to compel the vendor to sell,
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             If a vendor exercises their ‘call’ option, this allows them to compel the buyer to purchase, or
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          If there is ‘no exercise’ of the put or call option, then neither party exercises their option and the agreement comes to an end.
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <a id="Q" name="Q">
      <span>
       <span>
        Qualified title
       </span>
      </span>
     </a>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Warning placed on a certificate of title of a property, which means that the particulars set out as to ownership and interests in the property are not guaranteed by the Land Titles Office
       <br/>
       Will generally appear on titles recently converted from Old System to Real Property Act titles by the Land Titles Office. Solicitors will generally treat these as for Old Systems Titles. See also "Limited Title"
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <a id="Qualifying Development Costs" name="Qualifying Development Costs">
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         Qualifying Development Costs
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </a>
    </td>
    <td>
     The value of the security collateral being ‘constructed’, as used in the LVR calculation for a
     <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000688">
      Construction Loan
     </a>
     .
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Refer to ‘
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000684">
         Loan to Value Ratio
        </a>
        &gt; LVR calculation’
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <a name="R">
     </a>
     <span>
      <span>
       RA Valuation
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       A Restricted Assessment (RA) (also known as kerbside inspection) is a qualified opinion by a panel valuer of the market value range of a property based on an external inspection (kerbside) of the property. The valuer does not enter the property's boundaries. The valuer provides an indicative market range for a similar property in the same locality as the security collateral being valued. Refer
       <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000686">
        <em>
         Security Collateral Value
        </em>
       </a>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       RAP
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Risk Assessment Platform
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Refinance
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       The partial or full repayment of an existing secured or unsecured debt using loan funds. The facility may be closed (clearing debt) or may remain in place (reducing debt).
       <br/>
       The debt may be internal  or external.
       <br/>
       Refinance can be facilitated via a new loan or an increase to an existing loan
       <br/>
       Note:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       A refinance may also be considered a 'Debt Consolidation'. Refer definition for Debt Consolidation
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Registered proprietor
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Person or corporation who is registered at the Land Titles Office as proprietor (owner) of a particular property. There can be more than one registered proprietor of a property.
       <br/>
       Only a registered proprietor of a property can give a valid mortgage over the property to a mortgagee.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Regulated loan
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       A loan regulated under the National Credit Code
       <em>
        WBC
       </em>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <a id="Renovations to an already established dwelling" name="Renovations to an already established dwelling">
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         Renovations to an already established dwelling
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </a>
    </td>
    <td>
     Improvements made to an already established dwelling that may include, but are not limited to, updating internal fixtures and fittings (e.g. new bathroom or kitchen).
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <b>
          Does not include
         </b>
         any change(s) to an existing floor plan, full or partial
         <a data-tagid="Demolition of an already established dwelling" href="#Demolition of an already established dwelling">
          demolition
         </a>
         ,
         <b>
          or
         </b>
         the construction of an attached
         <b>
          or
         </b>
         standalone dwelling on the title, e.g. granny flat
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <div>
      <div>
       <div id="_com_1" language="JavaScript">
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            Refer to
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
        <a data-tagid="Qualifying Development Costs" href="#Qualifying Development Costs">
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            <span>
             Qualifying Development Cost
            </span>
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </a>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <a id="Rental income received on a long term basis" name="Rental income received on a long term basis">
      Rental income received on a long term basis
     </a>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      Property is self-contained and is rented out to a single tenant or group of tenants usually on a vacant possession basis. Leases may be between 6 months and 24 months in length and give the tenant/s right to occupy the whole of the premises.
     </span>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       Note: For the purpose of rental income, a granny flat is considered the “whole premises” when it is a fully self-contained separate area of occupancy with a minimum of 1 conventional bedroom (not a studio / partitioned space) with full living facilities including standard kitchen, bathroom facilities and direct independent access.
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <span>
      The property is
      <b>
       not
      </b>
      rented on a room by room basis or a room within an owner occupied dwelling
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <a id="Rental income received on a short term basis" name="Rental income received on a short term basis">
      Rental income received on a short term basis
     </a>
    </td>
    <td>
     The property is typically tenanted for says of less than 6 months at a time (except for student accommodation) where the occupant has sole  / exclusive use of the whole property. A property rented on a short term basis may be a:
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         Standard investment property rented on a holiday basis (e.g. rented through Airbnb or Stays)
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            Serviced apartment, Hotel / Motel or holiday accommodation
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            Student accommodation
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            Self contained granny flat
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <span>
      <span>
       Note: For the purpose of rental income, a granny flat is considered the “whole premises” when it is a fully self-contained separate area of occupancy with a minimum of 1 conventional bedroom (not a studio / partitioned space) with full living facilities including standard kitchen, bathroom facilities and direct independent access.
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <span>
      The property is
      <b>
       not
      </b>
      rented on a room by room basis or a room within an owner occupied dwelling
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     Renter
    </td>
    <td>
     Someone who rents a property from a landlord and has exclusive right to the rented property during a lease term.
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        There is usually a written tenancy agreement signed by both the landlord and the tenant.
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Residential Long Form Valuation
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Residential Long Form Valuation Report is also known as a comprehensive valuation report. A full length, detailed report. A Residential Long Form valuation report is not in a standard format. Refer
       <em>
        <span>
         <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000686">
          Security Collateral Value
         </a>
         &gt; Rules &gt;  Default Residential Long Form Valuation Scenarios
        </span>
       </em>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Residential dwelling to be erected (e.g. by licensed builder or owner builder)
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Construction of a standalone dwelling or duplex, structural renovations to an existing property or multi-unit residential developments. Refer
      </span>
      <em>
       <span>
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000682">
         Acceptable Security Collateral
        </a>
       </span>
      </em>
     </span>
     <em>
      <span>
       &gt; Rules you must apply &gt; Identifying Standard Real Estate Security Collateral
      </span>
     </em>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         Refer to
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <a data-tagid="Qualifying Development Costs" href="#Qualifying Development Costs">
      <span>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          Qualifying Development Cost
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </span>
     </a>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Residential Short Form Valuation
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       A residential Short Form valuation report (also known as Property Pro report), is an industry based standard 2 to 3 page (usually) valuation report for use on an average residential property. Refer
       <em>
        <span>
         <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000686">
          Security Collateral Value
         </a>
         &gt; Rules &gt; Default Residential Short Form Valuation Scenarios
        </span>
       </em>
      </span>
      <br/>
      In most instances where a valuation report is required, valuers will prepare a standard valuation (Short Form report).
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     Resort rental
    </td>
    <td>
     See
     <a data-tagid="Rental income received on a short term basis" href="#Rental income received on a short term basis">
      Rental income received on a short term basis
     </a>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Retired
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Employment type
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Having left one's job and ceased to be working
      </li>
      <li>
       All or majority of income is derived from pensions (including aged and service pensions from Government sources), investments and / or annuities.
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Retirement village accommodation
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Retirement villages are designed for people aged over 55 years or older or are retired from full-time employment (or are spouses/partners of such people).
       <br/>
       Such residents receive accommodation and services, other than services provided in a residential care or aged care facility. Refer
       <em>
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000682">
         Acceptable Security Collateral
        </a>
        &gt;
       </em>
      </span>
      <em>
       <span>
        Assessing security Collateral requirements - Non-standard Development
       </span>
      </em>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Reverse Mortgage
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     A reverse mortgage is designed for people aged over 60 years or older using the equity in your Owner Occupied property as security, to advance funds.
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        The borrower is not required to make repayments, interest and fees compound and add to the principal amount borrowed. Normally the loan is repaid in full when the borrower (or deceased estate) sells the security.
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Rural property (non-specialised)
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Income-producing properties used for rural/primary production activities such as grazing of stock common for the area and cropping of standard broad acre and horticultural crops. They may also be non-income producing hobby farms with a land area in excess of 8 hectares that do not meet the requirements of 'residential real estate'. Refer
      </span>
      <em>
       <span>
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000682">
         Acceptable Security Collateral
        </a>
       </span>
      </em>
     </span>
     <em>
      <span>
       &gt; Rules &gt; Assessing Unacceptable Security Collateral
      </span>
     </em>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Rural property (specialised)
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Properties restricted to primary production use or a use that cannot be readily adapted to alternative uses and retain their current market value in the process (e.g. intensive poultry, intensive piggeries and boutique ventures such as emu or alpaca grazing).
       <br/>
       Other specialised rural properties may contain water allocation rights or licence. These rights can influence and inflate a purchase price. They can also be sold or traded separately to the security property itself. These properties are normally found adjoining major river systems. Refer
       <em>
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000682">
         Acceptable Security Collateral
        </a>
        &gt;
       </em>
      </span>
      <em>
       <span>
        Assessing security Collateral requirements - Non-standard Development
       </span>
      </em>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <a name="S">
     </a>
     <span>
      <span>
       S.C.A.T.T.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Solicitor's Certificate as to Title and Undertaking - which is the certification given by the Bank's solicitor or Mortgage Preparer that all appropriate enquiries in relation to the proposed security have been satisfied, all appropriate documentation has been executed by the borrowers/mortgagors, and that funds are to be released in preparation for settlement. In addition the solicitor also undertakes to complete the matter in a timely fashion including the lodgement of documents for registration and return to the Bank.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       SDA
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Specialist Disability Accommodation
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Search
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       The examination of records and registers at offices of public record (e.g.. Lands Titles Office, Australian Securities and Investment Commission) to determine ownership, encumbrances and information (such as registered mortgages and charges) that are essential to effectively determine the Bank's security position, secure and settle advances.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Security Collateral Value
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Refers to the value of the property offered as security collateral determined in accordance with the valuation methods defined in this policy and is used in the calculation of loan to value ratio (LVR).
       <br/>
       The Security Collateral Value may be based on:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Contract of sale (purchase price)
      </li>
      <li>
       Validated customer estimated market value
      </li>
      <li>
       An acceptable Valuation
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Serviceability Repayment Amount
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       The repayment amount which is ultimately used within the serviceability assessment
       <br/>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Serviceability Assessment Rate (SAR)
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       The interest rate which is applied within the calculation of the monthly payment/commitment used for serviceability
       <br/>
       Refer
       <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000710">
        <em>
         Serviceability Assessment
        </em>
       </a>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Serviced apartment
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       A fully furnished apartment available for short-term stays that provides hotel-like amenities, such as room service, a fitness centre and shared laundry. Most are equipped with full kitchens, Wi-Fi and internal washer and dryers.
      </span>
     </span>
     Refer to
     <a data-tagid="Rental income received on a short term basis" href="#Rental income received on a short term basis">

       Servicing capacity

    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       See Disposable Income

     </span>
    </td>

       Settlement

     <span>
      <span>
       The purchaser of a property hands over the balance of purchase price in exchange for the title documents and keys. Also called 'completion'.
       <br/>
       Settlement of the loan funds will not necessarily coincide with the settlement of the purchase.

     </span>

       SFSS

       SGB

    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       St George Bank

     </span>

     </span>

       Self-managed Super Fund

     </span>
    </td>

     <span>
      <span>
       Snow leases
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Properties located in the Snowfields with ownership held under a lease/head lease structure. Example: Located in Kosciusko National Park subject to a head lease from the National Parks and Wildlife Service and Kosciusko Thredbo Pty Ltd.
      </span>
     </span>
     Refer to
     <a data-tagid="Rental income received on a short term basis" href="#Rental income received on a short term basis">
      Rental income received on a short term basis
     </a>
     and
     <span>
      <span>
       <em>
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000682">
         Acceptable Security Collateral
        </a>
        &gt;
       </em>
      </span>
      <em>
       <span>
        Assessing security Collateral requirements - Non-standard Development
       </span>
      </em>
     </span>
    </td>

   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Social Security Recipient
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Employment type
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       In receipt of a Government Income support payment (e.g. age pension, Family tax benefit)
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Split contracts (multi-unit residential developments
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Split contract for a multi-unit residential developments, generally a developer is seeking to sell and settle the land prior to construction of the houses/townhouses/units occurring. Refer
       <em>
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000682">
         Acceptable Security Collateral
        </a>
        &gt;
       </em>
      </span>
      <em>
       <span>
        Assessing security Collateral requirements - Non-standard Development
       </span>
      </em>
     </span>
    </td>

   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Split contracts (single residential property constructions)
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       <br/>
       Single, stand-alone residential property constructions with no common roadways, common access ways and in particular common walls or slab, even where there is a split contract involved (such as a standard house and land package). Refer
       <em>
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000682">
         Acceptable Security Collateral
        </a>
        &gt;
       </em>
      </span>
      <em>
       <span>
        Assessing security Collateral requirements - Non-standard Development
       </span>
      </em>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       SRO
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       State Revenue Office
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Stamp duty
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Form of tax charged by state government on certain documents or transactions e.g. contract of sale, mortgage, share transfers, leases etc.
       <br/>
       The rate at which duty is payable will depend on the state, and type of instrument/document.
      </span>

    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Spousal

     </span>

    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Married or de facto relationship
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       SSL
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Student Start-up Loan
       <br/>
       See
       <a href="#Study and Training Support Loans">
        <em>
         Study and Training Support Loans
        </em>
       </a>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Strata title
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Home units divided into lots. These lots form the strata plan for that building. The owners of a unit own a lot in the Strata Plan. The Strata Plan is managed by the Body Corporate. A separate Certificate of Title is issued by the Land Titles Office in respect of each individual home unit.
       <br/>
       There is also a Certificate of Title in relation to the common property (e.g. stairs) but should never be mortgaged by the Body Corporate.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Stratum title
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Stratum title pre-dates modern strata title subdivisions. Under stratum title, the property is subdivided into lots. Each unit owner is the registered proprietor of their lot and also holds shares in a service company established under the Corporations Act 2001. The service company owns and manages common property.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Structural renovation or extensions
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       As a guide structural renovations include additional rooms, or new floors being added, or other significant changes to a dwellings structure. Excluded are cosmetic changes such as internal/external painting, bathroom/kitchen renovations, pools, landscaping.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Student
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Employment type
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Principally involved in academic study with little or no income
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Student accommodation
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Similar to any residential dwelling where property are mainly rented to students as temporary accommodation.
       <br/>
       A dormitory (dorm) or boarding house that provides sleeping and residential quarters for large numbers of students in school, college or university are not acceptable form of student accommodation to the bank.
      </span>
     </span>
     Refer to
     <a data-tagid="Rental income received on a short term basis" href="#Rental income received on a short term basis">
      Rental income received on a short term basis
     </a>
     and
     <span>
      <span>
       <em>
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000682">
         Acceptable Security Collateral
        </a>
        &gt;
       </em>
      </span>
      <em>
       <span>
        Assessing security Collateral requirements - Non-standard Development
       </span>
      </em>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <a name="Study and Training Support Loans">
      <span>
       <span>
        Study and Training Support Loans
       </span>
      </span>
     </a>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Government financial assistance loans for people undertaking higher education, trade apprenticeships and other training programs.
       <br/>
       HECS/HELP/VSL/SFSS/SSL/ABSTUDY SSL/TSL
       <br/>
       Refer
       <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000710">
        <em>
         Serviceability Assessment
        </em>
       </a>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Substitution of security
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       A loan variation activity which allows the security on an existing loan to be changed while the loans remains open .
       <br/>
       Also known in WBC as a 'Portability'
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Superannuation Guarantee Charge (SGC)
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Contributions into Super are made by employer and must be equal or greater than to 9.5% of your 'ordinary time earnings'. The ATO defines 'ordinary earnings' as what an employee earns for ordinary hours of work. It includes things like commissions and allowance but not overtime.
       <br/>
       Where an employee salary sacrifices for any reason the employer can apply the SGC to the total ordinary earnings
       <strong>
        <span>
         or
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
      the total ordinary earnings after the salary sacrifice.
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Supported Guarantee
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       The guarantors security is used to support the loan application i.e. the applicant should be able to service the proposed loan commitments however requires assistance from a guarantor to provide additional security. A guarantee is required for each mortgagor who is not a borrower for a particular facility.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Surety
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Person who makes themselves responsible for another's payment of debt; also known as the guarantor.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Survey
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Diagrammatical representation &amp; report from a qualified surveyor, showing the boundaries of a specific property and any existing or proposed improvements. The report attached to the diagram indicates whether the building complies with local government ordinances e.g. distance of exterior walls to boundaries.
       <br/>
       The report may also state whether there are any encroachments from buildings or fencing on or by adjoining properties.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <a name="T">
     </a>
     <span>
      <span>
       TAE
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Total Approved Exposure - applicant's borrowing exposure to the Bank covers all liabilities including unsecured loans and credit cards
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Tax Bill
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       An amount payable to the Taxation Office for
       <strong>
        <span>
         previous
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
      year/s tax which
      <strong>
       <span>
        is not yet due
       </span>
      </strong>
     </span>
     <span>
      <span>
       as at full application date.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       e.g. $4,000 payable for Notice of Assessment -year ended 30 June 2019.
       <br/>
       Payment due 26 November 2019
       <br/>
       Full application date 5 November 2019
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Tax Debt-Type A
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       A formal payment plan with the Taxation Office to pay
       <strong>
        <span>
         previous
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
     </span>
     <span>
      <span>
       year/s tax in agreed instalments over an agreed period of time.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       This does not include any arrangements to
       <strong>
        <span>
         pre-pay
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
      tax expected to be payable for the
      <strong>
       <span>
        current
       </span>
      </strong>
     </span>
     tax year, e.g.
     <em>
      <span>
       <span>
        PAYG Instalments
       </span>
      </span>
     </em>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Tax Debt-Type B
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       An amount payable to the Taxation Office for
       <strong>
        <span>
         previous
        </span>
       </strong>
      </span>
      year/s tax which
      <strong>
       <span>
        is overdue
       </span>
      </strong>
     </span>
     <span>
      <span>
       at full application date and no formal payment plan is in place with the Taxation Office.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       e.g. $4,000 payable for Notice of Assessment -year ended 30 June 2019.
       <br/>
       Payment due 26 November 2019
       <br/>
       Full application date 5 December and $4,000 has not been paid
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <a id="TBE Valuation" name="TBE Valuation">
      <span>
       <span>
        TBE Valuation
       </span>
      </span>
     </a>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       To be erected or 'as if complete' or 'on completion' valuation.
      </span>
     </span>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        May also be referred to as a ‘Construction’ valuation.
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       The terms refer to a valuation being done on the basis of a property that is yet to be constructed or is not yet fully constructed.
       <br/>
       It can include existing dwellings where an extension is being added or renovations are being undertaken, vacant land where a stand-alone dwelling will be built or a multi-unit development.
       <br/>
       <br/>
       Refer to:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <em>
          <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000688">
           Construction loans
          </a>
         </em>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <a data-tagid="Qualifying Development Costs" href="#Qualifying Development Costs">
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            Qualifying Development Cost
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </a>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       T &amp; C
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Terms and Conditions letter
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Temporary
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Employment type
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Temporary employment is short term, of a seasonal nature or has a termination date
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Tenants in common
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       A form of co-ownership in which the property is held in common with others. Tenants in common have fixed undivided shares in the property. Tenants in common can have unequal shares (for example, two-thirds to one and one-third to the other).
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Tenants in Common title
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Not to be confused with Tenants in Common above. (A forerunner of strata title and not very common).
       <br/>
       This is title given to home unit owners, where the right of occupation of a particular unit in a building, is given by the ownership of a share of the whole property registered with the Land Titles Office.
       <br/>
       Each home unit owner is issued with a certificate of title in their name. The owners are all a party to a Deed that governs the use of the common property.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Third party security
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Security collateral offered by a person or persons not identical to the borrower (s) such as a company offering company directions or the security collateral is owned by two people but offered as collateral for a loan for only one of those people). Refer
       <em>
        Guarantees
       </em>
      </span>
      .
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Timeshare property
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       A form of ownership or right to use a particular property or properties, such as a holiday villa, apartment or cabin for a set period of time. Refer
       <em>
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000682">
         Acceptable Security Collateral
        </a>
        &gt;
       </em>
      </span>
      <em>
       <span>
        Assessing security Collateral requirements - Non-standard Development
       </span>
      </em>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Torrens title
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       System whereby ownership and all dealings on a property are detailed on the one document, i.e. A Certificate of Title or Deed of Grant.
       <br/>
       Under this system a mortgage is a charge or encumbrance on the title.
       <br/>
       Registration is compulsory to effect legal transfer of an interest in property, and each time the property is sold, mortgaged, or a mortgage discharged, the transaction is recorded on the Certificate of Title.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Trading entity
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       An entity that is 'Trading' is involved in a production activity (i.e. manufacturing or sales of goods or services).
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       If creditors, debtors or stock are observed on the balance sheet, and/or if a measure of 'cost of goods sold' is observed on the profit and loss statement the entity is considered to be trading.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Transfer
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       A document transferring ownership of property under the Real Property Act e.g. in the case of a sale, the vendor signs this document to enable transfer of ownership to the purchaser at settlement.
       <br/>
       This document is liable for stamp duty, and is registered at the Land Titles Office.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Transportable homes
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       A dwelling transported to site and permanently affixed in place and connected to services (e.g. water, gas, electricity, sewerage) and cannot be moved again. Refer
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Trust
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       A trust is an obligation imposed on a person or other entity to hold property for the benefit of the beneficiaries. The trustee is responsible for managing the trust's affairs.
       <br/>
       Common types of rusts are:
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <strong>
        <span>
         Bare Trust
        </span>
       </strong>
       : A trust where there is no trust deed. This type of trust commonly arises from a single transaction (e.g. used when a superannuation fund is purchasing a property)
      </li>
      <li>
       <strong>
        <span>
         Discretionary Trust
        </span>
       </strong>
       : The trustee has discretion as to how to distribute income and assets between beneficiaries. The beneficiaries are usually described by reference to a certain criteria. Generally, it is not possible to clearly identify all of the potential beneficiaries (e.g. a Family Trust)
      </li>
      <li>
       <strong>
        <span>
         Unit Trust:
        </span>
       </strong>
       The beneficiaries hold units in the trust and funds and assets can be distributed according to the unit holdings. The unit holders can be easily determined at any given time. Unit Trust can be listed or unlisted.
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       TSE
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Total Secured Exposure - Is the total of all loan exposure against the (proposed) new and/or existing residential real estate security collateral(s).
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       TSL
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Trade Support Loan
       <br/>
       See
       <a href="#Study and Training Support Loans">
        <em>
         Study and Training Support Loans
        </em>
       </a>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <a name="U">
     </a>
     <span>
      <span>
       UCCC
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Uniform Consumer Credit Code.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Unemployed
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Employment type
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       Not currently employed but actively seeking employment and / or in receipt of unemployment benefits
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Unit
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Any property with a unit number or entitlement allocated including but not limited to: duplex, triplex, villa, strata title unit, townhouse, apartment, company title unit, community title unit, stratum title unit.
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Unregulated loan
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Any loan not covered by the definition of Regulated Loan
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Unsupported Guarantee
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       The guarantor's income is used to support a loan application, i.e. the applicant has insufficient income to meet serviceability and the guarantor's income is sufficient to assist. Reliance on an unsupported guarantee is only acceptable from a married or defacto partner. Refer
       <em>
        Guarantees
       </em>
      </span>
      .
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <a name="V">
     </a>
     <span>
      <span>
       Vacant land
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Land void of any improvements  (must be residential)
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       VSL
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       VET Student Loans
       <br/>
       See
       <a href="#Study and Training Support Loans">
        <em>
         Study and Training Support Loans
        </em>
       </a>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <a name="W">
     </a>
     <span>
      <span>
       WBC
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Westpac Banking Corporation
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       WBG
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Westpac Banking Group - incorporating Westpac, St George Bank Group and RAMs
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       WLMI
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Westpac Lenders Mortgage Insurance
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <a id="Z" name="Z">
      <span>
       <span>
        Zoning certificate
       </span>
      </span>
     </a>
    </td>
    <td>
     <span>
      <span>
       Certificates from the local government (i.e. council) stating the zoning of a property (e.g. residential, commercial, industrial) and whether proposed or existing council plans affect the property
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
  </tbody>
 </table>

 </h2>
 <h3>
  <a name="A_About_Lender’s_Mortgage_Insurance_(LMI">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      1.1  Why this policy
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h3>
 <table>
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <b>
         Purpose
        </b>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Lender’s mortgage insurance :
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          protects
          <b>
           the Bank
          </b>
          against loss in the event the borrower defaults which results in the sale of the security property, and there is a shortfall in the sale proceeds to cover the debt owing to the Bank.
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <b>
           does not
          </b>
          provide any protection for
          <b>
           the borrower
          </b>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          is required when the loan to security value ratio (LVR) exceeds the Non-MI maximum lending value ratio.  Refer
          <em>
           <span>
            <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000684">
             Loan to Value Ratio (LVR)
            </a>
           </span>
          </em>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <b>
         Applicable to
        </b>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Consumer mortgage applications for:
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           new loan
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           loan increase
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           variations to an existing mortgage insured loan where the mortgage insurer’s risk is increased or amended
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td valign="top">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        <b>
         Lender’s mortgage insurance cover
        </b>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           For construction loans, commences from the date of the first draw down (i.e. settlement for land) or the date of the initial loan establishment and / or drawdown and where payment of the LMI Premium is received.
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           Will be for 100% of the principal, interest, legal and selling costs
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           For
           <strong>
            <span>
             all
            </span>
           </strong>
           loans, LMI cover is valid for the duration of the loan contract or the expiration of the loan term (i.e. residential principal and interest loans, or residential Combination Loans) unless a variation to the contract’s terms and conditions are agreed to, which may necessitate an additional premium being payable.
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <span>
           For
           <b>
            Bridging loans
           </b>
           the period of cover applies for the Bridging period and will continue on the end debt situation if LMI cover is still required.
          </span>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
  </tbody>
 </table>

 <h3>
  <a name="R_Approval_Authority">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      2.3 Lenders mortgage insurance approval
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h3>
 <table>
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <h4>
      <span>
       <span>
        Restrictions
       </span>
      </span>
     </h4>
    </td>
    <td colspan="2">
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          An LMI policy, approval or In Principle Approval (IPA) should not be issued until applicants have met acceptable minimum credit standards. Final approval is subject to the satisfactory completion of all verification activities required of the Broker, Assessor and the Mortgage Centre / Verification Teams
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          A consumer mortgage application meeting LMI lending value ratio is not an indication of approval
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <h4>
      <span>
       <span>
        ALMI Underwriting Standards
       </span>
      </span>
     </h4>
    </td>
    <td colspan="2">
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          ALMI will underwrite mortgage insurance up to the following:
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
       <ul>
        <li>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            $2,500,000 mortgage insured exposure to a single borrower across the Westpac Group
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
        <li>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            $2,500,000 at an LVR of up to 95% in a single loan including capitalising of the LMI premium
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
       </ul>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          ALMI has its own set of acceptance criteria ‘ALMI Underwriting Policy’, based on the level of risk it is prepared to undertake. This criteria may vary from the Bank’s credit policy for acceptable risk.
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <h4>
      <span>
       <span>
        Credit Rules -Loan amount and LVR
       </span>
      </span>
     </h4>
    </td>
    <td colspan="2">
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          All Credit rules utilise the base loan amount and the base LVR, with the exception of serviceability assessments where repayments are based on the capitalised loan amount
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td rowspan="6">
     <h4>
      <span>
       <span>
        LMI approval and authorities
       </span>
      </span>
     </h4>
    </td>
    <td colspan="2">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        ALMI operates a Delegated Underwriting Authority (DUA) in conjunction with authorised Credit employees, whereby Credit may issue LMI policies on behalf of ALMI, provided that certain criteria are met.
        <br/>
        <br/>
        Approval criteria is detailed within Consumer Credit Policy and the individuals DUA authority letters.
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     <br/>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        LMI may be approved either:
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2">
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <b>
           within LMI open policy (DUA1) by authorised WBC employees
          </b>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="2">
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          <b>
           outside open policy:
          </b>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <ul>
        <li>
         <span>
          <span>
           <span>
            by authorised LMI DUA Holders (DUA2):
           </span>
          </span>
         </span>
        </li>
       </ul>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
    <td>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          Applications referred outside the open policy should have a basis for consideration given higher LVR
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          Lenders / Assessors need to provide mitigating factors, such as financial position, stability, income / servicing, existing customer history and / or security to warrant cover at the level sought
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          by ALMI underwriters (DUA4), for loan applications outside of both open policy parameters and DUA2 approval levels
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
    <td>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          Credit must assess the credit worthiness of the application and if they consider the application worthwhile, recommend the loan to ALMI underwriters (DUA4) for consideration and approval.
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <h4>
      <span>
       <span>
        <strong>
         <span>
          Genuine savings, 10% equity, Customer contribution
         </span>
        </strong>
       </span>
      </span>
     </h4>
    </td>
    <td colspan="2">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        New loans and loan increases requiring LMI must comply with the policy detailed under
        <em>
        </em>
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000717">
         <i>
          Genuine Savings, Equity and Customer Contribution
         </i>
        </a>
        <em>
         <span>
          .
         </span>
        </em>
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td>
     <h4>
      <span>
       <span>
        Duty of disclosure
       </span>
      </span>
     </h4>
    </td>
    <td colspan="2">
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        Duty of disclosure is owed to the insurer under the Insurance Contracts Act.
        <br/>
        <br/>
        It requires disclosure to the mortgage insurer of all matters known, or that could reasonably be expected to have been known, that are relevant to the Insurer’s decision as to whether to accept the risk of the Insurance, and if so, on what terms.
        <br/>
        <br/>
        This duty also extends to any subsequent renewal, variance or reinstatement of the LMI contract.
        <br/>
        <br/>
        Failure to comply with the duty of disclosure, may entitle the insurer to reduce its liability under the LMI contract in respect of a claim and or to cancel the contract.
        <br/>
        <br/>
        If the non-disclosure is dishonest (made knowingly), the insurer may also have the option of avoiding the contract.
        <br/>
        <br/>
        Also see
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000698">
         Loan Application and Approval
        </a>
        &gt; Validation of information provided by the customer
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
    </td>
   </tr>
  </tbody>
 </table>
 <div>
  <div>
   <div id="_com_1" language="JavaScript" onmouseout="msoCommentHide('_com_1')" onmouseover="msoCommentShow('_anchor_1','_com_1')">

 <h3>
  <a name="R_Variations_to_loans">
  </a>
  <strong>
   <span>
    <span>
     <span>
      2.4 Existing insured loans - Variations and Top Up premiums
     </span>
    </span>
   </span>
  </strong>
 </h3>
 <table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="1">
  <thead>
   <tr>
    <th scope="col">
     <b>
      Scenario
     </b>
    </th>
    <th scope="col">
     <b>
      Action
     </b>
    </th>
    <th scope="col" valign="top">
     <b>
      LMI waiver - Legacy LMI providers ‘QBE and
     </b>
     <strong>
      Helia (formerly Genworth)
     </strong>
     <b>
      ’
     </b>
    </th>
   </tr>
  </thead>
  <tbody>
   <tr>
    <td>
     For:
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          A Loan Increase or other variation to an existing mortgaged insured loan, or
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          An internal refinance of an existing mortgaged insured loan
          <sup>
           1
          </sup>
          , or
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          A new application using security collateral already covered by an existing mortgage insurance policy
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
    <td>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        Whenever the mortgage insurer’s risk is increased or amended, the mortgage insurer will be notified by the responsible processing area
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        Prior to the Bank notifying approval to the customer, the mortgage insurer is to approve the variation and use of the existing policy
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        The change will generally be applied to the existing policy and insurer
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        Where additional LMI is required, the premium will be calculated by using the new total exposure amount and LVR Policy, and taking into consideration any previous premiums paid by the customer (premium credits).
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
     Exceptions apply for ‘Legacy LMI providers ‘QBE and Helia (formerly Genworth)' as detailed in the next column
    </td>
    <td valign="top">
     Where Lender’s Mortgage Insurance is required and the existing policy cover is held with QBE or Helia (formerly Genworth):
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        OBP will waive Lender’s Mortgage Insurance up to the MI-Max base LVR applicable under ‘
        <a href="https://creditriskpolicies.westpac.com.au/app/answers/answer_view/a_id/1000684">
         Loan to Value Ratio (LVR)
        </a>
        ’ policy for any of the below scenarios:
       </span>
       <ul>
        <li>
         <span>
          Loan increase to the existing insured loan
         </span>
        </li>
        <li>
         <span>
          An internal refinance of the existing mortgaged insured loan
         </span>
        </li>
        <li>
         <span>
          A new application using security collateral already covered by the existing mortgage insurance policy
         </span>
        </li>
       </ul>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <b>
      Applications with this waiver applied are assessed to non-LMI standards
     </b>
     <br/>
     <br/>
     <span>
      It is not permissible to have multiple insurers with an interest in the same property.
     </span>
     <br/>
     <span>
      <span>
       <span>
        A restructure of a new mortgage insured application is required when
       </span>
      </span>
     </span>
     :
     <ul>
      <li>
       <span>
        <span>
         <span>
          an existing security collateral offered is already covered by an existing ALMI or WLMI mortgage insurance policy,
          <b>
           and
          </b>
         </span>
        </span>
       </span>
      </li>
      <li>
       <span>
        another existing security collateral offered is already covered by an existing QBE or
       </span>
       Helia (formerly Genworth)
       <span>
        mortgage insurance policy
       </span>
      </li>
     </ul>
    </td>
   </tr>
   <tr>
    <td colspan="3">
     <sup>
      1
     </sup>
     For WBC: SGB, BoM, BSA and RAMS are considered to be external providers
    </td>
   </tr>
  </tbody>
 </table>
